Very convenient with superb location, easy access to subway station directly from the hotel. Perfect for business and leisure trip. Shops, restaurants, cafes, convenient stores, department stores, 24 hrs mcdonald and public transportation are all around and in walking distance. Indoor parking available at the building where the hotel is loacted with special overnight discount rate for hotel guest. Can not fault of any service at time of our stay. However, lobby is on 2nd floor which may affect a little bit of inconvenience if you need any immediate assistance. More impressive than expected. Inter-connecting rooms available. Complimentary 2 bottles of water daily. 'Handy' phone provided and very useful.
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We stayed here for 6 nights. Location couldn’t be better-2blocks off the main Ginza street and many restaurants/fast food places in the area. The subway is right next door and the access is also through the hotel. The front desk personnel are exceptionally helpful and personable. The only complaint I have is that the breakfast-which is not included in the room rate-is very sparse especially re fresh fruit. Also the rooms are small as v the Tokyo Hilton on the other side of town.
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Here for two nights pre-cruise and this was a great location. The hotel is clean, modern and very quiet. We were on the fifth floor and had no noise pollution either from neighbours or outside.The hotel is easy to get to, surrounded by many subway stations. Our first time in japan and we took the subway, getting here easily after a short walk from the station. As others have indicated, there’s a McDonald’s in the same block and lots of stores like 7-11, Starbucks and high end retail nearby.We particularly enjoyed going into the ‘Food Stage’ level of the Matsuya department store a black away, where there was fantastic fresh food on sale and many taste tests available.We had booked a privilege room, and I am not sure if it was because of this, or is a standard feature here, bu we greatly appreciate the extra benefit of having a smart phone in our room that we could take with us on our travels and use to make free local and international calls. We were also delighted when we got an early check in — our room was ready on arrival at 11am.It is worth noting that this hotel does not do lunch, dinner or room service. This was not a problem for us as there were so many great food options nearby. We would definitively stay here again when visiting Tokyo.
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The hotel is very modern and centrally located in Ginza. What i like about this hotel is its location. Very short walk going to the many shops and malls in Ginza. Very accessible, basement of the hotel is the local train station. About 15min walk to the main JR Tokyo Station. Hotel has its own restaurant but a little more expensive. If you are feeling a little trifty, there's a McDonald's store and a number of convenience stores (Lawson, Family Mart, 7Eleven) just right across the corner. There are also numerous restaurants offering local fare, e.g. ramen, tonkatsu, sashimi near the vicinity of the hotel.The rooms are very clean and the staffs are very helpful. Wifi is complimentary. We utilised our membership points so we were upgraded to a grand room on the 12th floor. We booked a total of 3 rooms since we were 3 families. Other 2 rooms were only standard rooms. The Grand room was good for family of 5pax, we were 3 adults and 2 kids aged 13 and 8. Snacks and beverages on the minibar were all complimentary. Coffee maker and tea pot were also available. My only comment is about the bathroom. It was quite small and the shower/ bath tub area on the room that we stayed in has no curtain so we were careful in taking a shower to prevent water spilling on to the bathroom floor. We stayed at Rm 1216. On our last night, we transfered to a standard room. It can only accomodate 4 pax. One of our kids joined their grandparents on another room. The room has the same size of bathroom. There was a shower curtain on the bathtub area. However, one of the cabinet door was off it's hinges and had tendency to fall off. We never bothered to call guest services and just left it as it was. Overall, the hotel was nice. Only recommendation i can give is to improve on their quality control to correct minor defects.
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The Mercure was booked by our travel agent and was a good choice. In Ginza, a bustling area with restaurants, shopping and direct access to a metro line in the basement of the hotel, we felt part of Tokyo. There's a convenience store at the end of the street, and a McDonalds and Starbucks as well. The room we were in was on the third floor, small and perfectly formed, but a little dreary in terms of natural light because of the building opposite. It had everything we needed - except for power points near the bed and enough power points in accessible locations. We ended up charging devices in the bathroom because they were the easiest power points to get to. I appreciated having the kettle in the room so I can make tea. Check in staff are excellent - truly some of the best I have interacted with over the many years I've been staying in hotels - and they go above and beyond what is normally expected of reception staff. The bar and dining area could do with a refit and I noted that only breakfast will be served in the restaurant after 30 April. Breakfast is the standard hotel buffet fare, but it's enough and it's good. The bar area does need a little work to more it more 'cosy' and comfortable though.All in all, a good stay, no problems and very good service.
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Although the rooms are perfectly adequate, the location is ideal, and we are generally fans of Accor hotels, this one had such terrible service (cigarette smoke in the room; extremely food receptionist: chaos in the lobby) and was so disorganized (mistake in status so that we did not receive benefits until later after we pointed this out) that we cannot recommend. We arrived at the hotel on Friday evening and were greeted by a scene of extreme chaos at check in. When we were finally given the keys to our room, we were shocked to find that it reeked of cigarette smoke. We called reception to request a new room. To this request, we were asked, “Have you used the bed? Don’t mess up the sheets!”Perhaps so they can foist the room on the next guest without another cleaning, despite the excessive cigarette smoke? You have all been warnedRudeness aside, the hotel is chaotic. There is no priority check in, and seemingly no order in which customers are served. The hotel had also mistaken our Accor status number so that we did not receive the benefits (drinks, room upgrade) until later in the stay. Check out was not much better, with only a single receptionist working at 10:45.While we appreciated the status conferred room upgrade halfway through our stay, the room did not become available until late afternoon so that we were left without a room during the day of the upgrade. When we checked in with the receptionist at 3:30, we were told that the room had not yet been cleaned.
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Cannot believe how small and cramped the rooms are here as we barely have room for our bags . Suggest you check the rooms first.Apparently the rooms are earthquake proof with massive beams taking up all the space.
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The rooms are clean and spacious for japan standards... Great hotel for families. Friendly and helpful staff. Breakfast was very good with enough choices. Location of the hotel is perfect as just above the subway and a lot of restaurants nearby...
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: It’s a small, modern hotel right next door to designer labels and flagship stores. There’s an underground connection leading to a couple subway stations. So, very convenient for shopping and getting around.Tokyo JR station is a bit farther – about 15-20 min by walk from Marunouchi South exit 八重洲南口. (It’s actually closer, ~10 min, via Exit 2 of Keiyu Line 京葉線but you’ll have to walk up 3 floors) – manageable as we didn’t have a lot of luggage but still less than ideal. The airport bus station at Ginza is closer (~7 min by walk), and it’s cheaper (1,000 yen versus well over 3,000 yen of Narita Express). So, we took the bus when we left for the airport.The room itself is also small but well-appointed – there’s even a smart phone available for our use in town (with free wi-fi and calls!)Overall, our stay there was satisfactory. But the price of this hotel is not cheap. If we don’t have to stay in the Ginza area, we might explore other options next time.
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We stayed here for three nights and found it to be fine for our requirements. Good access to transport links and Ginza itself is awash with fab restaurants for a variety of budgets (reserve in advanced if you can). We ate at Kushiyaki Bistro Fukumimi one night, it was fantastic and only a few hundred meters from the hotel. The staff were very helpful in booking restaurants, suggesting places to visit and were generally polite and courteous. There is no dining facilities after breakfast, but step out of the hotel and you don’t have to go far to find somewhere to eat. There is a bar, which opens from 3pm. Special mention to the breakfast staff who were all really welcoming and friendly; we found the breakfast to have a good selection of options and which were replenished frequently (the hotel was very busy when we stayed last weekend). Rooms are compact and yes space is limited but for a few days in this bustling city, the Mercure Ginza is a very good choice :)
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: First of all, the location is great - it's very central and the hotel is surrounded by shops, restaurants and subway stations on various lines. The Kabukiza is within walking distance as well.The provided smartphone makes exploring a breeze - it really is becoming an essential part of any hotel's offerings. Early and late checkouts are handy and not terribly expensive (well, compared to how much you have to pay for a room that has enough space for two suitcases lol). The wifi is very fast.It would have been nice to be able to get room service or eat dinner in an on-site restaurant. This hotel does not offer either of those options. I can accept that, but they leave paperwork (the usual "hotel information") in the rooms that vaguely says the restaurant will remain open until May, but they don't specify that they mean May 2018!They still do breakfast but it's fairly ordinary. Go to the nearby 7/11 instead - you'll save a lot of money (and their food is surprisingly good).
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The best part about Mercure Ginza is its location. The hotel sits on top of the Ginza-Itchocme metro line (Just need to press B1 and you’re at the station). It is in a quiet spot that faces an office building, but just walk three minutes down the street and you are in the heart of the Ginza shopping district (Look for the LV store and turn in). And there are a 24-hour MacDonald’s and Lawson a minute away.However, be prepared that most of the rooms do not have much of a view (they face an office building so you can peek into the cubicles of office workers ) and there isn't a pool or onsen facilities. However, the hotel’s facilities are a winner. The lobby is designer chic and cozy. I stayed in a twin room that came with ample room - there was even a comfy armchair with leg rest and a fashionable overhanging lamp. The toilet’s bathtub is spacious by Tokyo’s standards and I like the overall design from the lift lobby. The bed rest also has a classy chic design, something that you don’t usually associate with budget business hotels My stay also came with breakfast that I looked forward to waking up to. Expect a mix of local and Japanese food, such as pasta, karaage, scrambled eggs and lotus root, with a wide variety of drinks. I hope to be back at the Mercure Ginza again.
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Good location. Average service at check in. Overall was good stay for the price you paid. Rooms are quite small but it’s normal for hotels in Tokyo. Comfortable bed though. Friendly service at the bar.
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Really enjoyed our 5 night stay here. Room spacious by Japanese standards also very quiet. Bed firm but comfortable. Great buffet breakfast. Location was really convenient, subway station outside and lots of restaurants nearby. Seven eleven also very close. Easy access to fish markets and walkable to JR station.
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Hotel and rooms very clean, staff courteous, professional and very helpful. Breakfast choices were numerous and food fresh and of good quality. Room amenities were excellent and the use of a smart phone very helpful.
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I’ve stayed at several Mercure hotels in Europe and always been pleased, so I was looking forward to a weekend in Ginza. The location is great and the hotel is in good condition but I expected a lot more. The room was tiny, there was no desk to work at and there was almost no storage space. The high price may have been due to the Tokyo marathon, but even allowing for that you don’t get a lot for your money.
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I have stayed here more than once. Good location in Ginza with friendly staff and helpful staff in the restaurant and very clean rooms. Reception is efficient and checks in and out quickly. I would stay here again.
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The hotel is easily accessed and is superbly situated. The rooms are extremely well presented and designed for ease of use for all age groups. The staff were extremely helpful and were friendly and humorous when dealing with our family group. Breakfasts were beautifully presented and offered a great range of European and Japanese food. I would certainly stay there in the future and recommend it to others.
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: First time staying in Ginza and wanted a hotel that was also close to where I had my business meetings. Great location close to shops as well as great places to eat. Rooms were a decent size and comfortable
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The hotel is in a prime location. However, the rooms are very small. Only 1 lift was working. There’s no gym. I am not sure with the price, is this worth it? I would rather go to another hotel. Breakfast buffet is very small too.
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Anyone who wants to go to Tokyo should have this very nice hotel in their minds. I was truly amazed. As of November 2018 the hotel undergone renovations and it is wonderful. Everything is new, shiny and clean. Common areas as reception and aisles are beautifully decorated, and very modern. Modernity does not mean poor taste or coldness. I really liked it. Rooms are impeccable, with new furniture and nice amenities. I was even given a cell-phone with 4G connectivity to use during my stay!!I want to thank all the staff for their kindness. The employees at the reception and the waiters at the bar were awesome. Breakfast is very good, I recommend paying for it. You’ll find all the western options and some local flavors as well.I stayed for 17 nights; a very long stay and was assigned room 1008. During a stay that long it would be easy to have any sort of issue, but in this case my stay has been so great!! People make a great contribution to a client experience, and in this case I have nothing to complain about.In terms of location, it is very good!! Just a couple of blocks from the Ginza Avenue, just a few blocks from the Wako building (use it as a reference) The metro line Yurakucho, at the Ginza-itchome station, in the exit 11 has a direct entrance to the Hotel, it is convenient and useful, especially in bad weather.I loved this city and I want to get back. Japan is a beautiful country, with great people and services. I loved this hotel, it has been very rewarding to stay there.Had I the chance of coming back to Tokyo, this hotel will be my only option.
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The location is very close with sub way station, near lawson and family mart.. in the heart of Ginza.. the room is small, clean enough and nice hospitality.. need deposit when check in.. the staff was good and nice.. just 1 elevator working while the other one was out of service.. Thank you..
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The location of the Ginza Mercure is so handy to shopping and transport hubs. This was the 3rd time we have stayed at this hotel and it keeps getting better. Staff are super helpful and the rooms are good.Very spacious bed and a comfortable stay. Highly recommended
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We love the location of Mercure Ginza, it’s very easy to get to subway stations. Standard rooms are small compared to deluxe room we stayed in previously, however not much time spent there. Breakfast buffet is OK and all staff are always friendly and helpful. Hotel renovated and would recommend and stay again.
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The hotel is located in Ginza area which is central location for those who love to do shopping in Ginza. There are many department stores, restaurants, and coffeehouses in the area. Travel to the hotel from Narita Airport is easy. I took the Keisei Skyliner from Narita Airport to Ueno Station, then transfer to Ginza subway line, and alight at Ginza Station. The exit A13 is closed during my visit, so I use the another nearby exit instead to the Matsuya Ginza Department Store, and I walk from the Matsuya to the hotel in few minutes. There are a Lawson, 7-11, and Family Mart convenience store nearby. McDonald's is just downstairs. The hotel reception is located on the second floor. The lobby is very small. The staff was helpful during my stay. They also have a Ginza map to help you with travelling around the area.The check-in was fast, however the staff still asked me to get my credit card swiped as a security deposit which I did not find such process in other Mercure hotels. The room size was decent for Japanese standard. It was clean with basic room facilities. Wi-Fi Internet was okay with fair speed.They serve breakfast in a restaurant on second floor, opposite the lobby. The breakfast was okay, but boring with limited choices.The hotel also provided the complimentary handy 4G smartphone in the room. You can bring and use it outside hotel. The Internet is unlimited with some city guides and free call.They were renovating the hotel during my visit, and one of the elevators are closed. There was only one elevator to serve the entire hotel which was annoying, because the wait time was usually long than usual.Mercure Tokyo Ginza is a centrally located hotel in Ginza area. The room was small, but clean. Breakfast was average. The staff service was okay. When it comes to the price, I think I can find better value-for-money alternatives in the area.
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: staff language issues in speaking English. well not so much speaking but knowing how to explain things. IE the dining area turns in to a bar at night but they do serve breakfast in the AM. the PM staff said no restaurant Bar only....There were other issues too. I will not stay here again even if there is direct access to the trains underneath the hotel. hmm is that safe...must be in this earthquake proof nation.
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The hotel is perfectly located. There is a metro subway under the hotel Basement one, it connects to Ginza station and Tokyo station and many more. The hotel has descent size rooms each room has a GPS handy device which includes free international phone calls. It also allows to use all features. Including maps, internet and restaurants, events etc. the toilets are Japanese so for the flush button it’s located at the back on the right hand side (hard to find) The bar in the hotel has a variety of drinks and great place to relax before dinner. The restaurant in the hotel is only open at this stage for breakfast. The food is great. Also near the hotel there is kit Kat chocolate place if you have a sweet tooth. Great to visit. There is plenty of restaurants and cafes close to the hotel.
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: If you don't mind the absence of a grand foyer (the check-in counter is one floor above via 2 elevators), everything else exceeded our expectations, including large rooms recently refurbished, a smartphone with free usage and its central location to Ginza and beyond, thanks to a basement passageway to the Tokyo metro. The main Tokyo station is a 7min ride away by taxi, where one can connect to Narita Airport either by train, or nonstop bus express (US 10).A little pricey, but really average for Tokyo. Will gladly return. A little pricey, but really average for Tokyo
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: A wonderful location and room a good size staff exceptional so helpfulRoom was spotless and loved the free smart phone with a walking GPSThe Ginz, restaurants, and railway all within easy walking distance If you don’t care for Japanese food there is a McDonalds about 100metres up the road and also a seven 11 not far. A wonderful stay
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We found this hotel to be excellently located for our first visit to Tokyo. The staff was friendly and helpful. For its grading our room was comfortable and for Japan roomy. We were able to get over our jet-lag in a quiet well appointed room and take advantage of the numerous attractions within walking distance of the hotel. We would definitely stay here on any subsequent visit.
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Not too bad, but not too great either. The location is decent, with easy walking distance to most things in Ginza, shopping, eating, etc, but the hotel is average at best. Staff were nice and helpful (they even offered us a drink after the restaurant had closed, as there was no bar), but that's the best aspect. The carpark was too small for our car, so we had to park somewhere offsite (a 10-`15 min walk away), and the hotel was undergoing renovations, which was a pain. Lifts were very slow and dirty, and the rooms seemed from an age gone by, so I'm not sure what was being renovated. Certainly not my floor! The room was tiny, and was oddly laid out, but in a bad way. There were odd nooks and areas that weren't much use, and not a lot of space to put my things, and certainly barely any space to work. The window was also tiny! Furnishings were okay ,and at least the room was clean. I'm not sure I'd stay again...
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Stayed here for three nightsFantastic location in Ginza extremely close to the subway. Loads of restaurants and bars nearby and short walk to the shopping heart of Ginza. Taxis easy to get on the neighbouring streets and connivence stores, fast food, coffee shops and speciality stores nearby too. Rooms were very modern but very small. Tokyo hotel rooms are obviously small as space as a premium but we had a cot in our room too which was a struggle! Bathroom was a bit dated but find. Make sure you pack light and for those of you who like to spread out- might not be for you as very tight. We were able to check in early which was fabulous. Wifi was good and free wifi device in room is available to be used which was also very handy. We were travelling with a baby and they were very happy to provide a cot for us which was great
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I stayed at Mercure Tokyo Ginza for 3 nights with my family and we had a great time. The hotel has a convenient location to different subway lines, and a passage to the Ginza-Itchome station on the Yurakucho lines is accessible directly from the hotel basement, however you have to walk perhaps 400 meters. You can also easily reach the Higashi-Ginza station on the Hibiya line and Ginza station where you will find the Ginza, Hibiya and Marunouchi lines, by foot. The breakfast is OK, but a bit strange, like they can't decide if it should be a japanese or western style but the coffee was great. Our room was spacious and very fresh and modern, and we were offered an early check in without any additional charge, which was great because we could get a few ours of sleep before we started to explore Tokyo.
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: My third visit to this hotel. Nearly all I wrote in my previous review still stands except the minibar is no longer stocked and the entrance area and reception have been overhauled. The major plus on this visit was the outstandingly helpful Yumi on reception who went to great lengths to ensure we found tickets for the recent Australia/New Zealand rugby match. Certainly way and beyond service and thank you again.The one disappointment was the poor directions given to get to Haneda Airport via subway. Yes it is on the Toei Asakusa (red) line from Higashi Ginza station (not Asakusa station as one member of reception insisted (I knew she was wrong because we visited the shrine and station of the same name). The two important pieces of information that were omitted were that the two Higashi Ginza platforms can only be reached above ground. We had to climb back up a long flight of stairs with our suitcases and cross the busy main road to access the correct platform. The second important piece of information is to look for the train with Haneda on the headboard as not all trains go to that airport.
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Stayed here two nights after a cruise. The location is terrific, just two blocks off the main shopping street of the Ginza. They were just finishing renovations so the lobby was closed off. However, all rooms were finished and noise was not an issue at all. Check in was easy and they held our bags for us until check in time. The staff was quite friendly and helpful. The room was exactly as you would expect in Japan--small, expensive (about $300 per night) but certainly more than adequate. We choose to have our suitcases on the floor since there was really no other place for them. There is a room safe, refrigerator, TV, nice sized bath including a super duper toilet with all the Japanese gadgets. But nicest of all, the room had a free smart phone that you could take with you while you toured the city. It also offered completely free calls to various countries including the US. It was a terrific touch especially since our older version phones did not work on the Japanese cell phone frequencies. We made sure to opt for the room package that included breakfast. Breakfast is on the second floor, is buffet style, and includes both Eastern and Western style breakfast items. The coffee was quite tasty out of their large custom coffee machine. We extended our check out by two hours--one they gave us free and one we paid an extra 1000 Yen (about $10). Your bill will also show an additional 400 Yen local tax which most likely was not already figured into your room rate.In terms of airport transportation, here's the deal. To Narita, where most international flights are, would be about $250 by taxi so not a good choice. There is bus service but the stop is not within easy walking distance with luggage. So, have the hotel call a taxi for you (tell them how much luggage you have so they call the right size) and take it to the Tokyo Station Yaesu South Entrance which will cost about 1000 Yen ($10). They can't enter the bus area but can drop you off about 50 yards south. Find bus platform #7 for The Access Narita bus which runs frequently and costs a mere 1000 Yen. They will take your bags and mark which airline you're flying so they unload them at the right stop. We used this on a holiday Monday so our driving time to Narita was a fast 55 minutes. Terminal 2 is where most of the flights are and it has 2 entrance doors so ask which stop is for your airline. American Airlines, for example, uses the first stop which is door 2. Overall between the hotel and the bus, we would definitely do this again.
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: This hotel is situated near the heart of Ginza near a subway station. So location is very good. Staff are friendly and efficient. The room we stayed in was quite spacious by Tokyo standard. However, there is no security to speak of. Anyone can come up the lift to your room. The restaurant on site only serves breakfast. Fortunately, there are plenty of eateries nearby. It is apparently still under renovation. Should be a nicer hotel when renovation is completed.
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I stayed here for my business trip from Monday to Friday. I’m a platinum member and consider that this is the by far the worst AccorHotels.1) Check In was way too long. I booked my 5 days trip on the app. The receptionist had to use my credit card three times. Firstly they charged me only for four days. Then they had to use my Visa card again as they forgot to charge me for breakfast. Then they checked and realised I booked five days. The whole process took me 40 minutes.2) forgot to give me vouchers - I went to the Resturant for my breakfast before my big meeting. I went to the Resturant and was asked to present voucher. Needless to say, they never gave me any. I had to do all that after work to get my breakfast vouchers.3) most hotel stamped the validity date of their breakfast vouchers for your entire stay. No, not this hotel. You have to check the day of your voucher. Each voucher is valid on a specific date. On my second day, I used my fifth day voucher. The second Day voucher expired on my last day! This is just stupid... I ended up buying breakfast elsewhere as I’m sick and tired of dealing with this hotel again!
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Perfect location, excellent amenities, and very helpful staff. We had a weekend in Tokyo and wanted to use Ginza as a base to get around the city. The hotel has an access to the subway under the building that you can access from the hotel elevator: now that's service. Check-in was a breeze, and in a very un-Japanese manner, they let us check in before 3pm. You can't go wrong with this place.
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The hotel is in a great location close to the Tokyo Station and several metro stations. The room was comfortable, clean and tidy. The hotel is currently undergoing renovations. With only one elevator working and the hotel restaurant closed for dinner. We were disappointed that we weren’t advised of the renovations prior to check-in.
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Good hotel with nice friendly helpful staffThis was our second visit Last stayed in 2013 and we were happy to return A little surprised our room was tired this time round but renovation was happening on higher floors in the hotel On the last day of our trip we opened our room door in the morning to find the carpet and hallways covered in plastic and workmen everywhere We were the only guests on the floor, every other room was stripped We had a late checkout in the afternoon and the work made our last day uncomfortable This could have been avoided completely if we’d been warned or advised. Really disappointed in the final experience on our last day of our trip It was very hot and we were tired but not able to relax due to the work outside the room
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The hotel is perfectly located, close to the train station and many metro lines. It is a great spot to start visiting Tokyo. The rooms are not very big, but comfortable and rather quiet. The only thing was that we booked for two adults and a child of 5, and we got a room with two beds. We would have to pay on top for a roll away bed. The breakfast was ok, nothing special, rather continental than Japanese.
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: This is a basic tourist hotel if one wish to stay in Ginza area whereby everything is within walking distance.The drawback is that it is under renovation and one can go straight up to your hotel floor without any hotel card. Any stranger can go up and down as they wish for the moment.Service wise, it is within expectation.
hotelName:
18    Mercure Tokyo Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Pros - The really nice thing about First Cabin is the rooms are very clean and nicely laid out. I upgraded to the cabin style rooms rather than the capsules. The lobby downstairs is also very nice with a fully stocked bar and snacks. The staff are very friendly and helpful and truly cater to travellers. The washrooms are also very decent and clean. This place feels very peaceful and the noise is kept to a minimum (during the day…)Cons - The beds are not very comfortable, likely some of the hardest matts I’ve ever slept on. Despite daytime noise levels the evening can be quite bothersome with an inconsiderate neighbour (which I had). The shower and vanity area is only cleaned once per day so I found supplies and clean showers a bit worse than expected in the mornings vs the evenings.Summary - First cabin is a great place to stay if you’re familiar with the capsule hotel experience. lf not, understand that you’re at the mercy of the schedule of others that are staying there. Think of it like sleeping on an airplane and have your ear plugs, eye masks and other sleep aids handy.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: First time trying this hotel and have mixed feeling,.Positive: - better than expected capsule hotel experience- excellent location makes transportation time to be minimizedNegative:- quite expensive- toothbrush is not provided, but pajama provided. If they provided pajama and pants, why dont provide toothbrush and toothpaste? It provide more inconvenience than convenience as we all have our own clothes!- no sauna room consider such size of hotel. Even a 3000yen per night cheap hotel in Asakusa provide basic sauna facility.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Affordable stay for the location, which is minutes away from Tsukiji Market. Easily reachable from either Narita or Haneda Airport by the Asakusa train line via Higashi-Ginza station. Also less than two minutes’ walk from Tsukiji station of the Hibiya metro line.Clean bathrooms with toiletry and laundry machines, individual private showers and communal Japanese-style baths, separated by gender. Unfortunately, their mattresses are very firm and can feel uncomfortable to some people. Noise may be an issue in the morning or at night due to other guests.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Had one night stay in Feb this year and was totally satisfied with the room and the facilities. It is not a typical capsule but a room without ensuite bathroom. The whole place is well maintained and clean. It was quite occupied for a friday night and I could hear some snoring in between the whole night but it is not a big issue for me.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Its a beautiful capsule hotel.much bigger then the usual cabin capsule.Area is very neat and clean.Place is quiet too.Common toilet is clean too. Got a first class capsule with more personal space.Room is well maintain , clean with no smell.This capsule hotel is a 15 mins walking distance to the Tsukiji market.Great experience as the hotel is close to the fish market and you do not have to wake up early.Its near to the Ginza area too.Metro is just outside the capsule hotel and many convenient shop such as 7-11 and family mart nearby for foods and drinks.The hotel has some vending machine and serve food at certain timing too.Great value for money and its safe for solo travelers.There are many branch in other district too.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Well, where to start. Facilities are great definitely 10/10 for showers, toilets, cleanliness, all toiletries provided 'which if not packed is a bonus, down to razors. Linen changed daily great.Location , easy no problems. Late check in in, no so great. So, the down side..bing bloody bong of lift every 5-20 mins..foot traffic every 3-10mins..phones buzzing..crikey..if your a light sleeper (like me, i had 30mins max out of 8hrs..so 1.5/10..if it wasn't for the amenities I'd be gone like donkey kong.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: In my past trips I've always booked the business class cabins, however this time I thought I'd try something different.Something different wasn't so pleasant, one being the neighbours in first class are so much more noisier than the ones in business class. They would slam they're doors shut, they would move about loudly which is not very considerate. And especially the snoring of one neighbour, it could be heard throughout the whole floor, which was ridiculous. If you're a snorer please do not book yourself in a capsule hotel, it's mean and frankly irritating. Overall the room size in first class was great, plenty of rooms for movement, but if you're looking for something that's more quieter and serene, business class is for you and plus it's cheaper.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Stayed here for one night as I wanted to experience a capsule hotel while in Tokyo. Was pleasantly surprised by the whole stay. While I had to leave my suitcase unattended in a baggage area, the female only floor I was staying my on felt safe. The capsule itself was roomy and comfortable. I even had a small humidifier (very popular in japan to put moisture back into the air) which I borrowed from the front desk. I also had a dip in the Japanese communal bath.. preordered the breakfast the night before- which is served at the bar downstairs. A simple offering but good value for money and a good feed to start the day. A short walk to the wonderful fish markets.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The staff were friendly, helpful and spoke good English. The hotel is clean and very well-maintained. Japanese style-bath on 6F is rather small but it was never crowded. The cabin is certainly better than a capsule. There's a small compartment to lock your items. Bed was rather hard. The pyjamas given meant that I could travel even lighter. At the ground-floor lounge, there's a microwave oven and hot water. No refrigerator is available. As with most areas in Tokyo, there is no shortage of food options or convenience stores. Transport options were good, there was a direct bus to Tokyo Big Sight a short walk away. From Narita or Haneda, catch the Keisei service that uses the Toei Asakusa line. Only two coin-operated washing machines, which meant that I had to queue. You chain your suitcase to a rail along the corridor for the cabins, which means that you would be disturbing people if you need to access your suitcase late at night.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I wanted to tick off the capsule hotel from the list. I think First Cabin capsules are a bit too big and not representative of the typical capsule. It probably explains why the price is a bit steep too. It would have been nice if they provided lockers.Otherwise everything was pretty tidy. The location was good for a visit to Tsukiji tuna auctions. Their intel was not so great. Get there at 2am they said. I could have gotten there at 5am instead (and had some mores sleep) Could probably have found something cheaper nearby too - but I was a bit lazy.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I really appreciate the private and clean space at first cabin. The cabins were bigger then expected and pretty comfortable, even tho the bed was kinda stiff. There's a complimentary lock box, and storage underneath the bed but it's not gonna be big enough to fit a travel backpack or suitcase. The shower/bathing area is communal so be ready to expect that, there's only one private shower. The hot bath was nice! It was affordable and I really enjoyed my stay, it was great to experience the Japan capsule hotel experience.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We stayed here on our last night in Japan and it is a very clean modern capsule hotel. The sleeping space was not as small as I expected, and I could still stand on my bed and not hit my head on the ceiling. There are some quirks about storing your stuff due to the limited space, but it wasn't anything that bothered me too greatly.One thing to watch out for foreigners: For the women bath area, there is only one private shower. With about 2-3 floors dedicated for women, that could mean a long wait for the private shower room. The only other option is the Japanese communal bath, which can be quite a culture shock for some since it is bathing with the other female hotel guests. I saw another guest being surprised about it and she ended up waiting for quite a while to use the private shower since she was uncomfortable about the concept.Each "cabin" can only be closed by a curtain, so it does not block sounds from people walking through the hallway. If you're a light sleeper, this setup will not work for you. If you do end up staying here, try to request for a space as far away from the floor entrance as possible.Overall, if you're looking for an affordable stay or just want to try out the novelty of a capsule hotel, this is a good place to go. It's also in a great area with easy access to the Tsukiji fish market and subways.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The cabin is clean and very closed to the fish market. As well as you also can walk to shopping in Ginza and Yurakucho area. It is very convenient for public transportation by subway. There are some restaurant and convenient store such family mart around the hotel. There are also Starbucks and Tully's coffee very closed to the hotel.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: My friends and I stayed here for 4 days. We had a great experience. It is very clean and organize. You will be provided with basics and toiletries (Shiseido brand), you will even get a pijama. Your capsule have internet and a TV. Bare in mind that the capsules are off courses very tiny. There are bathrooms in every floor but showers only in two floors. The staff was OK, not the usual excellent service you get in Japan. Bring earplugs... noise at night from other capsules might ruin your capsule experience.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The staff were nice and helpful and the onsen had more privacy than most in Japan apart from that I wouldn't stay here again. The washing machine was poor I had to put my clothes to dry on a one hour cycle 4 times and still weren't dry. My neighbor got in at 2am and started unpacking her suitcase. The bed felt very hard and had about 2 hours sleep. When I did complain no one understood it's fair enough there's a language barrier but no one tried to resolve my issues. Im glad I didn't pay anymore than I did.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We stayed here for one night to experience the much talked about Japanese cube hotels, and we were impressed. I was skeptical at first since there was no door, which i was no aware of before. But the place was clean, safe, quiet and came with so many unexpected amenities. The bathrooms, spa was excellent and amenities were excellent. I recommend this place at least for one night.Also, very close to the metro station.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The room and bathrooms are super clean. It has everything u need from pjs, towels to make up remover and curling iron. I would highly recommend this place to anyone traveling solo or with friends. Short walk to the fish market (5-8 mins).
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The hotel is very modern and clean. The cabin or capsule is very spacious and comfortable. The bed is just of a good standard single size comfortable enough and indeed i was able to have a good night sleep. The toilet/bathroom was provided with all the toiletries you need and very clean. Hotel location is just in front of a subway or metro station so it is really a good based to go around Tokyo. There is a nearby airport bus stop maybe just 5-10 mins walk and Dennys restaurant and 7/11 store nearby.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: My experience at First Cabin Tsukiji was a good one. I would not recommend it if it is your first time in Tokyo. I would instead recommend the Capsule Hotel in Shinjuku, or anywhere budget friendly in Shinjuku. Shinjuku is a better area to stay for your first Tokyo experience then the Tsukiji area. The Tsukiji area is very quiet, particularly at night, and the area does not cater well to tourists. This is a better hotel for Tokyo business travelers. Some things I liked about First Cabin Tsukiji is the bed and layout of the room. Everything you need, including space for luggage, space for charging, place to hang clothes, and of course traditional Japanese robes and slippers provided. The bathroom was clean and conveniently located near the elevator and all the rooms. It is a quiet, peaceful hotel and fit my needs as I wanted to stay near Tsukiji market for a good price. Some things I didn't like was the temperature of the rooms and halls. It was uncomfortably warm, and there was no way to adjust the temperature in the rooms. Also, the men's shower area was not particularly clean. Especially the sinks and showers. The service at the front desk was not particularly friendly. And the large bar in the front lobby was always empty, with no one behind it to serve drinks. I sat at the bar for a long time, multiple times, waiting for someone to serve drinks, but no one ever came, so I left. The location is not ideal for exploring Tokyo. The nearest subway is Tskiji station on the Tokyo Metro Hibaya line which you have to switch trains to get to many places in Tokyo. Better to walk 10 minutes to Tsukishijo station, which connects to many subway lines in Tokyo. Overall, my stay at First Cabin was fine, and suited my needs, but I wouldn't stay here again. Needs a better location and better service in my opinion. If you are a super budget traveler, and just need a cheap bed in Tokyo, First Cabin Tsukiji will work out fine for you.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: It's the Biggest room at the price you can get around Tokyo metro.(I paid around$25/night.) very close to Tokyo subway station and tsukiji market(best place for breakfast or lunch)Will come back next time if I travel alone
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: If you want to be near the Tsukiji market, First Cabin is definitely recommended!The hotel is inexpensive, and is convenient for you to walk to Tsukiji market and only a 10 minutes walk for shopping at Ginza.Overall the hotel is lovely, be sure to book in advance as rooms are unavailable quite fast. The only downside to this hotel are the bedsheets, they're a little rough and dry.*First Cabin, if you're reading this please add more softener to your bedsheets. Thanks in advance.*
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Pros: I like how big your room is compared to the regular capsule hotel. All the toiletries are present like soap, shampoo, toothbrush and towels and the location is great like a 5 mins from a train station and they even have a convenience store next door.Cons: Bathroom is on a different floor and the divider is thin and it can create a lot of noise when opening/closing
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I always wanted to experience a capsule hotel and so glad I did in this hotel. The price cannot be beat! $25 per night beats any hostel and Airbnb. The hotel grounds were clean, modern design and most importantly very safe for anyone traveling solo. The staff were extremely nice and always willing to help. There is no negatives I can think of, it was very easy to get to: one block away from the metro station and within walking distance of the Tsukiji Fish market. Although I would not recommend for over 2 night stay, it really depends on your budget. I wish we could get the option of a high quality capsule hotels this cheap in Europe or elsewhere in America.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Tokyo was the first stop on my trip to Japan and what better way to kick off my first visit to Japan than a stay in a capsule hotel? After reading positive reviews and factoring in price and location, I settled for the First Cabin Tsukiji for my three nights in Tokyo. I booked a "Business Class Cabin" at $45.53 CAD per night. My flight landed midday and with a 17:00 check-in time, I leisurely made my way to the hotel to see if an early check-in would be possible. Unfortunately, an early check-in was not possible but the receptionist offered to put my belongings aside while I explored the city for a bit.The cabin was spacious by my standards, and in comparison to the more traditional sized pods. I managed to sleep comfortably, though the sliding up and down of the neighbouring "doors" or blinds can be a bit noisy for the light sleepers. I was given two keys for my belongings; one for a little cupboard in the actual cabin which I was able to fit my backpack into, and one for a padlock/cord for larger items such as my luggage which is to be stored in the hallway of the sleeping quarters. Be sure to bring a lock for your bags if you are not comfortable having your belongings out in the open. Though I did have a lock for my luggage, I did feel safe as a key card is necessary to enter your respective floor.As for the bathrooms, I did not have any issues considering it was all communal. I never had to wait for a sink, toilet, or shower, nor was there ever more than one other person besides me when I had to use the facilities. There is a bar/lounge on the main floor. I am not sure if the main clientele were guest of the hotels or not, but it seemed pretty busy every night when I returned to the hotel. You did have to drop off or pick up your keys every time you left or came back, but this seems to be the norm for capsule hotels. Unlike some places I have read about, you did not have to "check out" or make sure you did not leave anything in your room everyday, which was a major plus for me.As mentioned above, I booked this hotel due to its location and proximity to the Tsukiji Fish Market and Tsukiji subway station. It was nice being able to wake up early and walk to the fish market, and then heading back to the hotel for a nap. I would definitely stay here again on a future visit if I were on a budget and I would recommend this hotel for first-time visitors looking for the experience of staying in a capsule. Excellent value for the price I paid and its location to the nearby fish market!
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: 'Hotel' is located nerby metro station and famous fish market and kabuka theatre. Cabins (I used buissines one) are clean, you have a locer for some stuff to hide. Bed is quite comfortable. The problem is that you don't have a place for bigger luggage so you have to leave ot outside the cabin (you can attach it to the wall but it works only if you have a locked suitcase.There are 3 showers + 5 open in the barh for 3 floors of cabins. It may be hard to get there sometimes.Noises around early morning which make it hard to sleep.To summarize it is a good place to stay but only for one/two days.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I like the hotel with below points:1) very near to metro station (around 2 mins walk to hotel) which has lift so it is good if you have large luggage2) free wifi3) free skin care products (toner, lotion, cleaning oil, cleaning water), hair dryer in lady floor 4) have all supplies you need in cabin (i.e. TV, towels, lockers, pajamas)5) 10 mins walk to fish market information centre - it is only reason for staying in this place as you need to be there at 2am to ensure you get the ticket. (I was the last one in first visitor list which I arrived at 2:15am) 6) has lady floor which is good for safe concern.7) can leave luggage after check out or before check in8) can catch a bit sleep after fish auction before check out timeThe things I don't like as below:1) the curtain is so noisy whenever you move it for in or out - which bothers others and myself2) air circulation is not good once curtain is down3) can't sleep well as there are always sounds around (people in and out, curtain sounds, stuff movement sounds etc)4) receptionists are not helpful in information queries5) check out time is 10am which is earlier than most hotel.6) shower for lady is not in same floor as cabin area (5/F) so it is not convenient if you want to take showers.7) reception didn't wake me up on time as I requested so have to set alarm clock for ensuring you are up on time as you need.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: This is my second stay in this hotel. I like it for its tidiness , close proximity to metro. Onsen included, a washer and drier $4. A bar downstairs. Spacious capsules, a safety bar to lock your luggage. Recommend.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: When in Rome...so we HAD to do a capsule hotel experience when in Tokyo. Really impressed with the facilities. No woman needs to be at all concerned about security. seperate floor with its own access pad. capsules were uber clean, well designed and proportioned. Great location with a subway station 1 minutes walk away
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: First cabin tsukiji was in a great location, literally 1 minute away from tsukiji metro station, about 15-20 minutes walk from Ginza; a large shopping district, 5 minutes from the world famous tsukiji fish market, and 5-10 minute walk from a number of other metro stations that joined with other lines so you were in easy reach of Haneda airport, shinjuku, shibuya and pretty much anywhere within Tokyo.Everything about this place screams efficiency. You can't make noise are use your phones in the sleeping area so you do actually get a great nights sleep despite being in a capsule hotel. There is a key card access to get into the lift, each floor, and cabin sleeping area so you do feel like your things and yourself are incredibly safe.The bathrooms were extremely clean, and there was a shower room and public bath for stayers to use. They had everything you could possibly need including face wash, toner, moisturiser, shampoo, conditioner, body wash, hair brushes, hair dryers and straighteners! You literally don't need to bring anything. The capsule was actually incredibly spacious and I thought they were very comfortable to sleep in. The only thing I could fault was that sleeping in a capsule did get incredibly hot! However, the great location, cleanliness and efficiency of this place makes it 100% worth it's stay, plus it's extremely good value. I'd highly recommend here
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Excellent location for getting to the Tsukiji Fish Market, especially since I wanted to go to the tuna auction. There are high end Shiseido amenities for women. The facilities are clean. Slept well for the one night stay.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The hotel is located 500m away from the Tsukiji station, also walking distance to the Tsukiji market. The room is very clean I think it's worth for what I paid.Make sure you book the first cabin, the business class is very small.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I've stayed in a First Cabin Capsule Hotel in Akihabara, and returning to Japan, I needed another place to stay in order to make it to a music festival happening in Makuhari at the time.After the stay, I can confirm that the First Cabin Capsule Hotels are among some of the best capsule hotels Japan has to offer.A quick trip to Tsukiji via the Metro Subway line, you get out of the station, go up to the street, look around, and you should see a building with the words "FIRST CABIN" sticking out from the front of the building, letters going top to bottom.Check in is after 5pm, and requires a room key in order to access the elevators, stairwells, and door to the sleeping pod area.The pods themselves are roomier than you think, even the smallest ones on offer.You get to your designated pod, pull up the shutter, and get acquainted with compact travelling, wishing that this kind of thing existed aboard the airplane you probably arrived in.Each pod has a TV (plug in your headphones to hear the sound), light, and lock box to store your valuables.First Cabin provide shared bathroom facilities (also, male and female floors are seperate), and also provide bathroom products like shampoo, conditioner, body wash, even shaving foam and razors.From my experience, I would recommend Tsukiji First Cabin if you have plans to spend the entire day at a music festival or even at Tokyo Disneyland, and you're looking to save the expense of a hotel by staying at Tsukiji instead of somewhere far more pricey.Great value, even better location right outside Tsukiji Metro subway station. :)
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Stayed for 1 night. Location is nice, just next to Tsukiji station. 1st floor is a bar and front office. Saw couples of salaryman at bar enjoying the night. First impression, hotel is very modern and nicely design. Greeted by front office lady, who speaks English. she asked me if it is my first time there and i said yes. She then showed me booklet of manual in English, explain about regulations, facilities and check-out time. Given access key and safety deposit key then go to check the room. Room was same as in the pictures and my order (superior capsule room). It was spacious considering it is a capsule hotel. Amenities : sandals, big towel, small towel, pijama, toothbrush. As for facilities they have public bath, shower, grooming section, self washing machine, vending machines, bar. Check-in time is 17:00 and check-out time is 10:00+ : Location, very clean, public bath, like the shower gel and shampoo- : bed is hard, noisy (some inconsiderate guest was there)
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: From the outside First Cabin Tsukiji looks like first class, but looks can be deceiving. My experience at First Cabin Tsukiji was mixed, but I left the hotel with a sour taste in my mouth.I arrived just after sunset on a Tuesday and was surprised to see just how close to Tsukiji station it is located. During check-in I was shown a booklet in English explaining certain rules, etiquette, etc. Explaining the rules is fine, however the manner in which they were "explained" was not particularly friendly. A Japanese lady spent about 5 minutes flipping through the booklet pointing at certain sections, all without muttering a single word, and despite my best efforts at convincing her that I'm able to speak Japanese she was either incapable of working this out or didn't care until right at the very end. Once she had clicked that verbal communication was indeed possible the process suddenly became much easier and slightly more friendly.She then disappeared and a gentleman with average English skill (for Japanese) arrived and, again despite my best effort encouraging him to speak Japanese, began to explain the checkout process in broken English. He informed me that checkout was before 11am and asked when I would like to do so. 11am sounded fine to me.Now, the rooms themselves are great in many ways - very large for a capsule, big bed, lockbox, air conditioning fan control, clean (well, the place is new, so...). The not so good points about the rooms are that they have a very uncomfortable latex bed, lockbox is only for narrow items (it's quite deep and long, but if it's wider than maybe 10cm it won't fit), air conditioning fan control only has 3 settings (very low, low, slightly less low), temperature control isn't available. I'll repeat that last one. Temperature control is NOT available. As it is winter the hotel is heated to 24~26 degrees Celsius, and once you close your curtain the main air flow stops. Couple this with the insubstantial in-room fan and latex mattress at you're in for a very sweaty, sleepless night. I asked if anything could be done and was informed that the floors are set to a temperature and that it can't be changed. Luckily I was only there for two nights, because I would have changed hotels otherwise.I didn't use the bath facilities, however I did have a look and they appeared to be your standard public bath.Finally, it was time to leave. As you might imagine, after two nights of virtually no sleep, getting up in the morning wasn't exactly the easiest thing to do. I had planned to leave by 9am, but seeing as the cleaning staff open the windows during the day to room started to cool down a bit and I was able to sleep for a short while. I jumped up at about half past 10, showered, packed my things, and was downstairs at 10:55am. I was tired, hungry, and grumpy, so hearing "checkout is at 10am, so we're going to charge you 900 yen for one hours stay" was not high on my wish list. You may remember from what I wrote earlier that at check-in I was informed that I could check-out before 11am. I informed the lady (probably the friendliest of them all, despite the bad news) that this is not what I was told at check in, and that I wasn't going to pay. She fetched the manager who, with probably the worst English of any of the staff save for the mute check-in girl, told me I must pay because I stayed for one more hour. After attempting to reason with him he must have given up, and in an extremely rude manner said "OKAY no charge. You don't pay. Goodbye.", turned away and shuffled through some papers. Needless to say I was a tad bit shocked.I've rated this hotel as 2 stars (I would go 1.5, but it's not available) because of its location and the fact that it's new. If you choose to stay here I hope you have a better experience than I did.I really want to like this hotel as it offers all I need in a hotel, but given the experience I had I will not be staying again.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: If Tokyo's all booked up for the weekend, this really is a good option. Tsukiji is centrally located, and the facilities are generally clean and well-maintained. As you probably can gather, it's a notch up from the common double-decker drunk salary man capsule hotel. You can stand up in your capsule. The ventilation and air conditioning are quite adequate. And the bed, although hard by western standards, really is a bed.However, many of the problems particular to capsule hotels still exist. Although First Cabin has many rules to cut down on the noise - such as a prohibition on cell phone conversation in the sleeping areas - you are often woken up at odd hours by your neighbors pulling up and down their canvas door, zipping and unzipping their luggage, and rustling plastic sacks. In other words, noise isolation is next to nothing. You could wear earplugs, and First Cabin does provide them gratis, but I have to wonder why they just don't use normal doors on these room/capsules. If ventilation is the issue, a swinging door with vents would at least sidestep the noise issues of the current roll-up canvas partition. I would wager that it would provide just a bit more sound isolation as well. Other cons were: the shower rooms were clustered on two floors. This coupled with a single, small elevation ensures morning elevator congestion. There should be showers on every floor.  The shower rooms are not as regularly attended to by cleaning as I think would be optimal. Given that the hotel's business model benefits from an economy of scale by only having to clean 8 showers for about 75 capsules, one would think that some of the realized savings would go back into more frequent cleaning of the shower stalls. And finally, a 5pm check in time is ridiculous. If First Cabin is to charge rates that honestly, aren't that much of a discount from a (perhaps older but still clean) business hotel, it should loosen up a bit. Hotel check in time should be 15:00. Max. Period.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: It was a great place to experience sleeping in a pod/capsule without being too claustrophobic. Wouldn't say the location was great, but it is close to the Tsukiji Fish Market, which is almost always a feature of all Tokyo tours. Our main criticisms were that the mattresses are incredibly hard and there was only one female shower, which is just ridiculous given that there is a whole female floor. It was also pretty expensive for what it is.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: This is a very new location for First Cabin, and thus the facilities are top notch. Being a block away from the Tsukiji fish market makes it an ideal spot to stay for an early morning visit to the market.The bar/cafe lobby is great for meeting up with others, and there is space to do some work if needed. There are common bathroom facilities and a traditional japanese soaking pool, along with showers too. In the actual cabin, everything is designed well and conveniently laid out, including a secure storage drawer.My experience was only marred by some miscommunication during the booking. i booked online for a male room and was sent a confirmation of the booking request. However, two days before arrival, they sent me a reconfirmation saying i had booked a room for the female floor. I said that was an error and to have that fixed, but did not get a reply. Upon arrival, I was told that there were no more male rooms at the lower price level and that i'd have to upgrade to the higher price level. Took some explaining that I shouldn't have to pay more for their mistake. Upon conferring with his manager (who seemed to be brushing it off, but i could be wrong), he said he could give me a larger room for no extra charge, but the TV in it wouldn't work.I was fine with that and had a good stay. And I'd stay here again on a future trip. Just not sure if the booking process online is reliable enough to prevent future issues so I'll have to be vigilant about it.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: a capsule is a must try of course when visiting Japan, the good thing is they have female and male floors here so for both tourists good to try. their bar is quite popular. staff could improve their english
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I could not get on my flight (standby/buddy pass) so had to cancel my booking. I am being charged extra for not showing up.... Although I emailed the minute I knew I could not make the flight (after waiting 8 hours in airport...) policy is 72 hrs for refund. This is stupid. The hotel makes a profit on clients problem! I pay a penalty for a problem outside my control. Needs to be changed!
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Comfortable, clean, spacious enough and with fast free Wi-Fi, a nice TV and Spa! I loved the location and that they were willing to help waking me up at 3:30 a.m. since I was going to the Tsukiji Market. The security to separate women and men floors is perfect, and the staff is really nice. Please go and have a luxurious and comfortable night at this capsule hotel.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: First Cabin is professional. Extremely proper with great facilities including an onsen! I got a good deal otherwise, it is slightly pricey. However, it is very comfortable and unlike other capsule hotels, it does not feel weird. There is complete privacy.The location is perfect, right next to Tsukiji Fish Market.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The hotel was very quiet and comfortable. All of the facilities were wonderful. The staff were very helpful and recommended an incredible all night sushi restaurant when I arrived at around midnight. Exactly what I wanted when visiting Japan.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I called the hotel about a week before my arrival to book a room. Most of their staff could not manage phone enquiries in English but they put me through to another colleague who spoke excellent English. My reservation was made efficiently - a confirmation nbr given immediately and no credit card information needed. I took the Access Narita airport bus from Narita airport to Ginza station (1000yen). From there, I took a taxi to the hotel which costs about 900yen. Hotel check-in is strictly at 5pm so if you arrive early, just store your luggage with them and come back later. I booked the first class cabin which offered more space than the standard ones. The bathroom was spotlessly clean and the vanity area comes equipped with everything you need, including a hair straightener. Wifi is good. The area is very safe too. I got out at 3am in the morning to catch the tuna auction and the streets were perfectly safe to walk around for a solo female.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We stayed at this "capsule" hotel for 1 night to check out the Tsukiji fish market. It was very convenient: about 10 minutes from the market, tops. The capsules are big compared to what we expected and the hotel is stylish with a spa. Really a great and fun experience!Bestregardsfromfar.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Clean and well maintained as compared to other capsules. A 3 min walk from the metro and about 10 min walk to the fish market. Surprisingly, i had one of my soundest sleeps here. The interior feels like a spaceship.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: one of the things i wanted to see while staying in tokyo, however this is not a capsule hotel in is luxury capsule hotel. so do not make the mistake of thinking this is the one you see on web photos. is bigger, there is not a pile of them, there are no doors, just a curtain and all of you can think of for the night: headphones, ear buds, towels, piyama...there are separate floors for women and men.the bathroom/mini onsen is very clean and not on every floor, but this is not an issue.the location is excellent specially for the fish market and Ginza (where all the luxury stores are) and very near Kabuki theater.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I stayed here with my boyfriend as we wanted to experience a capsule – be warned though, there are separate floors for males and females so we didn’t experience the capsule together. The “capsules” are more like very small rooms – there are no cubicles above or below you and you have enough space to stand up. Wifi is availiable on every floor, each capsule is equipped with a TV and the shared bathroom is very clean and all the amenities – toothbrushes, toothpaste, shampoo, conditioner, face wash, moisturizer, body wash, cotton buds, hair dryers, hair straighteners, pajamas and slippers are provided. There is also ample space outside your “capsule” to store suitcases etc and reception will also hold any luggage for you. My two gripes would be that there is only one shower available for all the female guests and that for light sleepers you may be a bit sleep deprived the next day with people continuously coming a going from there capsules. Other than that I felt relatively safe (you need an electronic key to get onto the female floors) and really enjoyed my stay!
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: This is one of the most interesting places you can sleep at while in Tokyo. There are, of course, older, more fascinating capsule hotels there, but First Cabin is newly-open and it offers top notch facilities, excellent service, comfort and everything at the best price. Be advised, however, that if you are travelling as a couple you will have to sleep in different cabins, as cabin hotels usually have separate floors for women and men :) The place is very safe and clean. Choose First Cabin Tsukiji if you wish to visit the Tsukiji fish market and especially the tuna auction (at 4 a.m.) - it's located in the close vicinity of the market and they can help with instructions on how to attend the auction and how to reach the market in 5 minutes walking.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: This capsule hotel is a very high end place out of all capsule hotels. The capsules are quite cheap considering their spacious design. The showers are clean and private, and the whole cabin area is cozy and quiet. It is also quite close to the Tsukiji fish market, if you are interested in that.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Simply outstanding! Modern design, clean facilities, and secure access to all floors only by keycard. Front desk staff are extremely friendly and welcoming. There is a bar in the lobby serving small plates and flat prices for all wines. Excellent location, directly next door to Exit 2 of the Tsukiji metro station. The amenities are impressive - a 38C whirlpool spa, communal (Japanese) style washing facilities, multiple hot showers & toilets mean never having to wait. Premium Shiseido brand mens toiletries and soaps are provided to all guests, as are slippers and spawear. I could not have made a better choice in Tokyo, and I would return there without hesitation. The only thing is the beds are hard, but this is the norm in Japan, and you will get used to it.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I booked this place online after reading Trip Advisor reviews and they don't do it justice. It is 2 metro stops from Tokyo central station. The place is stylish, immaculately clean and so quiet! The facilities blew me away. Spa? More like on site onsen. Beautiful hand basin area with all face clenser, cleansing oil, cotton pads and buds, slippers, you name it. Blowdryer. Check. Great shower if only one. Shampoo conditioner body soap loofah. Check. The cabins themselves are bigger than I expected. You get towel face towel pajamas (Japanese size of course) toothbrush toothpaste and a loofah. Tissues rubbish bin. Access to vending machines for food and drinks ans a beautiful bar on the ground floor. There are a few coffee shops in the vacinity and a couple of restaurants including a Dennys. I would highly reccomed this place to anyone.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Good: excellent location. Friendly staff. New, modern and well maintained. Complete amenities. Safe (just left my luggage at the luggage corner in the cabin). Quiet and clean.Bad: bed is too hard. Room is too hot. Its colder in the corridor and even outside the bldg. i noticed japanese dont like cold aircon. For these 2 reasons alone i am not coming back. I am typing this with no sleep right now and i am checking out early coz i cannot take it. I feel bad becaus i really like the place. But at the end of the day, u need sleep and i didnt get that.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: First Cabin Tsukiji resembles a capsule hotel in that the capsule room is missing a fourth wall and is replaced by a screen door for privacy, except that this place is a step classier. The provided amenities (toweIs, sleepwear, etc) and décor seemed fancier. Also, I was able to fully stand up from my bed. You can't do that at other capsule hotels!This hotel is located conveniently near the Tsukiji station on the Tokyo Metro Hibiya Line. As you might have guessed it from its name, it is in the Tsukiji district of Tokyo's Chuo Ward and within walking distance to the Tsukiji Fish Market, making this a great hotel to stay overnight if you want to catch the early morning tuna auction there. If you’re coming out of Exit 2 from the subway, note that the hotel sign "FIRST CABIN" sticking out of the building is reversed. Hopefully they fix this soon.The front desk was located past a restaurant/bar in the back and one had to walk with their luggage past the diners and people at the bar, which I found a bit awkward. I stayed in "business class," which provided a bed that was larger and slightly more comfortable than a regular capsule hotel. There was a narrow lockable drawer on the side where one could put their valuables in and for the larger stuff there was a rack/luggage area nearby. I didn't use the in-room flat screen TV, but it was quite large and the front desk provided headphones upon request as to not bother other guests when it's on.
