The room was a bit on the warm side, but there was an air-conditioner/fan switch that could be turned on. It didn't drastically change the temperature, but it was better than nothing.If you want a semi-capsule hotel experience, but feel a bit claustrophobic looking at those pictures of traditional capsule rooms, then give this place a try.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The cabins are clean and well laid out with all of the amenities you need. We stayed for one night which was probably enough given you are sleeping in such small quarters. The staff were really helpful and the cabins are located less than 10 minutes walk for Tsukiji fish market, and just down the road from the metro. The only negative is that the cabins are REALLY warm - and the air conditioning doesn't really make a difference. Well worth staying if you need a stop-off in central Tokyo.
hotelName:
19    First Cabin Tsukiji
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Clean and tidy capsule. Convenient location. Close to Korean shops and restaurants. Would have preferred some additional amenities but it looks like a great place for students or business visitors. Simple and clean common place.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The pods have plenty of space, the showers and bathrooms are top notch, beautiful lobby with a wonderful view and workplaces, and the best part; it's located in the heart of Shinjuku! The tram station is a block away and is very convenient if you wanna go for sightseeing!By the time I arrived here I made plenty of new contacts from all around the world! If you like being social and meeting people and travel, this is definetly the place!PS; They hand you out uniform-looking pajamas, giving you a serious Maze Runner feel to the place! Especially with all the modern and minimalistic interior!
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The people who work in the reception need to be able to communicate the rules properly. We went to the reception before 10am and asked several times if it was ok to come back after breakfast to take a shower and use our lockers. This was not going to be a problem. When we got back 10.30 we were told that we could neither use our lockers or the showers. Confusing. After a discussion with another person who worked there, we finally got to take a shower.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Best hostel experience I've had. Simple place but modern and they supply you with what you need: towels, pyjamas and a locker. The ambience is set at a level which keeps everyone quiet and respectful of others. Free Wi-Fi and power socket and covers in your pod. The only downside is you have to check in and check out each day (but you can keep your stuff in your locker), having to pay each day and get new pyjamas and towels. This means leaving the rooms/locker area/washrooms between 10am and 1pm.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: This is a must do for Tokyo. The whole facility, from the incredible 8th floor view, to the otherworldly toilets, was extremely slick. The capsles themselves were cozy and well temperature control led.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Unique and unforgettable experience. The staff is very polite and friendly. The cleanliness of the washrooms, bathrooms and pod is extremely good. A must have experience when in Tokyo. Location - centrally located near to a public transport hub and easily accessible to reach all Tokyo attractions.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: 9 Hours is conceptually brilliant! it's the future of hotels w/ its minimalist aesthetic and super-friendly staff. You'll feel as if you're part of the Starship Enterprise in your pyjamas (daily you'll be given fresh pyjamas, towels, toothbrush/paste). The pods are very comfy and minutes away from the Yamanote Line. Highly recommended.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: My stay at this capsule hotel was beyond my expectations. The simplistic and minimalistic aesthetic is breathtaking. Service is top knotch with easy check in and check out. The way the capsule hotel operates is very efficient and effective. The living quarters was also bigger and more comfortable than imagined. Air conditioning was sufficiently cooled throughout the building and in the capsule being on the bottom capsule. The locker system is very smart and effective. Washrooms are also mind blowing and very clean. The toilets are amazing. From the lounge to the shower floor to the living quarters every detail is clean, refined, and well thought out. Early luggage drop off before check in is also very convenient. I would definitely stay again another time. Thank you so much Nine hours for a wonderful stay!
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The stay at the place is amazing with the cool bedding area and overall clean and relaxing interior decoration. Many amenities were provided to me for a very relax and easy stay. It was a wonderful experience and I will definitely come back again in future visit to Japan.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Staying at this capsule hotel was an amazing experience! I was scared the sleeping pod would be tight and make me feel claustrophobic, but there was plenty of space and looked so nice! It was a little bit hot in the pod for my liking, but once I fell asleep it was no problem. I also noticed that the walls were not sound proof, but it didn't bother me. Everything was so clean and aesthetically pleasing. The toilet seats automatically flip open when you enter the washroom which amazed me. The service was wonderful as well. There is a lounge area which is very spacious and also very relaxing. I would definitely recommend.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: So first off, the capsule hotel is really a unique experience. When you first step in it looks really cool, however for myself I wish I’d have left after the first 5 minutes. The capsules seem to amplify the noise by there shape and position, also the fact that they are plastic probably doesn’t help. It honestly felt like staying in a dormitory with 100 roommates. For some reason the floor got really busy around midnight with somebody coming in or leaving every 5 minutes. I’m not sure if it’s the fact that you can hear everything so well or that I was particularly unlucky with my roommates for the night, but at 2 am I had to ask someone to turn to sound of on their phone as they were playing a game. Of course the hotel is not at fault for the behavior of its guests, but it seems to me that they attract certain behavior by allowing 24h check in and by not making the capsules noise proof. Other than the pair of pajamas you get and the capsule itself the hotel offers nothing special, the capsules are not equipped with anything special and the common space has nothing that makes you want to hang out there (which is probably why people are playing games in their pods) breakfast is at a nearby diner. All in all the experience is cool but I’ll definitely never stay at 9h again.O they also give a gift to anyone who shows them they leave a review on TripAdvisor, so expect reviews to be biased.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Amazing stay! will come back always. it was so clean and so futuristic, literally instagram worthy and worth every penny. We stayed for one night and wanted to immediately stay for longer! the experience is a MUST if in Japan.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Overall a great experience, showers and locker area are very clean and sleeping room was cool and quiet. Closest station is a short 200m walk away and a supermarket is located also just a block away. Free fast wi-fi available throughout the building. Highly recommended.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: This 9hours capsule hotel in Shinjuku-North is modern, clean and gives you a smooth, no-nonsense travel experience. Great value for money. You just gotto love the capsule concept, consider it an upscale hostel with more privacy ;)
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Facility is clean and very near the shopping area and major train stations. Whats best is very near Don Quijote, Ichiran, Ramen Nagi and the famous Gracery Hotel with Godzilla Head. Totally Instagramable!! Highly recommended!
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Nice place and convenient we will come back and return to this place, we will recommend this place to our friends in manila philippines.worth value and worth money for travellers like us, please try this place in shinjuku
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: This is my second trip to Japan and I did try quite a few different capsule hotels. This one is still my favourite! The super stylish concept of the 9 hours brand is great, the place always clean and the check-in/check-out is smooth. I tried the Akasaka branch too, but Shinjuku North is way better: more space, bigger lockers, more showers and a beautiful lobby with amazing Skyline views of Tokyo. I love to work in the little cubicles, that also double as a sort of coworking space.Can totally recommend!
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I would recommend this hotel to people who are traveling to Tokyo on a budget. It is affordable and very clean. The hotel provides pjs and slippers for you to wear. They also provide towels, tooth brush and soap, shampoo, and conditioner for the shower. The showers are large and private. They're clean too. The sleeping room is dark and quiet. There are no doors on the pods though - only a curtain that comes down to cover your pod door so you have privacy. I suggest bringing ear plugs because sometimes guests bring their large roll on suitcases into the sleeping quarters which can wake you up. There are lockers that you can keep your stuff in though. The pod has a light and plug to charge your phone in it. The bed is very comfortable and the blanket is warm. I think it is a cool experience to stay at a hotel like this and suggest you try it out when in Japan! The front desk staff were friendly and spoke some English. The hotel is located a block from the JR train station.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: My wife and I stayed here for one night more for the experience than for any other reason. The "hotel" is extremely clean and well organised and gave a good first impression. On arrival you are issued a card for access to your locker which houses a bag containing pyjamas, slippers, towel, tooth brush and tooth paste (everything you could need). The lockers are massive and easily fit 2 large backpacks with space to spare (This was one of our concerns before arriving). The common room is clean and tidy and has space for you to charge electronics or work on a laptop, it also has a nice view of Shinjuku. From the reception / common area you go down either the male or female lift to get to the segregated sleeping and washing areas. The washing areas have around (and this is a guess) 12 showers and 10 toilets with basins and mirrors down the center, and at no point were there any queues with what looked like a full house. The sleeping area is very space age and looked great in my eyes. The beds are large enough that you can easily sit up and move around and they have charging points a couple of small shelves and a pull down blind. I got a good night's sleep but was awoken early morning by someone nearby having a bad dream and making some strange noises, but other than that it was reasonably quiet to say how many people were in the room together. Overall it was a good experience and at a good price so i would recommend it to anyone who is used to sleeping in hostels / refuges / bunk rooms etc.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Spent two nights at the this capsule hotel. Immaculately clean. Friendly helpful staff. Excellent location 5 minutes from the JR Yamanote line, easy transfer from Haneda airport and great for Shinjuku and Shibuya.Capsule was bigger than it looks in pictures, mattress firm partner thought it was too warm I was happy with the temperature. Would I stay again yes , however for no more than.2 nights as there is no natural light until you go to reception area, which is large and airy.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We stayed at 9Hrs Shinjuku for a night just to experience staying at a capsule hotel, and we were not at all disappointed.I understand that this place opened in March 2019 for the business, so quite new and fresh looking. We liked the facilities, including shower, washrooms, big locker place and sleeping pod. The kit provided by 9Hrs was adequate, and the premises clean and tidy. One issue we faced was absence of temperature control for individual pods, which bothered few of us. Location was great, near to train station and convenience stores and restaurants nearby. Staff was very helpful as well. Most helpful thing here was they allowed us to keep our bags after check-out as we were heading for sight-seen before we check-in into another hotel. One peculiar thing to remember is that you don't get access to pods from 10am to 1pm, as its closed for cleaning.Apart from few peculiarities, we enjoyed our experience very much and recommend the place for a night max for families.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Loved it. It was perfect for a couple of nights. The capsule hotel is part of the Tokyo experience. It was super clean and the staff very friendly. The location is perfect. I would recommend it to everyone.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Everything is clinically kept in white and it feels a bit like being in a hospital, but the whole place is clean and functional. Male and female dorms are on separate floors, which you reach using different elevators. After your check-in you will first store your luggage in lockers and change into indoor clothes and slippers that you will find there. The capsules are simple but will do as a bed for a night or two. If you stay longer than one night you have to check out in the morning and remove your things from the capsule for cleaning, but you can keep the locker. 9 hours hostels are some of the cheaper accommodation options in Japan and still pretty expensive considering that you share space with around 30 other persons and despite can hear almost every single noise they make. If you have a light sleep, use earplugs!
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Nice, clean capsule hotel, very close to shin-okubo station. Pods are very clean and comfortable, there is an electric plug in each pod, which makes it very convenient. Prices are ok for Tokyo. Close to several combinis and Korean restaurants.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The staff here were very helpful, everyone I spoke to had good English, I asked for the temperature in my dorm to be lowered a little and they immediately adjusted it. The pods were more spacious than some I've stayed in previously. Modern, spotless, good price, easy to find, 15-20 minute walk to the central Shinjuku area, big lockers for your belongings, and a nice view of the city from the lounge area. I had a very good night's sleep here. One negative point however is that we had to check out every day and leave our luggage at reception, despite being booked in for two nights.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We enjoyed staying in this place. Well organised with everything a travellers could need. Very quiet in the sleeping area. Enough space in a capsule to feel comfortable. Good location, situated at a very busy street, with plenty of shops and bars.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Not only is this an incredibly unique accommodation experience but a genuinely fantastic place to stay! Great location - 2 minute walk from JR station Shin Okubo and about a 10 minute walk from central Shinjuku. The area is known as Korea Town with many great restaurants and shops on your doorstep. It feels like a super authentic area, with hardly any western tourists.The hotel itself is spotless, modern and well designed. Upon check in you’re assigned a capsule number, locker, slippers, pyjamas and towel. If you’re staying multiple days you must check out each day, but don’t worry your capsule and locker stays the same throughout your stay, but you can not access them from 10am-1pm while the staff are cleaning the areas. Showers are on a different floor to your capsule, but they are spacious, clean and fully stocked with toiletries.There’s probably 50+ capsule in each dorm room so expect a bit of noise/snoring. Just remember your earplugs and sleeping mask if you’re a light sleeper.Overall a fantastic stay and I’d recommend it to everyone!
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Very comfortable and convenient place to stay. Big common areas make it easy to work, visit or read.Check in was quick and the staff was helpful. All areas were perfectly clean.Sleeping area was quiet and comfortable. Great overnight option
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: It is my second time staying there. I spend my last night coming from the Japanese alps before flying off in late afternoon from Narita.The location is convenient close to many eateries, bars and shops - ideal to kill a few hours before getting in the plane.There is one metro station that brings you to Shinjuku or Tokyo station.As long as you set up the right expectations you will enjoy.The whole process of checking in is highly efficient. The pod is comfy and well heated. The common area is quite pleasant, withoffice space, very well heated too.The whole place, pod and common areas offer good and fast wifi connection.The bathroom, locker room and pods are very clean and well maintained.I could sleep well thanks to my noise canceling headset. My first time I did not have those and did not feel as much rested. The light pollution is not as potent as the noise, but in case it is good to have a mask with you.Overall the place offers a good value option. They keep it simple and deliver on it.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Stayed here for three nights because I wanted to check out the hype was all about. This capsule hotel was in an excellent location near the train station, plenty of Korean restaurants (high concentration of Korean fast food and restaurants) and a short walked to Shinjuku central. The pods were clean, spacious, warm and cozy. Bathrooms were very clean and each toilet was separate and private. Will stay again and met my expectations.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Nice place to stay when you don’t need a whole lot. I didn’t get in until midnight , didn’t book online and was going to cost me like 8000yen so I stood their and booked for the far cheaper rate. So if you see a cheaper rate book it so you have it set.Showers were very clean, pod was very clean . A little on the warm side but not bad. Charger port in your pod.And they have a big locker to store all your stuff in.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: location- 3/5 it is near the jr shinjuku station but is more or less 1km walk to the nearest metro station. since it is in the koreantown area, there is a lot of restuarants, convenient stores and beauty/pharmacy stores. ambiance- 5/5 the lobby is located on the top floor as well as the common area where you can eat. the capsule pods and lockers are on the same floor but the bathroom is on a different floor. there is a separate elevators for the male and female areas. cleanliness- 5/5 upon checked in, they will provide you a bag with pajamas, towels, slipper and toothbrush. the capsule pods are being kept clean everyday. the bathroom are spacious and very neat. service- 4/5 some staff are able to converse in simple english however when i inquired on how to get to the subway they were not able to provide accurate instructionsactivities- 2/5 since it is really for backpackers, there is limited activity although they provide a spacious common area for eating etc
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The main reason why I decided to stay in Nine Hours is because I wanted to experience staying in a capsule hotel. Its one of the experiences I wont pass up in Tokyo.The location of this capsule hotel is very central in Tokyo. Its one minute stop from SHinjuku station. As you exit the only exit way from the station to turn right go towards the direction of the railway bridge and on your right you will see 7 eleven. The entrance to the hotel is right after the 7-11 store.You can only use one lift going up to the 8th floor where the reception desk is located. As you enter the 8th floor, the reception desk will e right infront of you .A wall separates the reception desk and the main lobby where there is a long table, individual booths and a viewing deck of a nice view of the Shinjuku area.Once you check in they will give you a black net bag containing two towels, a black slipper, a pajama set and a toothbrush.They will also give you a card where there is a bar code you will swipe in your locker to open the locker. You have to return all that except for the slippers and toothbrush to the reception desk when you check out the next day,Everyone is expected to check out everyday before 10 am.There are no facilities for dining so you can buy food outside and eat it in the lobby. U cannot consume food inside your capsule.There is a separate floor for women (5th and 6th floor) shared showers are on the 7th floor. Each floor has toilets and wash basins.The capsules are actually quite spacious. I am 5'2 and I can sit up properly inside and my feet barely touches the privacy screen that you can put down at night.The hotel is located in Korean town and if you are adventurous enough you can actually walk to Shinjuku main station from the hotel.When I checked in on the first day the receptionist was very nice and friendly but on my second night the girl who checked me in was grumpy and showed her displeasure when I came back to tell her that my locker has another bag inside(they told me I can use the same locker on my second night).If you want to stay in an affordable place and near the tourist area, try to stay in this place. Its worth at least one night stay.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The location is very convenient and easy to find. This being said, it’s north of Shinjuku and more centrally located in Korea town, which was interesting to see, though at night the area dies. Many restaurants and bars were closed by midnight, so if you’re looking to party this won’t be the spot.In terms of the hotel/capsules, this was a great experience! The facilities are clean and orderly. The staff was very friendly and able to communicate in English. The capsules were comfortable and surprisingly spacious. Lastly, and probably the best part, breakfast is included just down the street at Gusto, which is a solid Japanese diner-style spot. Overall, I definitely recommend this spot!
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The conditions and standards in this hotel are very good: beds are comfortable, staff is very nice and helping, very clean hotel, large capsules, great common room with a great view of Shinjuku area, very central, and reasonable prices.But there is one rule they have you should know before booking there: You have to do a check out every day at 10:00 am, even if you're booked for more than one night. You check out at 10:00 am every day, and You re-check in later starting from 13:00. And, between 10:00-13:00, You're allowed only to use the common room.which means: if You're a party animal or a night person, it's not recommended for you to go to this hotel.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I stayed here with my other friends. the location is very strategic, you can find lots of place to eat, train station and shopping area by walking distance. The room itself is quite nice, I thought it will be smaller but apparently not. One of my friend was worried because she has claustrophobic but in the end she has no problem at all. They provide you towel, face towel, tooth brush, and pajamas to use! The only thing that bothered me is the locker. the space is quite small so it is quite a challenge to arrange your luggage on your locker area but you can manage by finding an empty space nearby! :)
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I really like this capsule hotel mentality and they are doing the best with all facilities. Just perfect. You should stay there and enjoy Tokyo. Location, staff, facilities... perfect! In addition they are very helpful in order to make you relax.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I'm currently staying at Nine Hours and wish I had booked another hostel. I have stayed at hostels around tokyo for cheaper and this is the worst hostel I have stayed at by far. The pods have uncomfortable beds and are situated in noisy rooms that echo with sound. Each pod room is cramped with dozens of beds. There are way too many people going in and out at all hours of the night. The pod doors are flimsy and let every sound in. There are also no windows or natural light in the rooms so good luck if you feel claustrophobic. To make matters worse you have to check out and check back in every day of your stay, meaning you have to pack and unpack every single day. This is such a pain and waste of time. And the ONE elevator that takes you to your room is inconvenient and takes forever. Plus the whole hostel is very poorly ventilated and they play obnoxious elevator music everywhere, making it impossible to get work done or find a peaceful place to relax. NEVER AGAIN. I CAN'T WAIT TO GET OUT OF HERE.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Location is easy to find, in the middle of Tokyo's Korean Town, Shin-Okubo.Provides good amenities : towels, pajamas, tooth brush, soap.We had a good night sleep here. There are a lots of shops and food around the hotel.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: This was my first time staying at a capsule hotel and I loved it! Clean and quiet, and I was pleasantly surprised by the size of the capsules (I’m 5’10” and had plenty of space, and my 6’3” husband felt the same). They provide PJs, slippers, towels, and even toothbrushes! The location was great, about a 4 min walk from the nearest JR station and surrounded by a ton of restaurants. For the price and convenience and I would definitely stay here again.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I had stayed at two Nine Hours branches in the same trip to Tokyo and this was the better one. Both were clean and well-maintained to their usual standards. There were no vending machine or water fountain in the property. But since it's located in Korean town near Shin-Okubo Station it's surrounded by many shops, convenience stores, and restaurants. The property has 3 elevators and only one of them allows access from street level to the 8th floor where the reception and the lounge are. Separate elevators connect to male and female floors from the 8th floor, meaning you have to connect on the 8th floor everytime you return to your pod (room) from outside. Some consider this an inconvenience, some consider this added security. Lockers and restrooms are on the same floor as your pods. My 29" suitcase was able to fit into the locker which was a huge plus. Towels, toothbrush, pajamas, and slippers were provided. The water pressure of the showers was extremely good. However, the showers were not on the same floor as the pods which I did find inconvenient. The pods were fitted with light switches and a power outlet. It was a little stiff and warm especially after showering. Nobody talked or played music in the sleeping area but I was woken up by other people's alarms in the morning. All in all a very nice experience and I would definitely stay again.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Really cool place to stay for a few nights in a convenient location (Korean area one station north of Shinjuku). It was clean and the staff were lovely. Capsules were comfortable and had a light/charging point. Shared showers/toilets were good, price very was reasonable for Tokyo and included a tasty breakfast at a cafe down the road. The only thing that we disliked was the daily checkout at 10am and re-check-in after 1pm which was really inconvenient as you couldn't access your locker, the bathrooms etc or if you'd had a few drinks the night before you couldn't sleep in if needed. General loud snorers and people in the sleeping room but nothing unexpected. Good for a night or two, we recommend it.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: 9hours was very clean and well-kept. Staff was friendly and spoke good English. It was easy to communicate with them to let them know that my key card wasn't working, whereas I had extreme difficulty letting staff know the same problem at another hotel.Was a bit expensive considering the lack of amenities - there wasn't even a vending machine. I stayed in capsule hotels in Akihabara for $15-20 cheaper that had TVs in the cap, better cap charging stations, and better lounges.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: If you're keen to try a capsule hotel, then this is a great option. It is very modern and stylish, and has all you need for a good night's sleep. The location is quite a walk from the nearest metro station, and pretty far from Shinjuku station, so it is not the easiest to get to and from with heavy suitcases.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Something that always fascinated me about Japan were capsule hotels, so during my time in Tokyo, I thought it would be cool to try one out and I had a great time.It’s located in a modern building with a sleek basic design which is somehow charming with a main lobby and then men and women separate dorms and shower rooms. You are given pyjamas which are comfy, a toothbrush, tickets for breakfast at a local cafe and a sizeable locker to put your things in.If you are worried about the capsule pods themselves, don’t be worried, I’m quite a tall person and was able to fit inside with enough room to extend my legs. Inside the pod is a curtain for some privacy, a charging socket, pillow, duvet and mattress. During the nights I was there everyone was quiet and I got to sleep easy, sometimes people set alarms on their phones which do wake you up, but I can resleep fine.All in all, I loved the place and would happily go back!
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: My friend and I arrived into Tokyo very early in the morning and headed to the 9 Hours. We wanted to leave our bags at the hotel knowing that we may not be able to check in yet. Upon arrival before I could even get a word out to reception, the receptionist very rudely said “check in is not I’ll 1”. He continued to be rude as we sorted our selfs and bags out. He also seemed to be very rude to his co-worker. This left a bitter taste for us and we were not looking forward to checking in or staying there. As for the capsule hotel itself it very interesting and would recommended staying there. Very clean and awesome experience just beware of the ONE staff member who ruined it for us.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I can not fault this hotel/hostel, staying in a pod overnight intrigued me and I'm so glad that I found this place. Everything here was super clean and modern, when you check in they even give you a bag with towels, slippers and pajamas. The pod can get a little stuffy when the blinds are down just because there is no ventilation and the only area for improvement for me would be the pillows; I found them a little hard.The location is incredible, super easy to get to from the train station and alot of shops/restaurants are just walking distance away.Can not wait to stay here again next time I pass though Tokyo and would highly recommend this place to anyone wanting to experience pod life. If you stay for multiple nights you do have to check out then back in each day however you can keep the locker so you don't have to worry about taking your luggage out.One recommendation would be to take ear plugs, I have stayed in plenty of hostels/share rooms before and never have I shared a room with so many inconsiderate travellers... People were coming into the pod area up until midnight and talking loudly when entering and the noise started up again at 5am when people started waking up.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The capsule hotel looks modern and futuristic. It is located in popular place for K-Pop fanatics and Korean restaurants. It is perfect for travellers who will just need a place to sleep at night and visit the tourist spots in daytime. The only inconvenience is you need to check out every morning as they need to clean the capsule pods. If you are couple, the sleeping quarters for male and female are separated in different floors. TThis is perfect for solo travellers. Better book early to get cheaper price.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Fine for budget travellers and backpackers. This is very bare-bones experience. Not being able to lock the pod was very inconvenient, and so was having to check out every day. The lockers were not large enough and everything about staying there was awkward. The pods were too stuffy on the first night and I felt I was suffocating. THey kindly turned up the aircon though and it was more bearable. Other than that, showers were clean. THe reception area was very basic and staff not particularly knowledgeable.Also the male toilets weren't cleaned enough - they often smelled of urine.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Many travelers had share their experience, check in- QR-code + locker + unpack - shower at different floor- not much space in the capsule.The sleeping quality is really good unless you have snoring mate in your room.The whole concept of the hotel is so advance and new to me, is very interesting.The location is great, near to SHin-Okubo station. 2-5 blocks with Family Mart and 7-11. Shin-Okubo is more to Korean Street to me.Cons is that, you need to unpack and pack every time you go change or shower, and that is tiring. For 1 day, is is nice to try.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The hotel is divided by men and women as many things in Japan.There is one floor with the bathrooms and another floor with the capsules and the lockers.You can leave your personal belongings in a private locker that opens with a QR code that they give you when you check in.The capsule is very modern looking like. Feels like being in a spaceship. Its a very clean place. The space in the capsule it's actually ok.The main disadvantage is the noise. There are people snoring, coughing, coming in and out of the room the whole night. For me is was really impossible to sleep even half an hour... It was exhausting.The price is really low.Even if I was not able to sleep, for me it was a very different and worthy experience. It's for sure a one of a kind...
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I really enjoy my 1 night stay the overall experience was great and smooth check in / out During check in you will be given a bag of pajamas / towel / toothbrush & slipper upon check out return the bag with towel and pajamas. The capsule come with single power outlet, a light dimmer i a pulling curtain in sleeping pods. I will come back again for my next trip again.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Even though it might get a little loud at night because you’re basically sharing a room with 40 people, I loved the design, the idea, the location and the showers! Free slippers and towels + toothpaste and toothbrush makes this better than a simple hostel.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: This place is perfect for a one or two nighter stay through Tokyo. Totally Affordable.All you amenities are there. Lockers, Toilets & Sleep Pods are located on different floors to that of your shower rooms and the check-in facilities.You are given a locker like that of a gym change room to put your baggage in.The showers are large, private and clean. You are given a towel, toothbrush and PJs and slippers. You give back the towel and PJs at the end of the visitThe beds are super comfy and a power outlet is provided in your capsule bed to keep your phone or laptop charged. This is a quiet warm room where respect is shown to other fellow sleepers.Only things that need to be considered in this establishment is that the locker key needs to be more of a hard card than a flimsy card that is not waterproof.The elevator situation takes forever to interchange between floors.I will take the opportunity to stay here again as this provided more space than a lot of Air BnBs on offer and it is situated in one of the best areas of Tokyo with everything around.Staff were super helpful and there is a common area where you can recharge and plan your day out in Tokyo.I would rate this place a Big 9 out of 10.
hotelName:
20    nine hours Shinjuku-North
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I've stayed for 3 nights at this capsule hotel. The capsule was spacious and bigger than I thought. I did not feel cramped or claustrophobic. The staff was fine some of them don't speak english but they have a translator. There's an alarm clock and a power outlet in the capsules. There's a different floor for women. The washrooms and the showers were kept clean. They provide evereything you need for your stay from pyjamas to shavers. The only hasle is that it can be annoying if you forgot something in your locker when you're in your capsule. Keep in mind that this place is only for sleeping there's limited space for anything else but there's a common place with a TV where you can have a seat or have a coffee with a smoking room. There's some convinience stores next to this hotel where you can grab a breakfast. Also be quiet in the caspules.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: 仕事が遅くなって、急に決めました。　共用スペースやキャビン、シャワーも清潔で、海外のゲスト用に英語、中国語、韓国語で表示があり、便利なホテルです。　I used this hotel after long overtime. The open sapce, shower and also cabin are kept with cleaness. And, guides are showed with English, Chineese and Korea. It should be covenience for visitors.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Everything was clean. Staff were nice and easy to communicate with. Everything was straight forward. Very quite place to stay at and was very comfortable. Location was relatively good. For the price you get amazing value. I regret not staying longer.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Stayed one night with friends before we all left for the airport. Close to subway station and a bus direct to Narita Airport. Very clean and they provide towels and pjs so I didn’t have to open my suitcase to get it. The locker space is a bit cramped. But overall I really enjoyed my experience of the capsule hotel
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: First accommodation upon arrival in Japan! Spent 3 nights on female floor. I picked this location partly due to close to Tsukiji market. I found Ginza oddly beautiful, so many shops & yet so perfectly clean.Back to the capsule hotel...I was very happy with the number of shower stalls & toilets & plenty of space for everyone to blowdry hair etc. There was a small lounge area for eating with drink vending machine. I was able to fit my backpack in the locker but travelers with big luggage won't be able to. That's not the hotel's fault. Price varied depending on day of the week. I thought it was a great deal.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: This was a wonderful capsule hotel in the heart of Ginza, and an experience that I would repeat in a heartbeat!There were 4 of us - 3 women and 1 man. The accommodation and lounge floors are segregated for males/females, but we had a great evening together downstairs in the lobby (very comfortable ground-level tables and seating PLUS a public footbath immediately outside) until we decided to retire to our capsules for the night. The capsules themselves are roomy, with tv (and headphones) USB socket, light, fan and roll down/or roll across shutter. Pyjamas and room slippers are provided, along with towels and all toiletries. There is a vending machine in the lounge and a convenience store immediately next door with great pre-packaged food etc.Staff are excellent and speak far more English than we spoke Japanese.We all throughly enjoyed our night and would love to spend a few more nights (at least) again in this accommodation.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I spent one night in this capsule hotel in the beautiful neighbourhood of Ginza. It's super clean and very conveniently located (just 5 to 10 minutes from the subway). Although I saw people from different ages, I'd say it's more convenient for young people.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The location of this hotel is very convenient - a couple of minutes from Ginza's main shopping street and about a 20 minutes walk from Tokyo Station. We stayed for the "experience" and also because we had a very early morning so there was no sense in paying full hotel price. We're two women so it made sense as there're different floors for men and women. After paying and checking in, you receive a key for a locker to put your shoes in and replace it with slippers. Afterwards you enter the locker area where you can put your bag/suitcase (in the corner of the room, the locker isn't big enough for luggage) and you have a bag with clean pajamas and towels. There's a lounge with a microwave and drinks machine where you can chat. The showers were clean and pretty spacious. The capsule itself was very clean, with a TV and outlet to charge your phone. Overall - a nice experience.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The Bay Hotel has an incredible location, near from a subway station, the place is near from many convenience stores, and other restaurants, the washroom is very clean, luminous and spacious, I feel réalité good here, hope to coma back again
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Unless you like small and narrow space to stay, I’d like you to have experience of “capsule hotel” that is a very unique hotel in Japan.Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel, which is the best capsule hotel,” is clean and cheep. And the staff is very friendly and kind. Safe enough for women to stay because men’s rooms are located at the different floor.VERY, VERY SMALL ROOM but it has some public shower rooms, toilets and washing machine. So no problem to stay. Let’s try!!
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Stayed in men's floor third floor bottom bunk capsule. The floors and rooms of the hotel are spotless, everything is great quality. 5stars for providing pjs, slippers and toiletries.Only surprise was that the corridor outside capsule can get cold at night.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Great experience staying at this accomodation with friendly staff and clean facilities. Exactly as offered and comfortable capsules to sleep in, highly recommend for a fun and safe time. They let me stay until checkin which was very helpful.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We stayed here for 1 night for fun, I and my 11 year old daughter on the women's floor and my husband and 14 year old son on the men's floor. My husband had a bad experience with loud and rude guests but when he complained to the front desk, they moved him to an empty floor--they were lucky the place wasn't full. My daughter and I had a top & bottom capsule near the door in a room with only 1 bank of about 14 capsules facing some windows (I think they were 401 and 402). They were only about half full and fairly quiet. The bathrooms and showers are beautifully designed and new and clean. They provide pajamas, razors, washcloths, hairbrushes and toothbrushes and there is also nice shampoo, conditioner and body soap in the showers. The capsules are fairly roomy for smaller people and I did not feel claustrophobic. You can leave the screen open a bit for some air. If you are bothered by small noises from other people going in and out, this might not be for you, but we had a good experience.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We had a fantastic and comfortable stay here at Ginza Bay Hotel! Its location is ideal for those visiting the Ginza shopping district and Tsukiji Fish Market early in the morning. Being 5'2", the beds were perfect and comfortable, but anyone taller than 5'6" would definitely start to find it claustrophobic. Despite being hostel-style, the hotel provides all amenities that a typical hotel would, from towels to toothbrushes, and even pajamas! Plenty of showers and toilets and a pampering room for hair and makeup. The hotel was very clean and quiet - there is only a small common area on the first floor but even then, not much interaction between travellers. The foot bath outside is a nice touch, perfect for soaking those tired feet.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The location is in about 10 minutes walking distance near Shimbashi station. You can make use of a JR rail pass or take a metro. Everything that you need for a night stay is provided (no need for a necessaire ) in this capsule hotel. You have a locker for the shoes, a locker for your stuff or an ovesized wardrobe for big luggage (but not locked). The staff is friendly and speaks English. You can also leave your luggage before you check in and after you have checked out. As a couple u need to split up for the night in two different capsules, as a single I think this capsule hotel is a good choice. There are also some lockers near the main entrance that I think you could use, even if you don't plan to stay at this capsule hotel.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The location is good, overall good experience. Some reviews stated that beds are not comfortable, although they are not super cushioned, they are good enough for a night sleep. The experience of sleeping in a capsule is good but the bad part is that you can hear all the noise on the other capsules, in my case a guy left his alarm beeping for 15 minutes while he went to take a shower at 4 am, so if you need a quiet room to sleep this is not your place.You will be provided with a fresh set towels and pijamas everyday, also available free soap, razor blades and toothbrush.Bathrooms/showers are very nice and clean, despite there was quite few people during my stay I never had issues to find one available.Lockers are quite small, bigger bags have to be placed in communal shelfs which make the process of dressing a little bit of a hassle, considering there's only one bench to sit.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Great capsule hotel experience. Easy check-in/check-out, comfortable sleeping pods with clean sleep wear and towels provided every day. The lounge area is spacious and a good spot to hang out instead of being confined to your bed. A couple of small cons - I think I was pretty lucky to have a capsule toward the back of the sleeping area, away from the door. I’m not sure if I’d have had as much of a restful experience if I was closer. Also the cleaning times from 10am to 4pm seems a little excessive. I understand the need for a quick turnaround and appreciate the shove to not lounge in bed all morning, but having all of the shower area off-limits from 10am for most of the day seems a little overkill, maybe a staggered cleaning system would be better so some showers can be used while others are cleaned. Other than that rates are very reasonable, facilities are great (and clean), and the location is amazing for Ginza, Tsukiji and general access to metro links for the rest of Tokyo. Would definitely stay again!
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: First time in a capsule hotel and its spotless! The bathroom and the capsule itself is so clean and they have small amenities, like wash rag, towel, q tips, and etc. I’m so surprised by how quiet it is!
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I stayed 2 nights at the Bay and it was very pleasant. There was a common room with just about everything I needed and clean, nice capsules to sleep in. The capsules were stacked in two levels high and seemed ok to enter. Mine was at the bottom. The staff suggested fresh sushi at the fish market nearby and it was great. They spoke good English and even lent me scales to weigh my bag.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Wonderful 1st capsule stay experience. Well equipped with lockers, plenty of showers, makeup room equipped with hair dryers, rest area with microwave, boiler, plugs for your electronic devices and vending machines, laundry area. We came with big luggage. You can do away with packing and unpacking if you travel light since you do not have to spent time at the lockers area for all the troubles.Nightwear, towels, earplugs provided. Bathroom with body wash, shampoo, conditioner.The capsule is spacious enough that you can put small bags/backpacks. And you are able to sit-up on the bed. The bed is firm for a good sleep. Everything was fine, no complaints.I will definitely visit again if travel solo or with a partner on a low budget.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: My son and I stayed here on 6 Sep 17. It's a good basic place to sleep. The staff is friendly and helpful. The price is great for Tokyo, especially in Ginza. There is a lot to see and do within about 10 minutes walk, including the train station. My only complaint is that it was hot with the shade down, I opened the shade and it was fine.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I can't say enough great things about this pod hotel. I only had one night in Tokyo and am so glad that I stayed here. The pods are quite comfy (complete with bamboo mats for privacy and outlets to charge your phone), the bathrooms are *spotlessly* clean, and the service is efficient and helpful. I don't speak Japanese, so the receptionist immediately Skyped a translator using an iPad to make sure I had an optimal experience.The hotel is conveniently located in downtown Tokyo and an easy walk to the Tsukiji Fish Market and many other restaurants and shops in the downtown.The only caveat is that men and women stay on separate floors, so it might not be ideal for a couple or family traveling together.Overall, I would highly recommend staying here over a "normal" hotel, as the pod hotel experience would be difficult to find outside of Japan!
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: this is my second capsule hotel experience. this is coming from a resident here in japan. i stayed the one in ueno and this one is 360 degrees nothing compared to that. both men and women can stay, but in separate floors of course. it is really close to ginza subway station or shimbashi station. there is a donquijote nearby and lots of convenience store nearby. there is no bath, but there are many showers with individual spaces. there is one big shower room which i wanted to use but could not, did not want to wait. the facilities are very clean and new. which is the good thing about the place. the staff is helpful and things are easy to use. they provide you with a lot of free toiletries to use which is also a plus. the lounge is fine. no massage chairs but fine. no tv in the capsule so the only tv is in the lounge which is mainly japanese tv anyway so nobody really watches it. the lounge has a smoking room. and also has a lot of vending machines. the capsule is nice and clean. it can get a little hot inside, so depending on the person, some leave there sliding door/window open. there are more foreigners staying there, which i think the hotel mainly caters to foreign visitors. im asian but very westernized, so all my needs were basically fulfilled. the location is great. for sure, i will stay here again for my next staycation.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Very clean and modern hotel. You can hear people coming in and out and ruffling through their plastic bags throughout the night. If you are from the states, warning there's no air control, it gets sooooo hot and humid in the capsule. Barely feel the ac, it's set universally to 72 degrees, other than that it was a great experience.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I stayed here with my sister to kick off our vacation in Japan earlier this month. I've heard about capsule hotels so really wanted to try it out. The amenities (bathroom, showers etc) were immaculate, very clean! There's even a spot for you to brush/wash up and do your make up/hair. Very nice! The only downside to the capsule hotel which I probably should have expected given the unique sleeping accommodations was that I got no sleep. Combined with jet lag and the fact that you can hear every single peep and noise, posed a huge problem for my sister and I to get rest. All in all, I enjoyed staying here for the most part and was impressed by the cleanliness of the hotel. I would not recommend the restaurant below in the lobby but it's in a convenient location so one would not go hungry or be in shortage of food options. There is a 24/hour Lawson next door. Love Lawson and Family Mart! hahaha
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Stayed here for a few nights and it was a great experience. You have to leave your shoes in a locker when you first enter in the lobby. The lobby also contains the lockers for the men as well as their washroom. The capsules are all on a different floor for each gender. Showers are individual. The capsules themselves are quite comfortable. Only thing is that this was the one capsule that did not offer televisions in the capsule. Nothing wrong with that if you have a book or phone. I would stay here again.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Having never stayed in a capsule hotel, we decided to stay at the Ginza Bay Hotel which was an amazing experience. Located 5 mins by walk from Ginza station, the capsule hotel is extremely clean and the staff are very friendly. They even let me stay extra hours without charge which was amazing. The best part is its extremely close to the Tsuijiki Fish Market (7 mins by walk) and Tokyo Tower (20 mins). Lots of dining in the heart of the shopping district. BAr High Five one of the best whiskey bars is 5 misn way too. I would highly recommend this capsule hotel
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Loved it. Comfy, clean, helpful girls at counter. A great experience and a must do. The rooms remained quiet and I really saw no reason not to return again. I found the instructions easy and pajamas provided were actually comfy.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We were told that a capsule hotel is a must do in Japan and I am glad we chose Ginza Bay Hotel. We didn't want to go too cheap, but nothing too expensive either. This one worked out to be about $50AUD/night.The whole place has a very peaceful atmosphere, and it felt a bit like we were having a bit of a pamper night, with a little bag provided with pyjamas, hairbrush, toothbrush and paste and towels. We didn't even really need to unpack anything out of our suitcases except clothes to change in to the next day! The showers were lovely and warm, with soap, shampoo and conditioner provided. There was a little room with great lighting for applying make-up etc, and hair dryers and straighteners provided. It was a little busy at around 8.30/9am when the other quests are also getting ready for the day.The staff at the front desk were great, and we were able to leave our big suitcases there before check in and after check out which allowed us to explore the city. They can also happily recommend some great places to eat.The hotel is close to the Ginza strip with all the major fashion outlets. It is also an easy walk to the fish markets and Shibashi station. You will not be able to sleep with your husband/wife/girlfriend/boyfriend, as males and females are separated on different floors. But there is a common area where both males and females can hang out. This is one of the cleanest hotels I have stayed in. The only downside is if you are sleeping next to someone who is not very considerate and is noisy opening and closing their capsule doors, and a bit rough getting in and out of them. But that is not the hotels fault.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I have stayed at the Ginza Bay capsule hotel a few nights niw and have been very pleased with the place and its staff. The bathroom and shower facilities are great. The location is also worth mentioning as it is close to more than one subway station.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Stayed at this capsule Hotel. Was close to all the transport links and lots of shops nearby. Very convenient for short stays and with extra helpful and polite staff who speak very good English it is a good choice. The only negative is that you must check out every morning so this is not really suitable for couples or families but very helpful if you are on a short business stay I need a hotel quick.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Best location, hospitality is excellent the area in very close to prime shopping within minutes walking distance, make no mistake this will be the hotel to check in if you are planning to Ginza, we all love this place
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Great Place. Very nice design .Excellent Management . Super clean .Great location ( Ginza Av. Is 10 min walk ) , Really enjoyed the experience, Very nice and Friendly staff. Esp. Karen (Best Receptionist )..Wish her Good Luck.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Close to train and metro stations, it was very convenient. Very friendly staff, very clean and free toiletries. Only downside was that there was a couple of loud snorers but nothing that some good earplugs can't fix. Highly recommended if on a budget. Stayed here for a whole week so I had to check in and check out everyday however there are lockers, closets and a cloakroom where you can leave your luggage.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Honestly, I was quite skeptical about staying in a capsule hotel. I had fairly low expectations, but I figured I would try it anyways for the sake of new experiences.However, upon arrival at Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel, I found myself pleasantly surprised. My stay was absolutely fabulous. The hotel is modern and clean. The capsule experience was fun (as were the many included amenities - which were not provided at any other hostel in Japan). All around, a great capsule experience - I wish I stayed here for more than one night. I think if you are going to try staying in a capsule (or, if you are going to stay in a Tokyo hostel), this is definitely the place to do it.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Had a good chance to take couple nights at Ginza, and choosing this hotel was so great. This was my 1st time ever with capsule hotel in Tokyo and Ginza Bay Hotel made my night so wonderful with nice experiences. Well space management with very comfortable facilities, particularly capsules and bathrooms. The common area and also the capsule were extremely clean. The shower stuffs and bedsuit were provided new every night. Staffs are good both in English and Chinese.Only little things - A little bit far from Shimbashi stn. About 10 minutes walk with huge luggages was such tired.And cannot be able to be in the room from 10am-5pm.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The place is in an excelent location. Ginza is the best place to stay in Tokyo.The place is super clean, everything is in order and even though it is a capsule hotel it is very private and quiet. I highly recommend this place, however i must say that there are 2 things that i wasnt very comfortable with.1. The lights in the room cant be turned off, the capsule has a shed that is translucent. So you will have light during your whole sleep.....if you cant stand this, better choose something else maybe.2. It is hot in the capsules. The only thing available is a fan that i wouldn't call a fan, because i never felt any air. I had to sleep with the shed open - which gave me even more light.LIGHT + NO AIRif you dont like this, dont stay here.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I went to all of the BH capsule locations in Tokyo. The Nihombashi location is by far the BEST. The layout is great, with big full-height lockers which are located right next to the sleeping area, laundry machines, showers, and toilets... all TOGETHER. Other locations have half-height lockers and the various facilities are on different floors (sometimes even the toilets and showers are not located together). The beds here are comfortable too. It's a great place to stay, I believe I paid ¥2900 per night.Now for ALL of the locations I can say: They are professionally run and very clean. Most of the people using them seemed to be young Japanese (or other Asian) businessmen and a few tourists. I highly recommend staying here if all you need is a nice place to sleep. They have everything you'd expect at an upper mid-tier hotel: hair dryers in the bathrooms, towels, washcloth, shampoo, conditioner, body soap, etc. All locations seem to have laundry as well, though it is more convenient at some locations compared to others.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I was in Tokyo Ginza Bay hotel in December and it made my staying in Tokyo very enjoyable. The location is perfect: in the heart of Ginza, a very dynamic area in Tokyo, full of stores and restaurants, and easily connected by subway. The rooms were very clean and new, as well as the common areas (showers, toilets, etc). There are lockers for your bags and the hotel provides you with towels, night wear, toothbrush and all bathroom amenities. The staff is very kind and helpful as well.The price was very good in comparison to what the hotel offers.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Hello Recently paid a visit to Ginza Bay Hotel in Tokyo. Since it was newly built in July 2015, a few months after, the Hotel is to be found very clean and veryattentive to needs. Also female floor vs. male floor is provided for safe stay. The lockers are a bit small, and had to keep luggage at desk, but besides getting stuffs and packing, it is pretty convenient. Also the better part is its only 2 blocks away from main Ginza area, which is great. Lots of ramun places in the area. And the best part is its connected to one train ride to shimbashi station from Narita Airport. So no transfer has left it a safe ride there and not bad of a ride payment of 1330 yen to the airport. The only thing was to check in after 3pm, yet they will keep bags until your check in so you can walk around the area before check in. The capsule was nice, cuz all i needed was sleep after walking the streets of Tokyo. The only thing was the foreign owner...he was attentive, but a bit creepy in ways too. Very strict, but guess thats what keeps place in shape. Also outside they have a foot bath, that gets drained each night, and refilled in every morning after 10am..which is warm water to wash your feet. Finally i have stayed in many hotels in Tokoy for the past 5 yrs or so, but bc it was newly built recently, it was the cleanest stay i have had vs. all business hotels. I definitely will stay here again when given chance.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: A place for one or two nights. If you want to try an unusual accommodation, this is the place.Rather unfamiliar way to spent a night for people from outside Japan. The philosophy behind a capsule hotel is the japanese way of dealing with things pragmatically : Work, eat, sleep, go back to work...The whole procedure in this capsule hotel is planned to details : Check in after 5pm on 3rd floor and get your capsule card. Take off your shoes and stow in a little locker, get houseshoes. Go on to changing area with bigger lockers. Use locker assigned to your capsule, e.g. capsule 200, locker 200. Inside you find a bag with towels, pyjamas (fits all sizes). Close locker with your own code. Go to your floor. Mens floor 2f without TV, floor 3f with TV, Dont go for floor 3f with TV, unless you speak Japanese because all TV channells are Japanese only. 4f reserved for female only (dont try, otherwise some bodyparts will be cut off (joke)). Try to sleep. Not recommended place if you are a light sleeper. Can become noisy all night, because guests come in, go out all night. Dont get a capsule near to bathroom, shower, toilet etc. Some people dont care, are loud and uses area all night thru. One more important subject : If you are suffering from long jetlag (8-9 hours), you will have a hard time in the capsule, counting minutes and trying to fall a sleep. Check out latest at 10am. Hotel/capsule can not beentered between 10am-5pm. Staying several nights means check in, check out the other day and check in again and so on..All in all a good bargain and good location.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I stayed four nights here on the ladies' floor, spread out over the beginning and end of my trip. My first two nights were in a capsule that was very far from the door of the room, but my last two nights were in two different capsules that were much closer to the room door. This can have a huge impact on the noise that you hear, as people come in and out of capsules until 2 am and start getting up around 6 am. If you are a light sleeper, ask for a capsule that is further from the door of each capsule room. The capsules themselves are extremely clean and relatively spacious. There are shoe lockers, lockers for you to store you belongings in and limited room to put a larger suitcase in (but you can put it at the front desk if the luggage locker is full). The showers, bathrooms, and powder rooms are bright and clean. I saw a staff member come by every few hours to clean the facilities in the evenings. It can be a bit of a pain to have to check out and check in every day, but basically don't bother unpacking much as they provide you pyjamas and toiletries. It is close to tsukiji, so if you want to catch the tuna auction before it moves, this is a great place to stay and roll out of bed at 2:00 am to guarantee a space at the auction. There is a little restaurant downstairs which is good in a pinch, although there are much better options if you walk around the neighbourhood.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Stayed for 1 night while in Tokyo, expecting to walk over to Tsujiki fish market in time for the tuna auction. Who'd expected it fills up well before 3am??Still this is a great place to stay. New and modern capsule hotel with amazing facilities. Lockers for your items, individual shower cubicles, coin operated laundry, drinks vending machines, alarm in the capsule, and comfortable capsules. The hotel is within walking distance of Ginza and Higashi-ginza metro stations. The capsule was spacious for me (1.7m at 60kg), and the lower bunk is probably more accessible. Only con, unless you understand Japanese, there probably isn't a need to shell out extra for the TV. Light sleepers would probably want to pick up a pair of ear buds from the counter upon check in ;) Do note that if you stay more than one night, you would have to check out by 10am, then check in again after 5pm, as with most capsule hotels.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: More expensive than most capsule hotels but a bargain for the area. Close to the main streets of Ginza.New as big July 2015 so very clean. Individual showers for those who prefer privacy. Most capsule hotels have shared bathing areas.Added bonus that there is a women's floor. They area rarePaid 4700 yen.If I had one complaint is that the capsules were too warm. The cool air didn't make it in with the shutter closed.
hotelName:
21    Tokyo Ginza Bay Hotel
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: This hostel seemed great--clean bathrooms, great location, has a nice rooftop, nice rooms, great price,etc. I stayed here for just one night. I slept on the second floor on a lower bunk. I felt comfortable except I woke up twice in the middle of the night very itchy but I didn't think much of it. The next morning I flicked a small, circular brown bug off my mattress (it was very easy to spot, as the sheets and blankets were all white). I continued to be itchy all day and then hours later I finally looked in the mirror.......after searching on google seems like bed bugs to me?!?! Although I've never had them before so I can't be 100% sure
hotelName:
22    Samurai Hostel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The Asakusa district is the best, so you'll be glad to have a place to stay there. This hostel is very well located in it. It has a bath, a bar, good beds and a well secured keycard system. Plus, the staff is really nice. I'll definitely go back here!
hotelName:
22    Samurai Hostel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: currently staying in this hostel. it's located very close (within minutes) to Nakamise and Sensoji temple. it is a 5 min walk to asakusa station. staff are very helpful and always willing to find answers for your questions. capsules are clean and adequate. they will wash your sheets everyday but you have to request. they have a bath on the 6th floor.
hotelName:
22    Samurai Hostel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Place is awesome as the laundry room is just outside and there is even a prayer room. Daily cleaning so the toilet is always clean! Bed was bigger than what I was expecting and the place is convenient! It's near the sensoji temple and there's a lot of eatery near the hostel! The hostel itself serve food which is Muslim friendly and vegan friendly!
hotelName:
22    Samurai Hostel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I spent 9 days in early of October 2018 stay in this hostel.Got a bunk bed for 2 persons in mix dormitory room.Herewith my experience stay at this hostel : - Location near Asakusa Tokyo metro station, just 5 minute walk- You can reach this hostel, by Keisei direct to Asakusa station for only about 1200 yen (it is so important that you dont have to spent much money from and to airport), get exit 5/6 on Asakusa station, and just 5 min walk- Mix dormitory room is completed with bathroom and toilet, so you don't have to go downstairs or upstairs for take a bath or pee.- The bathroom was equipped with hairdryer, also liquid soap and shampo. You can get the towel also in receptionist.- The hostel also have elevator, so you don't have to bring your heavy luggage by stairs for up and down to the reception area.- The receptionist was very helpfull and kind, they allow us to check in on 11 am, that we supposed to be check in on 2 pm.- Kitchen available 24 hours, so u can simply cook or warm your food even late night.- There was washing machine in 2nd floor and 4th Floor if I'm not mistaken, just pay for 300 yen for washing machine and 100 yen for drying machine, so you don't need to bring dirty clothes if you want to move to other city in Japan.- The room rate is consider cheap with all of the facility- This is very important, that if you're moslem, there are many halal food near the hostel, we eat Matsuya for beef bowl and along of Nakamise street there was a lot of street food! There are also giant Don Quijote near the hostel to buy Japanese snacks and Masumoto Kiyoshi to shop Japanese cosmetic.Overall it is a pleasant stay in this hostel, thank you Samurai hostel.It make my Japan trip so delightfull!I will surely recommend this hostel to my friends and family.Keep up the good work and hospitality!
hotelName:
22    Samurai Hostel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Arriving at Enaka Asakusa Hostel the one thing that stood out was the staff! We arrived a little early at 8am (Check-in is at 4pm) off the night bus and welcomed by the girls behind the desk. They were very friendly and hospitable. The accommodation is very clean, the beds are comfortable. Just bring ear plugs as the dorms can get loud!
hotelName:
22    Samurai Hostel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I checked in last July 30, 2018. The location of the hostel is ideal for those who have a food tour and shopping on their itinerary. The staff is very nice and welcoming! They told me about the Sumidagawa Festival. The bed is clean and comfy. The key and lock system is good. The shower area is big and the toilet is on a separate room.The common area has a comfy and homey feeling.What I really like is the roof deck, you'll get a lovely view of the Tokyo Skytree!
hotelName:
22    Samurai Hostel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I stayed in this hostel for 5 nights and everything was really well. The capsule is spacious and totally clean. The receptionists were friendly and accommodating. In terms of proximity, it's 3-5 mins walk to Sensoji Temple as well as to Ginza Line Asakusa station.
hotelName:
22    Samurai Hostel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The capsules were quite large and very comfy. You can sit up in them, there is good light, and even a cupboard to store you things in with a key.The staff was amazingly friendly! No extra late-check in fee and just super service.The hotel had a very friendly and safe atmosphere, very nice, a much better than what I had expected for a visit to a capsule hotel^^
hotelName:
22    Samurai Hostel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The hotel is very clean. Everyone has to put their shoes in the locker before enter the dorm area. I like the lock in front of the capsule so I can lock my luggage and sleep without worrying. Inside the capsule is a comfy mattress, small cabinet and little panel that can place I-Pad or book.
hotelName:
22    Samurai Hostel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: First time visiting Japan, and Enaka was 1 of 5 hotels I stayed in during my visit. I have to say it was my favorite. It felt very family oriented, the employees were very kind and helpful. It's located close to train stations and there's a really cool market a 2 minute walk away that really thrives on the weekends. The whole environment of the area just feels so unique.The beds and pillows are comfy enough, the bathroom and showers are clean. Unlike other capsules I stayed in, your locker is located in your bed and your luggage gets locked up at the foot of your bed. Which I liked alot, other places have them in a separate room which is just inconvenient. One thing that really sets Enaka apart from other capsules is that you don't have to check out if you're a staying multiple days. Other hotels make you leave at 10am and you can't come back for several hours. Which creates a shower rush in the morning and lots of noise. At Enaka you're free to come and go as you like. The common room is also really awesome. Its a great spot to meet people and hang out at. They have beer and mixed drinks for sale at cheap prices too.You'll love staying here if you want the capsule experience. 10/10!
hotelName:
22    Samurai Hostel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: If you are planning to stay in asakusa, this will be a good place for you. It is conveniently located to the tourist attractions, friendly staffs, very clean and nice interiors. There is a lift in the hostel, so you do not have to worry about carrying your luggage up and down. In the dormitory, there is also a chain for us to secure our luggage. I personally like the interiors of the hostel- Clean, modern and new. Highly recommended!
hotelName:
22    Samurai Hostel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object
