With the option of having free breakfast, bike rental, or gym time.It may be a bit far from Tokyo proper, but with the train station less than a minute’s walk away the distance is not an inconvenience at all.Even the other guests are friendly, from every corner of the globe. They’ve created a very cozy environment indeed. Will definitely come back to explore the neighborhood. It has its own attractions and charm.Thank you Emblem staff and shout out to Sunny, one of the friendly faces you’ll see there!Arigatougozaimasu!
hotelName:
24    Emblem Hostel Nishiarai
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We stayed in Emblem hostel for 6 nights. Staff was absolutely fantastic. Our room was nice and clean but It had an emergency light impossible to turn off even at night which was very annoying. Hostel was clean but It could Have been better. Paper towels by the sink would do wonders. Otherwise there were hair and lots of water all the time. Also the smell was not nice Especially in corridors. It felt like No one has opened a window in weeks. As the breakfast was rather poor we decided to do grocery shopping in the store next door and Have It in the Kitchen/common room. It lacks few basic items like toaster Or table So having breakfast was uncomfortable. There is only one fridge and There are loads of people staying in Emblem hostel. Our stay was rather pleasant but with such good reviews i expected more. Right before our stay in Tokio we Stayed at hostel in Kyoto which was absolutely fantastic and I cant compare Emblem hostel to the one in Kyoto. Many people complain about the location. You know What You get. It is Good value for money. 40-60min from Shibuya Or Shinjuku but very close to subway station which is a great asset.
hotelName:
24    Emblem Hostel Nishiarai
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Stayed here for 7 nights and we were very happy! The pod beds are comfortable and cozy, however I would buy another pillow if I'm going back cuz that thing was rock hard. The breakfast is OK for the money they charge you, but there's a french bakery at the station that has way better food. The whole place is very clean and the staff is really helpful in an otherwise hard country to navigate in! They have tons of stuff you can do and there's always people there. Would definetely come back, the money is 100% worth it!
hotelName:
24    Emblem Hostel Nishiarai
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Clean places and friendly staff. I wonder there does not have any room service such as changing curtain for my bed for days. Next to the bed, there is a sound of electric current from the socket that I have to move away from it further so that I can have a quiet environment. It is interesting that there are many from Europe, American and Italy etc but very few of Asian.Overall, it is great to stay.
hotelName:
24    Emblem Hostel Nishiarai
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Wonderfully kind service from the front staff. Extremely clean rooms and washrooms especially !!! Very good experience and the staff makes an effort for people to have a social experience. Only thing to note would be travel time as it is about 50 mins to the city centre.
hotelName:
24    Emblem Hostel Nishiarai
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: This hostel is definitely one of the best that I have ever stayed in so far. Everybody is extremely friendly and helpful, gym is just next door which is convenient and even the distance to the main points isn’t an issue as the metro station is 1min walking and the connections are super efficient. The only thing this hostel needs to improve is definitely the variety in the cafeteria. The burgers are super delicious but definitely they must have more variety with different stuff and also they don’t serve anything between 9:30-11:30 (including coffee). In a hostel people wake up a bit later (not on time to make the 9:30 journey) so it would be good to have a coffee anytime. Anyway there is a supermarket nearby. Apart of that I highly recommend to stay there. Very clean and modern.
hotelName:
24    Emblem Hostel Nishiarai
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The Emblem Hostel was hands down the best hostel I have ever stayed at. It is super clean and the rooms are very spacious. The staff was very friendly and helpful. The bar and eating area is also very nice. I highly recommend this hostel.
hotelName:
24    Emblem Hostel Nishiarai
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: This hotel is walkable from Shinjuku station despite how large the station is and its numerous exits.The room was based in the south tower and was spacious with a decent size bathroom which included a shower/bath and the wizz-bang Japanese toilet. Outside the bathroom was a small wash basin and wardrobe which contained the room safe.The bed was large for a double and very comfortable. The room also included a couch and work desk.My room overlooked the Tokyo metropolitan building which is across the street.Location wise, Shinjuku station is a 10 minute walk away and Omoide Yokocho, Kabukicho, and Shinjuku Golden-Gai are close by as well. Restaurant wise, I only ate breakfast at Jurin Restaurant which was predominantly western buffet style restaurant with some Japanese and Asian options. The food was outstanding with a wide variety of hot and cold dishes, pastries, salads and cold cuts of meat. It was surreal one morning when a minor earthquake hit Tokyo (the floating floors dimmed the impact of it). The Main Bar was the only place I experienced a drink at the hotel and the bar staff were exceptional.Location wise, there is plenty of dining options at the hotel or in the local area, plus the joys of Shinjuku are all in a walkable distance (10-20 minutes) depending upon where you want to go to.
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: My two teenage boys and husband stayed at this hotel recently on the grand premier floors with access to the club lounge and concierge services. It was so amazing! The customer service was really good and we especially loved using the club lounge for breakfast and afternoon cocktails. It really added a luxury element to the trip. The hotel room was very pretty, albeit a bit small. We would’ve stayed regardless because of the club lounge. We also really liked the location which was right near Shinjuku station giving us easy access to get to places throughout the city.
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The manner of the front desk staffs was terrible, bad services, , the hotel is old , noisy, unstable air condition , I need to wait half hr to wait to fix it , it’s expensive, still need to take walk at lease 10 -15 minutes to the shopping area , I will never choose this hotel again!
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We got a good deal on a room at Keio Plaza. This hotel is in a great location because you don’t deal with all the noise of Shinjuku as this is about a half mile from Shinjuku station where all the activity is. Had a blast, great hotel service and super friendly staff. They went above and beyond to make sure that we were comfortable.Additionally, a lot of the tours, which save you a ton of time and allow you to see way more than you would be able on your own, leave from the lobby.
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Stayed at Keio Palza Tokyo in June and we enjoyed every moment in this wonderful hotel. The location of Keio hotel is just near to Shinjuku Station. I landed in the evening in Tokyo Narita Airport and took a very simple and easy train Narita Express from Narita airport to Shinjuku Station. In Shinjuku take the west exit and follow the Gouverment Building sign. The easiest way to find Keio Hotel is to look for pillar with “D” letter. When you find D60 in the left is Keio Plaza Hotel.The check in was completely Japanese (very gracious and very fast) and I was pleasantly surprised at the size of the room as I had heard all rooms in Tokyo were very small.The staff are friendly and helpful in every way. The room was bright, well decorated and had some fantastic details, not only the usual toiletries with a large assortment of toiletries (hotel supply an elastic hair band HOW COOL IS THAT) but shoe shining cloths, power adaptors, supply of mineral water every day and a wonderful Japanese toilet with heated seat. I would love one of those at home! Beds and pillows were very comfortable.Very rich breakfast in 2 different styles Japanese and Western style. I tried every day some Japanese cuisines and it is very good. Udon and soup of day are two best thing I have at breakfast. Also the algae are something unusual to eat.One of the amenities in the room is the free use of a smart phone with internet. Phone is located in the room on the desk. There is free Internet on it and Google Map was very helpful in big city of Tokyo. Phone will ask for a departure date and later tell you that it will erase all personal data after date you check out. Everything was in English. Free use of a smart phone is definitely a plus.I would like to thank to all of the staff from Keio for making as an enjoyable stay, and a special thanks to Ayaka Hagi and Shingo Kobori for helping me.Keio Plaza Hotel makes a great landing pad for our first Tokyo visit. I would definitely stay again when I return. Hope to see you soon.美しくありがとう
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We booked a triple room on an Amex platinum discount, having 1 free night for every 3 nights booked. Upon arrival, we were given non-renovated rooms in the old South Tower. Room was old, small, dusty (I couldn't stop sneezing everytime I'm in the room, which was quite abit given I try to sleep 8 hours a night) and dingy. Nothing at all like what I saw on websites and most photos posted by other travellers who got the renovated rooms. Perhaps these are non-promo full price paying guests. Toiletries were also not the Loccitane ones as advertised in many photos. When I enquired, I wasn't given a satisfactory response. The bell girl who was helping me with the enquiries was however pleasant and tried her best to help.Check in time was not at all flexible with many guests waiting in the lobby for 3pm. I was carrying a newborn who was fussy after a 8 hour flight and it was not at all fun standing in a lobby with a screaming baby.At check out, I asked an old gentleman (who looked like the manager of the bell counter) for help with the vending machine to buy bus tickets. He looked at me and ignored me, walking off mumbling... I was shocked. Also, I had to do some repacking and weighing of my luggage (carried away shopping) and was very happy to hassle with the carrying of luggage in and out of behind the counter (with a newborn strapped to me). However when a male white guy came, the old gentleman bell boy manager of some sort very quickly carried the weighing scale out for him unprompted! Goodness... I then sat and observed his behavior to other guests and noted similar trends. Unkind to anything other than white males...Not a hotel id recommend at all. There are many other more decent options in the area like Hyatt.
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: New property, room was top the line up-dated, great Wi-Fi, front desk very helpful and friendly and they speak English. Great location 5 minutes walk distance from train station and Kyoto Tower, lots of shopping, shrines, places to eat. Loved Kyoto + Loved this hotel
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Its a huge hotel in Shinjuku. We got a Club room and the room’s spacious and clean. Its a short walk to the restaurant strip in Shinjuku and a 10-min walk to Shinjuku station. The lounge is a bit plain and basic but offers a great view of the city. Staff are nice. We booked the Mt Fuji tour and the meeting place was in this hotel, very convenient!
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We stayed here twice. Our first room was in the South Tower. The room needed a renovation and the carpet was dirty. The view was spectacular. We had a view of Mt. Fuji. Our 2nd stay was a few days later. We had a room in the main tower. The room was clean and updated. We had an ironing board/iron, L’Occitane shampoos and soaps, an air purifier, nicer towels, robes and slippers. Our view wasn’t as nice but the room definitely was nicer than the South Tower. If you can book a room with breakfast, the Glass Court buffet is worth it. Great selection of foods. The hotel is convenient to a lot of restaurants and a few blocks from the train station. There is a bus that takes you to Disneyland and Disney Sea. Reserve seats early and be certain about return times. They don’t allow you to take an earlier bus back to the hotel if you’re tired and didn’t book that exact time. The airport limousine bus stops at the hotel. We had a super early flight. The bus pick up didn’t work for us. We ended up paying $300 for a taxi. We could’ve taken the train but the times didn’t work for us either.
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Firstly I must say that the hotel was excellent in responding to my emails and got back to me with very good detailed information and got back very quickly. I was disappointed when we checked in by the person who checked us in. They were the only ones who seemed not very friendly. The first impression is a lasting one. The concierge was So Very Helpful in helping us plan our activities. The location is good and we walked to and from the train station. We thought the breakfast was way too expensive but we just ate at the train station and there is a lot of variety there. We had a nice view from our room.
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I stayed at Keio Plaza for 3 nights at the end of my trip in Japan. I arrived to Shinjuku Station around 7pm on a Friday and it was very very busy. After I felt like I was walking around in circles in order to find my correct direction, I realized how close this hotel really was to lots of sights and transportation options. There’s a very busy couple blocks of restaurants/stores which was daunting to walk through solo at night but I quickly got over that. Check in at Keio was easy and my room was clean. I can’t remember if I was in the Main or South tower but I was pleased with the accommodations. Word to those who want to use their airport shuttle...book upon your arrival! I didn’t think the 6:15 AM shuttle on a Monday AM to Haneda would be booked but it was for me! I ended up having to take an earlier one to play it safe...oh well. Happy to answer questions!
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Location was central in Shinjuku area. Underground access to subway was within short walk from hotel. Direct airport limousine stop with complimentary Disney resort shuttle for hotel guests.Check in and check out service were swift. Service was prompt but at times a little stern.Had a family room with 4 beds and 2 toilets at main tower. Very suitable for families with kids in tow.
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Stayed quite a few times here In the past if you book yourself not as a group then you pay more but get good rooms If in a group the standard rooms are quite small and you hear your next door neighbour in the shower or watching tv the sound just carries Be aware of checking in 1500policy not before We had an event that started at 1400 being held at the hotel for 160 people followed the next day with another event in house still no early check in at 1330after arriving at 1230 from Korea I think if you are doing major events over 2 days a bit of flex would help especially when checking out at 6 in the morning on departure date
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We had the superior south triple room. It’s very new even with 3 beds, it’s spacious. Check in was fast. It was so easy to book the airport limo at the bell counter at the lobby. located around 7mins walk from Shinjuku Station, it maybe a little confusing to walk from underground.
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Location of the hotel is not that close to the Railways depends on where you are going. Room was not clean at all, hairs were everywhere inside the bathroom and dirts were found on curtain when checking in. Apart from the Lady checked us in was good, other staff was unhelpful and rude. The wheel of my suitcase was damaged, I asked some help from Information Counter, the western guy just showed me somewhere on a map with a building‘s name but without specify the shop’s name, do you expect your client to carry a big suitcase hanging around the city to find an uncertain place for fixing the suitcase. You need to log in the hotel WiFi every time when you return to hotel! Lastly just required half an hour or one more hour of extension on departure, the aged man at the Information Counter just replied you “can not, it’s a charge”with a cool face! I understood that it might be your hotel policy but would you please reply in a courtesy manner. I do not expect such experiences would happen in a hotel with a star! It was my first time stayed in this hotel and also it would be the last time too! You can have a lot of choices on hotel selection if under this price! I absolutely will not recommend to any of my friends!
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: This was my second business trip to Tokyo and my first stay in this hotel. At first I wasn't sure if it was a good idea to switch from my previous experience (Hilton) which was excellent. After staying there for 6 nights I can say confidently that it was a very pleasant experience. The only take was one day where I had to wait to get have my breakfast. Other than that...don't hesitate. Excellent location and excellent service.
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We stayed 3 nights at the Hotel Keio plaza in order to take in the Sumo Championships and had a very pleasurable experience. The hotel was spotless throughout and all staff were extremely smart and so polite and helpful. The public areas are very spacious and beautifully furnished.Our room was large and very well equipped with toiletries and had 2 types of beautiful robes for us to relax in. Like all other hotels that we stayed in, there were no little milks for Western tea-crema was available but how vile is that? However I did get used to drinking roasted tea as it came-still trying to like green tea!!Breakfast:- There was an extensive choice of either Japanese or Western food, and you could eat in any of 3 restaurants (2 western/Japanese and 1 Japanese). My only complaint which seemed to apply to every hotel that we stayed in on the tour was that the western hot choices (sausage and bacon) were luke warm and we English do like our food hot!!! The hotel has its own bakery and so not surprisingly pastries and bed were extremely good.We thought the location was great-only a short distance from the train station and from restaurants and shops in the City-also very safe to walk about.There were some lovely shops within the hotel and a very handy supermarket on ground level which stops open long hours-perfect for getting food if you've had a long day and need something to munch on or to get a drink.All in all, a really pleasant experience and I would recommend this hotel without hesitation.I cant say if this is a mid range or luxury hotel as the costs were paid for by the tour company.
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: 1. A lady named Ishikawa at the club lounge helped us a lot in terms of arranging bookings, giving directions, free pamphlets. She was extremely polite and helpful. She planned our entire route to Hakone as well. A special thanks to her.2. Walking distance to shinjuku station near by.3. Rooms were huge with bose speakers, tablet, handy smart phone.4. Great snacks and drinks were always kept at the club lounge for refreshment.5. We had a choice of breakfast at 3 restaurants, the club lounge on 45th floor, Jurin & Glass Court.6. Walking distance to a lot of eatery places, Keio department store, Bic camera, Yodobashi camera, Isetan mall, Uniqlo, Odakyu department store, Odakyu line to travel to Hakone, OIOI department store, Daiso, Government Metropolitan building.7. Airport limosine bus stops right in the gate of the hotel and the bell girls, yes there are bell girls who will help with the luggages.7. Smooth check in and check out in the club lounge.8. Vegetarian dinner was good at the Jurin. They had silver cutlery.9. Luggage had arrived in our room b4 we checked in. It was transfered from Kyoto.10. Blackout curtains were an added bonus for a peaceful sleep.
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Stayed for 4 nights, first time in Tokyo. Nice hotel in good location. Easy to get to from Shinjuku station. It wasn't cheap, but you get good value. Our room was large and well appointed. Everything you needed was there. Would stay there again.
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We stayed for just a couple of nightsand I think it is overly priced. The bathroom fixture has an old design and some black spots are seen in some of its corners. We took a triple sharing room and need to rearrange the furniture to have better mobility around the room and because it was blocking the way to the door. We stayed at this hotel for several times but we were never greeted ‘welcome back.’ Though the staff is very helpful and the location is near Shinjuku station.
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Let me qualify my review. First, this is the second time I stay at this hotel, 11 years apart. Second, I reserved a Premier Grand room. Shinjuku is the place to stay in Tokyo as it is the center of all activities: subway, restaurants, shops, entertainment, etc. The rooms are big considering it is Tokyo and they are amazing in terms of the use of space. Make sure to open all the drawers in the room as they contain pyjamas, robes, amenities, iron, safe, slippers, etc. The toilet (closet) door as I would call it opens automatically and the toilet/bidet gets ready for use which is great but somehow annoying to anyone else sleeping in the room. The service is impeccable from the time you arrive till you leave. The breakfast at the Club Level is superb and the service very attentive. As for the restaurants, we did not use them as I remember a Kobe beef dinner 11 years before that cost me 250$ per person: still the same price today. You can step just out of the hotel to a horde of restaurants at very reasonable prices.A piece of advice: become a club member (free) """"before""""" you reserve. The savings are great.
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: A previous visit to Tokyo involved staying in two hotels with microscopic bedrooms so it was pleasing to appreciate a decent sized room.Our room (1210) on floor twelve was clean and comfortable with bright colours and a reasonable size bathroom.It is a massive hotel complex so do not expect great personal service but it is only a short walk from the impressive Shinjuku station and there are a myriad of eateries in the vicinity.Breakfast is a very good choice of both Western and Japanese options but it can get very busy so worth arriving early for. We also had a late evening snack in the all day dining restaurant which was also very good.We would certainly stay here again if in this part of Tokyo.
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We stayed at Keio Plaza Shinjuku in 2015 and 2017 and were quite happy with it. This year (May 2019) we booked the same 33 square meter room in the North tower.Gone were the L'Occitane products. The great mattresses had been replaced with inferior, thin, too-soft mattresses. What used to be the wonderfully fluffy, absorbent towels were now coarse, older towels. The room cleaning this time was also not up to an acceptable standard.This hotel has a great location, with Tochomae Station our "jumping off point" for the Tokyo subway system. However, we cannot see ourselves at Keio again for our next holiday in Tokyo. We are at a loss why the huge downturn in quality! The price was the same as prior years, averaging just slightly more than ¥30,000 per night (over our 7 night stay).VERY DISAPPOINTING!
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: There are a lot of hotels in Shinjuku. Some people would like to stay closer to JR station, some people would like to stay closer to Kabukicho. My personal choice is making balance between good location and spacious room. So I try Keio Plaza Hote this time. I have to walk about 8-10mins from JR station to the hotel. You can choose to take airport limousine directly to hotel from Haneda or Narita Airport. I booked a larger newly refurbished room as size is 35sqm (it’s quite spacious room in most Tokyo hotels). The room is located at 29/F but the view is not that good as there are quite a lot high rise buildings around (you can see the room view picture I uploaded). The lobby is large and grand but not a modern stylish type. The check in process is smooth. The reception man provided basic smile and information that I needed to know eg the breakfast restaurants, Wi-Fi, checkout time etc. Once entered to the room, the decoration is the same as shown on trip advisor. It’s clean and tidy as most of Tokyo hotels. The room provided bottled water and instant green tea and coffee packs. There is a multi charger for use. The bathroom is good and quite spacious so that you can take a good bath then enjoy self made onsen to relieve your tired body after shopping or walking for a whole day. The toilettes are from L'OCCITANE. The brand is good with refreshing lemon smell but it will not give you bubbly feel after apply on the body (I personally do not prefer this type of shower gel). There is a tiny cube of bath salt provided for bath. Bed and pillow are ok to me and I don’t have any compliant about it. After sleep, the most important is breakfast. My wife is very picky about the hotel’s breakfast. There are 3 restaurants you can choose. One is American style, one is Japanese style and the last one is mixed buffet style. Surely, we choose the western-Japanese buffet breakfast. You may need to queue outside the restaurants for a short while as it’s quite busy. The variety of food is ok, there are 2-3 cold cuts, 2-3 simple cheese, 6-8 types of danish or bread, Japanese rice, udon, miso soap, Japanese fish, omelet, fruits, salad. It’s ok but not surprising. The quality of food is up to standard, not bad but not the best. I need a cup of good coffee but the coffee provide is too acidic and I like coffee which is strong and nutty. May be most of the coffee in Japan is relatively weak and easy. There is swimming pool and gym room in the hotel. But I am busy in shopping and sightseeing, so I really don’t have time to try the gym room for 3 nights stay. Tokyo is big! Shinjuku is the main place to go shopping and eating. If you don’t like shopping, you can choose to stay in other places. I do recommend Keio plaza hotel Shinjuku but please book a larger newly refurbished room.
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Hotel was arranged by our tour operator, gate 1 travel. Very nice and super clean hotel. Many restaurants and amenities within the hotel. Very close to other points of interests in Tokyo Courteous and efficient staff. Tour operator was well organized and also has a desk within the hotel
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I visited this hotel in April, and again in May.Keio Plaza will definitely be “home” when I arrive in Tokyo. The stay in May was at the end of visit in Japan, and I cannot think of a better place to spend the last night before a long journey home.Located in a an area close to shopping, transportation, and a park close by. Several restraints, an art gallery, and a very well stocked gift store.There are three restaurants open for buffet breakfast. Really nice to start your morning. A newspaper is left at your door each morning. Many elevators to move you between floors. Nicely decorated comfortable rooms.So many extras in the rooms. If you forgot your toothbrush or comb-no need to worry. The shower products were really nice quality. Very comfortable beds.I will be making this my hotel of choice when visiting Tokyo.
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: A first class hotel with excellent service. Very useful smart phone mobile WI-FI they encourage you to take with you around the city. Restaurant options were a little pricey. The location was great for exploring Shijuko
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Good hotel Maybe the rooms were small but they had tea in the rooms.The result!Save money easily with !: maxdeals.mlI liked the fact that they were providing a news sheet for each room. Also good, it is close to the Uniqlo store, Starbucks and MacDonald's
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Very good location, easy access to train station. Friendly front desk and guest relation. Bus tour meeting point. Need to login WIFI every day. Not good value. Breakfast at Level 2 is better than level 42. Long queue after 8am. Will try different hotel in next trip.
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: the rooms are big and the service is truly exceptional! we left our items out, which i wouldnt recommend and the cleaner put them in the safe for us, lever her code and asking us to change it once we arrived. loved it!
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Unfortunately Gate 1 tours does not get the best rooms for their customers. None of the ones on the website look like our dated 1970s room. I tried to upgrade to the executive lounge privileges with same room and was told that’s non-allowable. However they are selling executive lounge rooms on the website. When is staying at the Hilton nearby, if you wanted executive lounge privileges, you could pay for it with a 5000 Japanese yen upgrade.
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I stayed at Keio Plaza for 9 nights in April. Check in was fine; room was clean and kept clean all week. Staff accommodating and spoke English. We ate at Jurin Restaurant and the Skye Bar and also had room service. The prices are high compared to what you pay to eat in town; however, it's a different dining experience. The food, however, was good.Convenient complementary bus service to Tokyo Disney which we used, and Sunrise Tours has a desk in the hotel and the trips leave from there.Subway/train station a few blocks away and on the other side of the station is nightlife.Would definitely stay again.
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Good quality typical 4 star hotel. Very big well organised, excellent staff. Rooms are well appointed with bath.kettle and safe. About £2oo per night.Typical buffet breakfasts with 3 dinning rooms to choose from.one being Japanese which I did not try.Bell boy system was exceptional.Handy for the town and station, a few minutes walk away Tokio is a vast concrete jungle with not that much on offer, subway & rail system to tax the mind in getting about. Its all rolled in with Yokohama having a population of 26 million people, Houses are squeezed in between the many skyscrapers. Traffic seemed light by London standards but apparently moring is very expensive.its all very expensive by UK standards especially ladies shoes, Expect to pay £10 for a couple of coffees and a cake.
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: With 1440 rooms you'd expect to be permanently squeezed but, other than the lifts early on a weekend day, this does not happen. Even then the activity is not too constricting. Just busy. Squeezy.The counter staff are efficient and courteous. The Guest Relations/ Duty Manager's desk even more so. The rooms are spotless and more than adequate at a reasonable price. Breakfasts in a choice of one of four restaurants is outstanding. A well managed but not overly long queue signals weekends. We chose to eat in the light,bright Jurin garden restaurant and loved itLate check outs are available for about $25 an hour in two hour blocks. There is an efficient and regular one hour coach service to Haneda Airport at a fraction of the taxi cost.There are good little eating places within a five minute walk and on the other side of the hotel is the Government Building with free access to the viewing platform on Level 41. We didn't even dare enter Shinjuku Railway Station which has over 60 access points and millions of travellers every day.The only issue we had was WiFi which is reset by the hotel at midday every day. For us, techno dummies, that meant a daily trek down to the desk to have 2 ipads reset. On occasions it was fast but not always. At booking time, many weeks ahead, we had to push to be guaranteed a non smoking room.Whilst Japanese courtesy is well known this hotel takes it to new highs. They really mean it.
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Keio Plaza Hotel is a very huge hotel in great location. Since it is a big hotel, the lobby is always busy. Also, there was a line for the Super Breakfast buffet at 8AM. We booked a room above 20 floor in the South Wing. It was worth the money. Every morning during our stay, Mt Fuji showed with her snow capped cone. The size of our room was big enough for the three of us. Staff service was excellent.
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: we booked this hotel for the conceige services as it is very hard to book restaurants in Japan. every inquiry took two days to get back that I got so frustrated and called from new York to follow up on my reservations. someone from the club lounge conceirge told me to wait as they will email me the reply while I was on the phone. I snapped! I had to ask them to tell me the answer over the phone if I did or not get any reservations. I voiced my frustration and concern- guess what no answer! not even apologising- I do not recommend this hotel! poor customer service!!!!!!!
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I stayed on two different nights in the same week. The rooms were both described as Twin Superior but on my second stay I was informed at check-in that it was a renovated. It was much nicer. The bathroom was a big step up from the unrenovated one. The hotel is located very close to Shinjuku Station so it is a great spot. The staff are very efficient and polite. The breakfast buffet quite expansive and very good.
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: My first impression of this hotel was over- crowded and too many tour guests staying; however, underneath it all, the guests do their tour early in the morning, just like rush hour, and it is an interesting sight. This is not a bother at all.Receptionists all work like robots, and very professionals ( i mean it in a good way). There are trash cans in the lobby, which make us very difficult to throw any trash sometimes that are laying around the sofa from previous guests.Our first stay was in the South tower for three nights, and I highly prefer the triple room here. It is much spacious and has an extra sink in the powder room. Our second stay here was in the Annex tower, which is an older room, smaller, and not as fresh smell . Actually, it is a twin room, but they added an extra bed. (You see the difference?)What I love about this hotel:1. They provide an extension outlet for charging.2. Located nearby pharmacies, coffee shops, Family mart, restaurants, and karaoke places.3. They cater to quick check-out counters.4. Excellent breakfast choices.I would certainly stay here again for next trip to Tokyo. There are so many things going on around this hotel.
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I booked Keio Hotel based on many positive reviews on TripAdvisor. And my experience told me I was definitely wrong. I should stay away from this hotel.First of all, the staff is not professional. My family (2 adults and 2 kids) got into the lobby with 4 big pieces of luggage. Interestingly, the staff was just standing there and did nothing. Regarding the service at the check-in counter, what I could feel is that this hotel should NOT be rated 4/5 stars. Cold and work without enthusiasm. All the staff should be trained again. Upon seeing our rooms, I was definitely sure that the hotel should NOT be rated 4/5 stars. The room was dusty and the bathroom was ancient. Buffet breakfast was another disaster. I saw a waiter yelling at another Italian guest and poor and limited variety of food. Eventually, we went to Starbucks in the next day morning. Location is the only selling point for this hotel. Because of this ONE and ONLY ONE advantage, they don't have to worry about business and they don't need to provide necessary service to their customers.
hotelName:
25    Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We had a really nice and spacious room 902. Nice terace with a view. Staff at reception was really friendly and helpfull. Excellent location near senso-ji. Only minus; the breakfast. There are 3 choices none of them can pass for a healthy breakfast. We tried it once and went out for breakfast the other mornings. Kitchen staff wasn’t really helpfull to accomodate any minor request. My husband had a runny egg and asked for toast with ir (the standard combi). Only feedback de got ‘we don’t have toast’ (yet one of the menus is french toast so....). On the question ‘can I get a soy latte?’ First quick reply ‘that will cost extra ‘ (even though I opted for the french toast breakfast which is significantly cheaper than the other 2bbreakfasts). Then ‘we have no soy milk’.
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We were extremely pleased with our stay at Wired Hotel. We stayed in one fo the rooms near the top floor - a great decision. Plenty of room, balcony and super comfy bed. Loved the decor and gowns. My only quibble (and it is with most hotels in Japan) is the terrible waste associated with the bathroom amenities. I was hoping that a modern boutique hotel would also incorporate less wasteful products, such as I see now in many other similar chic hotels. Maybe a thought for the future? Lead the way Wired Hotel, as you do so well in many other areas and perhaps give us some options to ditch those little wasteful bottles! I still have a 5 star rating as I realise that it is also up to us, as travellers, to be involved in making a difference, not just the hotel owners. Oh and what a shame that Trip Advisor asks us to rate a hotel according to whether plastic water bottles are offered in our rooms!But a fabulous stay in every other way and Asakusa is a perfect area to have as a base with so many eating options nearby and the lovely temple and gardens.
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Wired Hotel in the Asakusa district of Tokyo is a modern, funky boutique style hotel with excellent, English-speaking staff and spotlessly clean facilities. Our room even had a B&O bluetooth speaker so we could stream music from our phones. Nice touch. The location is excellent, within a short walk of the famous Senso-ji temple, which itself is surrounded by dozens of interesting restaurants. On the negative side, we found the leather sling chairs in the room horribly uncomfortable and almost impossible to sit in. This furniture choice looked like an example of putting style above function. The Japanese breakfast served in the hotel’s small restaurant was excellent, but the high cost of a second cup of coffee was a bummer. We enjoyed our stay at Wired and it would have been even better if the room’s chairs had been good and that second coffee free.
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Unusual concept for a hotel - dormitories on the lower floors, nice rooms further up, deluxe rooms with balcony near the top. We had a deluxe room - view was nothing special ( rooftops) but we could see the Senso-ji temple which was great. Our balcony had a very healthy crop of rosemary growing in a pot. Reception was very helpful. And the cafe is pretty good too - limited menu but you can order a western breakfast. Plenty of restaurants nearby. In fact, the hotel is situated in a great old area - very lively and atmospheric and old buildings ( although a few new hideous tower blocks detract from the beauty).
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Clean, modern hotel with lovely staff. This hotel was perfect for our stay, apart from Asakusa did feel quite far out of the city. It felt as though the hotel thought of every tiny details to make your stay enjoyable. Comfortable beds, great maid service and helpful staff. Would highly recommend for anybody looking to stay in the East side of Tokyo.
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We had a wonderful stay in Wired! Our junior suite had sweeping views of the surrounding Asakusa area (including Skytree) from our cute little terrace. We really loved our room, which had ample space for the four of us, and the warm ambiance. We also appreciate the range and quality of the amenities provided in the room. The attention to detail was amazing: they had hand written guides for the area and the room was super chic but cozy. The surrounding area was fun to explore, lots of cute small shops and old F&B establishments. They also showed us one of the rooms with a view of the Skytree and Sensoji temple from the bathroom. You do need to walk quite a bit from the station, but it’s an enjoyable walk through the temple area and its surrounding neighborhood. Overall we would highly recommend Wired for anyone looking to stay in the Asakusa area, and we’re looking forward to our next visit.
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Stayed here for 3 nights as a family of 4. Rooms were a little tight but as expected in Tokyo and we got a bit unlucky as we had no view at all from the windows.The communal areas are lovely and the staff very welcoming. It really is in a great location to explore the surrounding area which was our favourite in Tokyo.Would recommend it to anyone.
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We stayed here as a family at the end of our holiday. Room was small, but beds were super comfy. Was definitely a bit of a challenge packing to leave in such a small space.Service was good, late checkout, and bags were held for us for an hour or so.Japanese breakfast was delicious and the children loved the waffle breakfast. Shared bathrooms were clean and well stocked. We loved the area. Would stay again.
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We stayed at a few different hostels around Tokyo and thought we would splurge for our last 2 nights. I am very glad we did. Checked in early at 7am and left our bags in storage and was pleased to find our bags in our room by the time we returned at night. Everything you could want in the bathroom is there. The room was very clean and tidy.
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The Hotel was perfectly fine, in a nice area with a nice vibe and very comfortable beds. In saying that, I wouldn’t stay here again. For over $400 aud/ night for the suite room, average isn’t going to cut it. The service we experienced from check in to check out was abrupt and disinterested. Our room wasn’t ready until 4:30pm with no offer to hold bags, or apology for the delay. A 5 minute shower was enough for the drains to flood over soaking the entire bathroom floor and the walls were incredibly thin. It was easy to hear word for word what our neighbour was saying, and you can hear the elevator all night long. After staying in other hotels in Japan, including others in Tokyo, I know there is better quality available for less.
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: This hotel is so charming. Comfortable with a great view of Asakusa temple. Food is also delicious.Staff friendly and helpful. Bathroom is very compact but practical.The area is fantastic, old Tokyo.
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: It is a cosy, clean hostel in a calm place but at the same time really close to some main attractions like Senso-ji and Nakamise Shopping street. You can have a good example for a traditional japanese breakfast - the continental breakfast is also good. Even if the prices for the breakfast are a little bit high, it's worth it or it's close too other good and cheap breakfast oppertunities like "Fuglen".The infrastructure is good - all you need is there and the staff are very welcoming.Good choice to start or end a trip in Tokyo.
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Simply amazing. The staff was amazing. The location within Asakusa was amazing. The entire experience exceeded all expectations.I can't speak enough of the staff and how friendly and helpful they were. Always happy to discuss fun places to go to, local shopping, and establishments to check out.Our room was 801, standard compact, and my wife and I couldn't have asked for more for the price. Very clean and minimalistic in design and decor and we loved it!The hotel location is literally perfect. Less than 2 km from the sky tree, Ueno Park, and less than 1 km from Senso-ji Temple. And if you're feeling lazy the hotel is situated within the Hisago-dori shopping street as well as the ROX shopping complex 100 meters away. Plus all the small side streets with shops surrounding the area. Oh, and did I mention the small amusement park just down the street (east of the hotel)?Food-wise, the on-site restaurant was great. Plenty of local and "Western" food to select from. The staff/chef was very friendly and would take a minute to chat or explain something. The parfaits were amazing, definitely try those if you have a chance!Cannot recommend WIRED Hotel Asakusa enough. When we go back to Japan (likely in a few years) this place is at the top of our list.
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We had a lovely room with a balcony that was ideal for a cocktail after a day walking around Tokyo. The hotel is very modern and has a great restaurant attached. The rooms are very tastefully decorated and well appointed. The staff are very helpful and we enjoyed our chats with Tomohiro the lovely Guest relations manager. Asakusa is a great area and the hotel is very close to the subway.There are numerous malls around the place and many excellent eating places and it is only a few minutes away from the Sensoji temple.I would heartily recommend this hotel and will definitely book again when we next visit Japan.
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: This is the best hotel room we have ever stayed in. We stayed in room D with a lovely roof terrace. The hotel was lovely and clean and had the best wee bar at reception.The place was that good that I have recommended it to my parents who will be staying in May 2019.The location is great and the staff too. Highly recommend to all!
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We stayed in the quad bunk room with a small family of 5 beds are big enough for our 2 little ones to share. The hotel is spotless and well maintained, our room was small but thats part of the Japanese experience! The location suited us perfectly little bit less busy and great restaurants near by.
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We stayed two nights here thinking we would explore the north area of Tokyo as we had spent two nights at the start of our trip in Ginza. On balance there is not a lot to see in this area and it can be done in a day. Staying in Ginza or Shibuya is better for getting around as it can take a long time to get from A to B in Tokyo. That said it is close to Senso Ji so you can get there early. The hotel itself is quite young and trendy. We took a double room, so not a typical shared hostel style room. It was a good size and had a terrace but I think overpriced for the area as we paid £165 per night. New and clean though with lots of light. Can’t comment on the shared rooms though. The breakfast is small and simple nothing great. Service one morning was very slow. The staff were quite computer says no in their attitude and not very amenable sometimes, just a reflection of the level of service. After waiting for 40 mins for breakfast, only one egg arrived when I asked for two and they insisted on charging 150 yen extra.... not really good customer service.
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I stayed for ten nights from the 1/5/18. I was in a six bed dormitory and it couldn't have been a better experience. Breakfast was excellent each morning although the selection of three could have done with a rotating menu. The bunks were the size of a single bed and heavy curtains prevented snoring etc. from being a problem. The toiletries provided were of a high standard and the showers were nice and hot with great water pressure. Hair dryers and Toto toilets were a bonus (nice warm seat and toilet and bidet combined). Washing machines and dryers were provided for a very small cost (100yen). There was also a common room with a toaster oven, microwave, fridge and freezer if you got sick of eating out.
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Room 902 is great (but not tall ;-) It‘s quite in night. Bed is very comfortable included the both pillows. Food is good. The desert menu is excellent. Possibility to rent a bike. I would come again to same hotel, same room. Picture is taken from balcony.
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Stayed here over Christmas 2017. Had an amazing stay. Been to Tokyo twice before and had not stayed in the Asakusa region so gave it a go. Great area that is, yes, somewhat touristy but a good convenient area for getting around. The hotel is fab! We booked a large private room with an AMAZING comfy bed (awkwardly gross slight brag here) I've had the gift of staying at some borderline stupid posh hotels like the Park Hyatt Tokyo and the Shangri-La in London but oh my, the bed at Wired hotel was the best heavenly cloud bed I have ever had he pleasure of sleeping in! We had a balcony over looking the sky tree and the little theme park next door. It was pure Xmas bliss, I will forever remember drinking Sake and taking in the lovely view on Christmas Night! They even left us a little Xmas gifts at our door!The little tombola game at check in was adorable and I was very happy and not at all jealous for the lady before me when won a whole bottle of Sake. This place has a great chilled atmosphere and unique quality that many hotels lack. My only very, very, small grievances is that the room we stayed in (cat statue in the corner, arty words painted on the wall) the bath\shower was awkward as it had no shower curtain so water spewed errrywhere and was hard to get in and out of. Also that the hotel freebies (no tea , coffee etc.) were lacking for what I have previously experienced in Japan. I love me some free earbuds and shower caps! Saying that though, there is a 7 Eleven like, 1 minute away (+_+). Can't wait to stay again!
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Top quality, boutique hotel located in Asakusa, a 5-10 minute walk away from Senso-ji. Highly recommend staying in Asakusa as it is a much more traditional neighborhood away from the hustle and bustle of more business-oriented areas. Wired Hotel is a very quirky and clean boutique hotel and I greatly enjoyed my stay. They have both hostel options as well as private rooms. Would gladly stay here again.
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I was in Tokyo on business for a little less than a week and brought my husband along with me to do some sight seeing while there. While I could have stayed in a more "central" location, we were so happy in the end that we chose Asakusa and Wired Hotel. The neighborhood itself is lovely and fairly quiet once you get out of the bustling Sensoji area, which is a very short walk from Wired. The hotel is clean, modern, and impeccably curated - if you've ever stayed in an ACE hotel in the states, its a similar vibe. The concierge was kind and welcoming. We stayed in one of the private rooms and it was very spacious and comfortable. They had great french press coffee in the morning. And I encourage you at least once to order the full Japanese breakfast - it was divine. If I'm ever in Tokyo again, this is where I will stay.
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I stayed at The Wired from Feb 27 - March 2, 2018. The hotel truly started my first solo trip on a positive note. FYI, The Wired is an all budget accommodation hotel meaning they have dormitory/hostel style bunk beds to private rooms to penthouses. I chose The Wired off of because of affordability and aesthetic. I really enjoy staying in these warm modern aesthetics hotels (turns out Wired used the same PR/branding as the Ace Hotel.) Before I get to the details, WHAT I LOVED MOST about The Wired Hotel was the young & friendly staff. They all spoke english or were learning. They were all very friendly especially Tomoyo and Kana. I met them one my first day as I was enjoying a drink after checking-in. They gave me great local recommendation. They really made my stay superb; I can't thank them enough!Ok, details! The first night, I stayed in the dormitory style room. Spacious/large closet space. USB hookup next to bed to charge your phone. Bathroom & showers were very clean.The next 2 nights, I stayed in a mini compact room. Again very clean, good for one person, it would be tight for two but its still doable. Location: I didn't find much to do in Asakusa except for Sensoji Temple and theres a Don Quijote (great place for souvenirs) down the street. 10-15 minute way to the subway depending on which line you are taking. Although, I found myself spending more time on the other side of town in Roppongi & Shibuya. I enjoyed being in a quiet area like Asakusa away from all the noise. There was still lots of things happening around the hotel too!It's all about preference but I really liked the comfortable & affordable stay I had at The Wired.
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Staff are multilingual and kind, rooms are nice, area is perfect for shopping, dining, and cultural elements. Really, there's nothing wrong with this place whatsoever. Highly recommend. You won't regret it.
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: A beautiful boutique hotel in Asakusa. The rooms are well designed and have a nice vibe. The staff all know English and very helpful. I particular like the 1 mile recommendations where the staff gives you ideas to explore around the Asakusa area.
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We really enjoyed the stay at this pretty new one hotel. We stayed twice and had two different rooms. First night we had their premium room which was just perfect. Felt very cosy. We had a small balcony and a lot of light coming in through big windows. The only little complain would be shower which did not have any curtain/glass so it did get wet...Second stay was in their standard room which was to my big surprise very nice sised room, again comfortable bed. The bathroom was not as luxury as in premium room but it did have shower curtain and did a perfect job for such short stay.We felt welcome by the hotel staff which spoke good English, we enjoyed discovering Asakusa neighborhood using their map with some special places to see like shops, cafes, restaurants. As well, we thought room price/quality was very good as Tokyo hotels can be expensive....If you use Haneda airport then it is easy to reach hotel using direct train link.Definately will return to this place for our future trips to NYC
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Will always remember this hotel with the beautiful room that smelled of wood... the best linens... yukatas to wear for breakfast... a wonderful view from your balcony! I regret buying only one set of yukata... could have shared more of them, and the memories to my dear friends!
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: This is my favourite hostel of all the ones I stayed in for my 3 wk tour of Japan. This even edged out a 4 star hotel in Ginza, which says a lot.The Wired Hotel is located in Asakusa, right on the steps of a covered shopping strip lined with restaurants and restaurants. It is also a short walk away from the Senjo-Ji shrine, a popular tourist attraction as well as one of the busiest restaurant districts of the area. Accessible by underground on two lines and a mere 10 min walk from either, it is a good option for convenience. The multi-lingual reception staff were friendly and helpful. The lobby was open-concept with the illusion of partitions by way of draped linens. The hotel bar/lounge/restaurant was chic in an understated manner, and hosted late afternoon drinks for guests. Each floor is equipped with a large open-concept kitchen and lounge. The shared washrooms were pristine, as were the rooms. The rooms were quiet and each bunk had heavy drapes to maintain privacy and kept the noise level to a minimum. Each bunk had a more than adequate locker space, and key access for a lock-box was located within the bunks. Temperature controlled rooms made the extreme humidity of September more bearable, and the linens were crisp, the duvet cozy and a fluffy towel was supplied. The wifi was strong and there was never a connection issue.Each floor had room options for mixed, men-only, women-only rooms, all with security key access to each. Washrooms were very clean, counters ample and hairdryers accessible. All in all, if I was not on a tight tour schedule, I would have stayed longer than the 2 days booked. Highly recommend.
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We travelled all over Tokyo for 6 days exploring alley ways and eating joints and we were so happy to come home to Wired Hotel in Asakusa every night. We were in room 803 with the most amazing balcony that we renamed The Rooftop Bar. After huge days exploring the city and eating so much, we would stop at the Family Mart next door, stock up on Japanese Whisky, chocolates, nuts, pork buns and anything else that took out fancy, then head up to 803 ‘the Rooftop Bar’ and watch the beautiful scene illuminate before us. It really made the end of each day special. The bed is exceptionally comfortable and the quilt is like a comforting cloud. We know that we couldn’t have made a better choice for what we like. A boutique feel in an incredible park of Tokyo.
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: My husband and I are just back from 10 days at the Wired Hotel and we couldn’t have been any happier. Our room was beautiful with a dazzling balcony with views across the city and even of the Senso-ji Temple if you sat in the right place. The staff is very international and you get the sense they are just as excited about Tokyo as any first time visitor is - a breath of fresh air. Asakusa is a great place with just the right mix of locals and tourist infrastructure. It’s also worth noting that if you should take advantage of the busses nearby, which get you some very close by neighborhoods of Tokyo in 10-15 minutes rather than always taking the subway. I couldn’t disagree more about previous comments about the hotel map- we definitely loved some of the suggestions we hit from it and found it had some useful info about places we wouldn’t have known about otherwise, we just popped the things we were interested in to our Google Maps list for ease. The lobby restaurant is a great meeting place with a mix of locals and guests with an OUTSTANDING selection of sake and a nearly daily changing of food specials. We enjoyed that the hotel embraces its location and encourages you to explore locally.
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Perfect location. Easy access from the airport via Asakusa Train Station. Artsy Hotel that supports local artists and their works. Lovely layout and design. Hip and cool public spaces. Rooms are simple yet tastefully done. The bed, pillows and linens are divine. Staff are helpful and friendly. Overall, it was the perfect choice for my first ever Tokyo adventure. It'll be my home in Tokyo for sure.
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I had an AMAZING stay here! The hotel opened in April 2017 so everything is very new and in top condition. Check in was thorough and friendly. The hostel level is on the 4th floor and really well designed. The common area is trendy and comfortable with a kitchen to use. The restrooms are always clean (they also provide shampoo etc and great hairdryers). Our room of 4 beds was small but super comfy - the single beds are huge and I slept very well! My friend and I were lucky to have the room to ourselves so it felt like even more of a bargain! You also receive a drink voucher (tea, coffee, juice) for every night of your stay to use at the hotel's restaurant. It was convenient to have a coffee before starting my busy days. I would definitely recommend my friends and family stay here. If I am back in Asakusa this is my first choice!
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: This is a great area, Asakusa district, older area of Tokyo. The hotel is modern, rooms are excellent. Beds are really comfortable. Staff are great, very friendly and helpful. I really enjoyed the food but there were some exceptions where I really thought they got it wrong. The breakfast option with salmon was fab. We couldn't have dinner on the 2nd evening as they had a booked our Sake event, we weren't informed and offered no alternative. Not good business practice.Still a recommendable hotel.
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Not enough words to describe the Wired Hotel. Location is amazing. Far from the crowd, in a neighborhood where you can fell the real Tokyo, tons of places to eat, a subway station and two Department Stores nearby. The hotel is brand new, the restaurant is super good, and there's the "hostel floors". 6 nights in a bunk bed for a very good price. Strongly recommended.
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Fantastic hotel in good location in Asakusa. Staff incredibly friendly and helpful at all times - this is one of those rare hotels that manages to be trendy without being too cool for school. Rooms are small, but that's par for the course for this kind of price in Tokyo, and there is an option for dorm rooms for those on a tight budget. Its a small hotel, so facilities are obviously limited, but the quality of everything is very high, and they have a great kitchen on one of the floors where you can store and prepare food, which is also a great way to keep your budget in check. We stayed in a lot of places in Japan and as far as contemporary hotels go this was far and away the best. Highly recommended.
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We had a bunk room for 3 nights and that was the best "capsule" room ive been in Japan so far. Ive been on nice hotels too but that one is brand new, modern, trendy and well equipped.The beds are equipped with big locks for the luggage and an extra lock inside the bed space, for small things.The shared espace is big, with sofas, full equipped kitchen, big wooden table... Scandinavian style...The showers and toilets were well equipped and we even had a nice and big balcony where we were able to do yoga (we had enough space finally!)The hotel provides you with home shoes, towel and toothbrush set. The soap, champoo and conditioner is also for free.They invited us to one free drink per day at their nice restaurant and they proposed us nice activities that the hotel itself organise ( like sake tasting or concerts).The have other types of rooms (double, private) but if your budget is limited do not doubt to go for the shared one ( the worst that can happen to you is to listen someone else's snoring).The staff is super diverse with multiples nationalities on the reception. Always willing to help.And they rent bikes if needed!The neighbourhood is awsome in case you dont know, the area worth a visit...
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: This was my favorite of the five (all nice) hotels I've stayed at in Tokyo. It is brand new (opened on April 1, 2017) so we were a little nervous beforehand as there were no online reviews at the time we booked. The staff are young and super friendly and fun. We stayed in a room with a balcony which had a really nice modern design and was very large by Tokyo standards (they have a range of accommodation, from hostel style shared rooms to high end hotel rooms). The location is excellent, right in the heart of Asakusa and only a couple of minutes from Sensoji temple. There are lots of great places to eat in the neighborhood. We did an excellent one hour tour of the neighborhood with one of the staff, Autumn, which was really interesting and gave us lots of ideas for non-touristy things to do. They have a good restaurant with lots of interesting Japanese food choices. Overall the hotel struck a nice balance between having strong Japanese elements but also being very accessible and welcoming to overseas visitors. Very highly recommended, I will definitely aim to stay there again next time I am in Tokyo!
hotelName:
26    Wired Hotel Asakusa
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Lovely hospitality, clean room with many little homey touches, helpful and friendly staff. After sightseeing amongst massive crowds, it was nice to come back to this quiet, snug little inn. Really enjoyed our stay!
hotelName:
27    Family Inn Saiko
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: My dad and I stayed there for 5 days and it was honestly the perfect place. It’s about 5 to 10 min walk to two train station, 5 min walk to a street with a lot of restaurants. Groceries and soft drinks machine are all around the hotel. The staff is amazing very friendly and helpful. The room are spacious and clean, I especially book it for the Japanese style well you are definitely in a Japanese house ! It’s like a family place there’s a fridge a microwave a distributor of soft drinks 24h at your disposition. I thought there was no breakfast but there is with unlimited coffee and tasty toasts. I already miss that place and the peoples over there. If you are looking for a Japanese ambiance where to stay and somewhere quiet but with facilities that’s the right hotel to book ! By the way you can have massages also in your room the hotel has an amazing masseur.
hotelName:
27    Family Inn Saiko
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I have just returned from a great five night stay at Family Inn Saiko. This was my first time staying in a more traditional style Japanese hotel and it was incredible. Firstly the staff were so welcoming and hospitable. They assisted with general directions and tips for Tokyo, and also arranged our transport back to Narita Airport. Our room was a standard twin; the size was plenty for two people. The bathroom was roomy and the shower pressure was really strong. The tatami floor and futon bedding was really comfortable, I found it much the same as sleeping on a firmer, western-style mattress. There was also enough room to comfortably fit two large suitcases. The room felt really cozy and like being at home. It was also spotless- the cleanliness of the inn was impeccable. The location was also great. I loved being in a residential area as it made the vacation more authentic. It was also peaceful to come back to quietness after long days of site seeing and crowded places. It was still easy to get to all the sites, and didn’t take long either. There are two stations that are accessible from the hotel; we mainly used Shiinamachi station which took about a ten minute walk. The walk was easy to navigate and the road was flat and quiet. On the way to the station there is a 7/11, some Japanese restaurants and a MOS burger. Overall we had a fantastic stay and would definitely come back again!
hotelName:
27    Family Inn Saiko
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We just returned from Tokyo and were very pleased to have chosen Family Inn. I particularly liked the residential area which was so peaceful after a day out in the frenetic madness of downtown Tokyo. I enjoyed walking home through peaceful streets marvelling at how clean and safe it was. There are small places to eat nearby, but few with English menus. However, one of our best experiences in Japan was when we ate at a local place run by a Grandma/Grandpa team; the chef and waitress looked to be in their 80s (yes - really!) it was so friendly, hysterically funny as we all tried to communicate, the other diners pitching in to help us order (we just pointed to other people’s food) and the food was not only delicious but super cheap.The owners at Family Inn are so helpful, speaking good English and very friendly too. The rooms were comfortable and tea, coffee and toast is available for breakfast.The only reason I didn’t give it 5 stars is that I didn’t realise there was no blind or curtain so I had to buy an eye mask after waking up at 4.45am. Come prepared. I would definitely recommend.
hotelName:
27    Family Inn Saiko
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I stayed at Family Inn Saiko with my two sons in early April for 3 nights. My eldest son did the booking, so I wasn't aware of the location until we got there. The Family Inn was about 1km away from the train station and tucked inside the suburban streets. It's a fair bit of walk especially after a day of activities. So keep that in mind when you make the booking. A 7-11 convenience store was located near the station.Staffs were very friendly and checked in was quick and easy. We stayed in a family room with three futons on the floor. Room was considered a bit small and not much walking space once the futons were out. Walking on each other futon was unavoidable. There was just enough space for two medium luggage. The bathroom has a shower cubicle and toilet with heated seat. The amenities were adequate. The are was quiet which was great. Internet was fine.They have a fridge in the kitchen next to the front desk which you could store food there. Instant cup noodles and snacks were available for purchase. Overall, we were happy with the stay except for the distance to the station.
hotelName:
27    Family Inn Saiko
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: A charming small inn, but I wouldn’t choose it if I wanted to stay in the thick of things and have limited time with me. It is a 13 minutes’ walk away from the nearest station and except for the futons and the tatami mat, did not feel much like a ryokan, which I had mistakenly assumed it to be. The hosts are warm though and the hotel cozy. Breakfast is basic: tea/coffee and toast with butter/jam. The windows have no curtains and the sunlight trickles in early. The residential area in which it is located provides a slice of real Tokyo. I didn’t use the Onsen but understand that’s quite the draw.
hotelName:
27    Family Inn Saiko
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Stayed here as a family with elderly parents. While the hotel may not offer full services like major hotels it was very cozy and the staff were very accommodating. The inn is in a local neighborhood, 10-15 minutes walk to the nearest train station. We used the Kannamachi metro most of the time as it was on the Tokyo subway route which accommodated our unlimited metro pass. The walk was quite nice, allowing the opportunity to experience the local lifestyles though the narrow winding roads can get a bit confusing at night when it's not as easily visible. We got slightly lost coming back to the hotel on the first night but got assistance from very friendly locals who led us back to the inn. I really enjoyed the private hot bath located on the 4th floor as an added bonus service the inn offers. The room was spotlessly clean and clean towels along with the 'yukuta' Japanese robe is included for free use. There is toast, water, coffee, and tea offered for a quick breakfast in the shared dining area. If you are looking for a more fulfilling meal, there are several convenience stores nearby to stock up in the inn's shared refrigerator. Overall if you are looking to experience local lifestyle, with some peace and serenity away from the city center in a friendly neighborhood at a reasonable price, Family Inn Saiko is the ideal choice.
hotelName:
27    Family Inn Saiko
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We stayed for 5 nights at Family Inn Saiko and really loved it. Our welcome was a cheerful and warm one, we were given the tour of the Inn on arrival and were lucky that we were able to check in a little earlier than expected. All the lovely touches around the Inn make you feel that the family are keen to share their knowledge and their culture - love the Owl theme! Our room was clean, comfortable and quiet and it was so easy to get into central Tokyo within minutes from the Shinnamashi station. It was far better to stay in such a lovely suburb neighbourhood and observe the day to day of the community than be too central and there are some good eating spots in the neighbourhood.We were sad to leave and we must say a big thank you to Yuki who saved us from missing the airport limousine bus pick up when we couldn't get a taxi (on a Friday evening)and very kindly gave us a lift to the Metropolitan Hotel pick up point. A very kind gesture indeed!We would love to stay again when we return to Tokyo!
hotelName:
27    Family Inn Saiko
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: This is an excellent place to stay short subway ride away from the busiest part of Tokyo. Our room was spacious, clean and very comfortable with tatami-floor and bathroom. The service was superb: they even woke up very early in the morning to make sure that we got into our taxi when we were going to the airport. To us the location was very good, only ten minutes from the subway station. The area is quiet, which is nice during the night. I am very sensitive to noise, but slept very well in this quiet guesthouse.
hotelName:
27    Family Inn Saiko
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: My stay at Family Inn Saiko was excellent. The staff was so nice and helpful when I had questions. The location of the hotel was in a quiet and peaceful neighborhood which was a different pace from other hotels I stayed at. The standard twin room was excellent for the price.
hotelName:
27    Family Inn Saiko
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Fantastic premises, exceptionally friendly and professional owners. Quiet and convenient location. It was a great experience staying at Family Inn Saiko indeed. I strongly recommend it.and I will definitely return.
hotelName:
27    Family Inn Saiko
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I went on a round trip to Japan and stayed at quite a few accommodations around Japan, but Family Inn Saiko was by far the best one. As soon as you arrive there you receive a very warm welcome by the incredibly courteous, attentive and helpful staff who also speaks English very well. If you read the other reviews about this Inn you'll notice that almost everyone emphasizes their generous hospitality and I have to say that they absolutely deserve this high praise as everyone at Family Inn Saiko does their utmost to provide their guests a wonderful stay in Tokyo. The Inn is located in a quiet neighborhood next to Ikebukuro and it takes a 10 minutes’ walk to get to the nearby located metro station. Of course this means it takes a little extra time to get to the center of Tokyo, but on the other hand this inn is very affordable and you can enjoy spending the night at a rather quiet and lovely place compared to the bustling city center. The inn offers you everything you need for your stay, I found it especially convenient that there is a washing machine (and drying racks) which you can use for free, as well as the detergent. The room was very clean and tidy, the futon bed surprisingly comfortable and in the morning you could enjoy a simple but tasty breakfast (toast and marmalade) for free.To put it short: I absolutely recommend this place if you are planning to visit Tokyo. They even gave me a beautiful parting gift! :) Next time I visit Tokyo I'll certainly stay at Family Inn Saiko again!
hotelName:
27    Family Inn Saiko
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Family Inn Saiko was a lovely last hotel for our stay in Japan. A traditional ryokan, the tatami mats, the futon and the ofuro were splendid and the attentive staff, always ready with splendid, pertinent advice were always on hand, but never intrusive. I would thoroughly recommend a stay at this excellent inn (and a visit to the lovely Italian restaurant around the corner) to anyone. The only downside is how far away it is from the metro station with little by way of indication.
hotelName:
27    Family Inn Saiko
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Our family of 4 stayed at Family Inn Saiko and enjoyed. The Inn is located in a quiet area near Ikebukero and was perfect for us.
