Down side is you have to manage your personal items pretty much in any area available in hallway, under the bed, etc. if you're traveling with load of items it might be a bit tough. Also if you're staying for longer dates, it might get a bit tiring. Bed is enough to sleep on but could be bit stiff. It's about 20min walk to hear to Shibuya, or take a bus for 10min. Perfect if you're traveling yourself and trying to save up on your trip, and trying to explore Shibuya day/nightlife.
hotelName:
30    WISE OWL HOSTELS SHIBUYA
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The heart of shibuya is moments away from the hostel making it a great place to stay if you're wanting a good night out or just to be in the the thick of the Tokyo atmosphere. Staff are awesome! Shout out to Marin for all her great suggestions and lovely vibes
hotelName:
30    WISE OWL HOSTELS SHIBUYA
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I was very pleased to have picked this hostel, it was very well located, near to Shibuya but not too hectic. The staff were so helpful and friendly. The rooms, and washrooms in particular were amazingly clean. The cleanest of my travels so far. I liked that the common areas of the rooms had cameras as I felt very secure. In addition to the fact there were big lockers. As a solo young female I felt very safe and looked after.
hotelName:
30    WISE OWL HOSTELS SHIBUYA
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The reviews on here really don't highlight just how small the rooms are - my boyfriend and I booked a twin room, and as it's a hostel in Tokyo we were expecting small, but this was a whole other level. We ended up with a bunk bed with no space on either side, with a very small area to put our belongings, and not enough floor space for the both of us to stand up at the same time. Also there is no curfew here, the walls are paper thin, and the floor and ceiling were concrete so noise carried, so both nights we were woken at 12.30-1am by guests coming in speaking very loudly and letting doors slam shut behind them (we ended up having to buy ear plugs to sleep through). The bathrooms were clean and showers decent size. I would also advise that although we didn't mind as we travelled as a couple, there is a very small eating area and no common area, so it would be difficult to socialise if travelling solo. Overall the hostel is fine if staying 1 or 2 nights but wouldn't want to stay any longer.
hotelName:
30    WISE OWL HOSTELS SHIBUYA
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Would go back again if in Tokyo.Helpful staff, clean rooms and toilets/showers.Great location, 12-15 mins walk from Shibuya station.Beds are most comfortable I had in a hostel, not sinking into them and drowning like in other hostels.And each bed has privacy with a curtain so another plus.
hotelName:
30    WISE OWL HOSTELS SHIBUYA
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The location of the hostel is great, within walking distance to 4 metro stops makes travelling around tokyo simple, and plenty of night life in the local area.The beds in the dorm are comfortable and feel private, plenty of space to store luggage as well.Finally the staff are all friendly and extremely helpful, made it feel like a second home!
hotelName:
30    WISE OWL HOSTELS SHIBUYA
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: My friend and I were in Tokyo for a week and needed a place that was clean, affordable and in a good location for exploring and Wise Owl Shibuya gave us just that. The location is ideal. It's on the edge of Shibuya, which allows a short walk to all the restaurants, shopping, etc. you could want while being just far enough away to avoid the noise and crowds. It's also a moderate walk or short bus ride to the Shibuya Train Station. It was a great base camp for exploring Tokyo and making some day trips.Tokyo is the safest major city on the planet, but I'll say it anyway, this location was in a very safe location. We walked in all directions at all hours and never found an unsafe area. The rooms have electronic locks and the whole area seemed fine for any age or gender.We chose the small private room for our accommodations. It suited our needs as a place to sleep on a decent bed. If you choose this option, just be aware that small means small. There was just enough room for the bunk bed, a tiny sink and that's basically it. There's almost not enough room for two people to stand. We had to store our luggage at the opposite end of the bed under the window, which requires unpacking/packing on your actual bed. That might be a problem for some, but for us, we spent almost every waking hour in the city, so tight quarters weren't an issue. We didn't travel all the way to Japan just to stay in our hostel. There are small, lockable cabinets on each bed as well as a couple of outlets.Everything was very clean, from the rooms to the bathrooms to the showers. Sheets were fine on the beds. Toilets and showers were clean. We never ran into any long lines trying to use the facilities at any point in the day. A towel was provided and they have shampoo/conditioner/body wash in the showers, though I suggest bringing your own wash cloth. There's a small restaurant on the main floor. I never used it but my friend ordered a few things throughout the trip. We walked across the street to Lawson for a quick breakfast every morning and ate elsewhere for lunch and dinner.The staff is all very friendly and helpful. They spoke english and were able to answer all of our questions.I would highly recommend this hostel for anyone looking for a nice, affordable place to get some sleep while spending most of the day out in Tokyo.
hotelName:
30    WISE OWL HOSTELS SHIBUYA
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The only night there has been very pleasant: good location at a walkable distance from Shibuya, merry professional much welcoming staff,clean rooms and bathrooms, nice wooden design, reasonable price.
hotelName:
30    WISE OWL HOSTELS SHIBUYA
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We stayed at Wise Owls our last night in Japan and it was perfect. Cozy and comfy beds and the staff were so kind, friendly and helpful. The hostel is within walking distance of Shibuya station and the famous crossing which makes it a convenient base for getting around Tokyo.
hotelName:
30    WISE OWL HOSTELS SHIBUYA
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Clean place, great atmosphere. Short 20 minute walk from Shibuya station. As a single 26 yr old female I felt safe walking around the neighborhood past midnight. The staff were warm and welcoming, helpful, and available 24 hrs.
hotelName:
30    WISE OWL HOSTELS SHIBUYA
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Great location, perfect cleanliness, newly built, very friendly staff, comfortable beds, great shower rooms, quiet at night, good temperature, usb chargers built-in, lockers, shoe storage, towels fresh everyday; amazing staff helped me with sending back my forgotten property on the same day! great service
hotelName:
30    WISE OWL HOSTELS SHIBUYA
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Wise Owl was a very pleasant place to stay for an evening, very central, a 20 min walk to Shibuya, and with a very modern functional decor, with nice cubbies for your shoes under the stairs in the bunks, and wood lock boxes by your head. Even a small kitchen area and mini-fridge per floor, and laundry on a couple of floors, which were all very useful for the budget conscious traveller that I am. The staff was very kind and accommodating, holding my bags and even letting me put some food in the fridge before the check-in time. I will be staying there again for sure!
hotelName:
30    WISE OWL HOSTELS SHIBUYA
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Within walking minutes from Shibuya station, it’s a brand new hostel, very clean with a magic mattress (really comfy) and to complete all the staff are very nice. If there’s one thing to say is about the common space, a good lounge to chill with other guests will be nice!
hotelName:
30    WISE OWL HOSTELS SHIBUYA
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The beds are super comfortable and the staff speakers Various languages. They are very understanding and adapt to your requests. I arrived very late in the night and checking was absolutely no problem. With my student budget I think I got a great deal!
hotelName:
30    WISE OWL HOSTELS SHIBUYA
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The best thing about this property was the service. Late check-in, very organized, kind staff, great communication and more. Next, the location was perfect. A nice walk to Shibuya station, a convenience store across the street, a few minutes from a bus stop. The bathrooms were clean and my belongings felt safe despite being in a room with what felt like dozens of other travelers!
hotelName:
30    WISE OWL HOSTELS SHIBUYA
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The staff were super friendly and helpful :) and it's only about 15 minute walk to the shibuya station & a convenience store just across the street All facilities were super clean - will definitely go back when back in Tokyo!!
hotelName:
30    WISE OWL HOSTELS SHIBUYA
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Honestly, I would be back tomorrow, if I could...My stay at Wise Owl Shibuya was nothing short of excellent. For a hostel, I was amazed at the friendliness, presentation, cleanliness and location of the hostel.It was a stormy night when I arrived, and I was soaked through to the skin. The girl at front desk gave me a towel straight away before she took my booking details.The hostel was well equipped. Cooking kitchen on each floor, a good amount of showers and toilets (I never had to wait), They had hairdryers and those self-heating toilets too.The decor is very modern and cool. The sleeping dorms are cosy and small- and each cubicle has it's own lock box for your belongings.The kitchen downstairs offered good food and beer too, but I wouldn't eat here every night, as I found it a little pricey- however, the kitchen staff were very friendly and appreciative of my comments on their rice pork bowl!The hostel did a lot of events and made notices for upcoming attractions and festivals going on in the area- which was a really cool way to integrate solo travelers. You were never short of options on things to do, and the staff were also very cool and welcoming - they even announce they are going for beer/food and offer spaces for people to come along!What i really loved about WOS was, after I checked out, I filled in a feedback card and chatted to the staff about Ireland (my country). One of the staff were going there soon for a visit. I was short on time and had to run for my bus.I was walking for about 2 minutes and I looked around to one of the female staff running after me - i thought i left something behind - but now, she ran after me to give me a discount card for the hostel, should I book again. Simply because I filled in a feedback card. This simple gesture stuck with me and really summed up how great my stay was at WOS. I will certainly be back. Thank you for the great welcome!
hotelName:
30    WISE OWL HOSTELS SHIBUYA
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The experience in here is not a simple place where one just checks in and solely uses the bed and shower room. It's the community that makes this Hostel a must stay. I've never met so many diverged people in one place who are willing to share their experiences. The staff are amazing--always have an positive attitude towards guest and their needs. The rooms go from private to dormitory style, plus separate male/female floor is available. All amenities are modern. One of my favorite part is their restaurant: Mother Farmer's Table. Their food is so good that I come here everyday for lunch and sometimes dinner (have to save my time with other food). The best part is their bar setup to allow guests to mingle with each other.
hotelName:
30    WISE OWL HOSTELS SHIBUYA
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Not very luxurious, but great for the price. I found the dorms to be good-- privacy provided by pasteboard walls-- easy check in/out. Easy to find. Good area of town. Lots of cool travelers staying there.
hotelName:
30    WISE OWL HOSTELS SHIBUYA
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The twin rooms had very little room to mill about in. Bed wasn't hard. Could hear traffic outside but was too tired to let it keep me up. Got a drink for 100 yen at their restaurant downstairs for staying in the hostel. 15-20 minute walk to bars and clubs. Would definitely stay again.
hotelName:
30    WISE OWL HOSTELS SHIBUYA
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: A compact room with all the modern necessities, you really couldn't want more. There is also a free in-room smart phone that you can borrow with unlimited local telephone calls and super handy to use for google maps and finding local things to do in Tokyo. As always, Japanese service is impeccable.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Did tons of reaearch on where to stay in Tokyo-Ginza and this hotel turned out to be excellent decisions. Best Ramen (across the street), shopping and several transit stations right nearby making it super easy to get anywhere. Strong wifi. Room very clean, quiet, more spacious than typical NYC one & well stocked with personal items. Staff english was challenging (not atypical). Wasn’t crazy about the restaurant (overpriced breakfast) but why go all the way to Japan and eat at your hotel anyway. Would definitely stay here again. Tip: they told us to exit Higashi-Ginza station at exit “7” and there literally is no sign for 7. Go to 8 and the hotel is around the corner.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Right in the heart of Ginza district (think Mayfair, London) and 5mins from the tube and major shopping centres. Some good places to eat nearby. Hotel rooms are small but that's just Japan, everything clean and staff very friendly. Can't comment on restaurant/breakfasts as we didn't eat at the hotel. All in all a nice hotel for exploring Tokyo.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We were told that hotel rooms in Japan are generally smaller than say in Europe or America. This is true. But smaller does not mean less pratical or less comfortable; on the contrary. Thiis is one of the most functional hotel rooms I ever used. From the bathroom to the writing desk, everything uses a minimum of space for a maximum in pratical use. When you stay there you do not need any toiletry; everything (and I mean everything) is here. The yukata at disposal is a tad small, as Japanese are generally smaller then caucausians. The breakfast came as a choice of 4 and was very good indeed,
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: My girlfriends and I stayed here for a vacation in Tokyo. The location is superb because when you shop for a lot of things around Ginza, you can just walk back to Solaria to drop off your shopping bags then shop again. The subway exit nearest to it is the Matsuya Ginza exit. Rooms are clean and their toilets have very helpful amenities and beauty products for women.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I have travelled Tokyo several times and Ginza is my first priority staying location. By around 10 mins walk, we can walk to fish market directly. Downstairs have high end shopping mall and restaurant such as central area in HK while the price is reasonable having a comfortable stay. This would be my recommended choices to everyone
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The Solaria Noshitetsu is located in the elegant Ginza, the luxury shopping district and one of the best neighborhoods due to its proximity to all the places of greatest interest!The rooms are well looked after, sometimes small but it depends a lot on the type of reservation you make although in Japan it is quite frequent. What will hit you is above all the cleaning!!!Breakfast is not continental: a selection of dishes is offered in line with Japanese customs and it is not surprising that there are dishes such as onion soup, cod fillet or raw beef. However you will also find roots, jellies, fruit, smoothies and dairy products such as panna cotta! Don’t worry a few meters from the hotel there is a starbucks!!!The staff is very respectful and courteous and the desk will help you for anything you need as booking taxi, restaurant or give you information about places and transport. In summary, a very good hotel, in Italy would be classified as a 3 or 4 stars.Marzio from Rome
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We stayed overnight in Ginza and arrived with our room already prep and waiting for us. The staff speaks fluent English and very welcoming. The place is a short distance walk from a Metro station and the surrounding area has lots of restaurants and shops. Will recommend this hotel is your journey brings you to Ginza. This is a well kept hotel.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: You are paying for the location for this hotel. The hotel is in the middle of Ginza, with great access to the shops. The rooms are quite dated and in need of a makeover. The staff also weren’t as helpful and welcoming as the staff in other hotels we experienced across Japan.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: This is not a 5* hotel presumably because it does not have a full service restaurant. But it felt like one due to the well designed and maintained rooms. Lovely place to stay in central Kyoto for a reasonable price.Would recommend to anyone
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The room was very well appointed with (unusual for this price range) a separate and comfortable sitting area where you can also enjoy a takeaway meal, which incidentally had a safe hidden beneath the sofa. The location is good with shops all around, including a department store. The hotel provides a free smart phone which was very handy for directions. They called a taxi for me to take me to Tokyo station (where I was to catch the Shinkansen to Kyoto) whilst I relaxed in the lobby until it arrived, and carrying my luggage for me when it did which was good service.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I was pleased with this boutique hotel in terms of location in central Ginza, easy walk to the fish market. It was quite pleasure to be able to walk out of the hotel in be so centrally located-in the midst of busy Ginza, yet the street on the hotel was on was quiet and low key. The rooms were compact more so than the pictures, Suitcases had to be stacked to walk around and it was tight with two people. The bathroom was clean, well proportioned and I loved having a separate shower/bath area.The service- the front desk staff always was respectful and tried hard to help, however at times they were unable to help us with what we needed- One example, a friend got sick while there and the front desk staff could not locate an English speaking doctor in the area, or anywhere in Tokyo, or followed up to see if we were ok- I would expect a hotel of that size to at least have a few names to refer to. We unfortunately had to leave early because of this illness and didn't get any credit on multiple nights. I have been in situations where I've had to leave early and have had more understanding on the part of the hotel staff.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We were part of a family group of 7 adults and one baby occupying 4 rooms. Me and wife's specific room was the double room, which was exceedingly small though clean.The only complaint was the unhelpful though polite front desk staffs. Not really having much initiative and not service oriented. Manager was also unhelpful.Recommend to choose larger rooms and upgrade staff training.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Room is pretty tiny and it didn't help that they have a couch squeezed into the tiny space. Photos of room look better online than in reality. The facade of the hotel looks really stylish but the room was a pretty far cry. The bathtub uses a dated shower curtain instead of those modern glass doors in contemporary hotels. On the positive side they do provide the necessary bathroom amenities.No english channels on TV except BBC. They do provide a mobile phone/tablet that you can bring out which allows free internet access and calls to a handful of countries. They provide only 2 bottles of water a day. I tried to ask for an extra bottle of water and was flat out rejected. The only thing I love about the hotel is the location and proximity to Ginza station. Overall, it is a pretty fuss free hotel that is relatively clean. I noticed many Japanese guests. Do not expect a hip and contemporary boutique hotel with state of the art amenities like how it is being portrayed in online photos.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The Solaria hotel is a nice, modern 13 floor hotel in an ideal location in Ginza. The rooms are small but very efficient and tastefully furnished. The separate shower and soaking tub provide a great way to unwind after a hard day of sightseeing and shopping. The hotel is just a couple minute walk from the Higashi-Ginza subway station and a five minute walk from the Mitsukoshi department store. The famous tsukiji fish market is just a ten minute walk from the hotel. There are lots of restaurants in the area, but be sure to go early since all the good ones get crowded real fast. The hotel’s breakfast buffet is odd. Only salad, juice and coffee are on the buffet line. You only have a choice of three different breakfast menus and you can’t get more unless you want more salad, coffee or juice. Weird. You can always go to Lawson’s or Family Mart nearby to pick up breakfast instead.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I tried this Solaria since the one in Kyoto was nice. This one is the total opposite. The rooms are dated and there are scatched and chipped furniture and decor. The bathroom is worn and the bidet is not heated. The window panes are not sound proof and you hear rowdy noises from bar patrons at night, a doorbell noise from a security motion detector, and street noises like ambulances. It isn't located on the main road but somehow it's very noisy. Our room was on the 7th floor. I usually stayed at the hotel in front of it, Tokyu Stay Ginza, which is quite good. This hotel looks nice from the outside but the rooms badly need some updating. The pictures from Expedia and Travelocity makes the room look new and modern, but it's not. Overall, I would not stay here again.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Stayed here for 4 nights back in October and fell in love with this hotel. Booked the single room and found it to be of decent size and very comfortable for one person. All the necessary amenities are in place. Though the room does not have any windows but I am fine with that. Staff are all friendly and helpful. Location is perfect! Literally steps away from the Ginza shopping strips and the subway. Surrounded by many restaurants, convenient stores and ATMs. Walking distance to the famous Tsukiji Fish Market.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We are booked to arrive at the hotel in mid April. We have a plan to visit famous restaurants and trying to book in advance, but facing challenges as most restaurants don’t have English speaking staff. I spoke to the hotel and they refused to assist with restaurant bookings. By the time we get there, the restaurants will be fully booked. Bad experience already!
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We had privacy, clean, silent room with the view - just what we've been looking for. Location is nice too, business zone, by foot you can reach cool locations. Breakfast was excluded so cannot ssy nothing about it.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: only location is good in Ginza, close to tube n shopping. room is small, said to be 24 sq m but not so useful, compared with similar size hotel in Tokyo. front desk is poor, when u ask to help, just said as noted in the paper. why I need to stay here? other hotels will not like that. Ask to help to book a taxi upon checkout, the girl reluctant to help! always need to ask for senior to solve. avoid & not recommend for stay!
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: My wife and I stayed here while on vacation. Right in the centre of Ginza, easy walk to everything, and close to the metro line if you want to go further afield. The rooms are small as you would expect, but very comfortable and well laid out, with everything you need. Breakfast in the restaurant is excellent food. (Could do better coffee). The staff at the front desk are very helpful and friendly, and will go out of their way to make recommendations and give you detailed directions. No gym, which is something I like in a hotel, but sometimes you can’t have everything.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We had a family trip over the year end and through my daughter’s research and my Japanese friend’s counsel, we picked this hotel for its location (Ginza, 3 min walk from the subway station) and cost. Due to its popularity, check in time was not negotiable but we soon found that everything else was spot on, from the room size (small by Asian standards but adequate), cleanliness, bed quality and especially the bathroom (sizeable and fully functional). I rate them a full 5 stars!There was however one (small) downside - there is a restaurant but no bar in the hotel. So waiting for family members and having a pre-dinner drink was not so easy ;). And the fact that ther was no gym didn’t go down too well with my wife. Anyhow all in all, however excellent and will certainly be going back!
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Quiet and comfortable room. Nice staff. The hotel is situated 200m from the subway with express trains heading to Haneda airport in 40 minutes.The hotel is in the heart of Ginza, allowing you to discover the neighbourhood.A lot of sights are by walking distance (Imperial palace, Tsukiji market).Hotel highly recommended for those wanting to stay in Ginza during their trip to Tokyo.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We stayed hear the last weekend in October. Room was small but more than adequate. No place to put large bags, but we managed. We were there when a typhoon hit so our plans to travel around Tokyo for sightseeing were crimped. We were able to do some major shopping and eating within walking distance with umbrellas
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I found the Solaria nishitetsu on tripadvisor. My main destination was Osaka and environs so this was my arrival and departure hotel for Japan. My husband and I were extremely happy with the location of the hotel which allowed us to walk to and from the subway for our Haneda airport flights, and to walk to the train station for the trip to Osaka, although the train station might be outside what some would consider an acceptable walking distance. We found nearby restaurants, coffee, and convenience stores all within a few blocks of the hotel on safe, well lit streets. The room for both stays was small (what room in Japan is not?), functional and very clean. The rooms had extra towels and toiletries, a room safe, new slippers and pajamas on the bed for guest use, hair dryer, etc. We did not want for anything. Wifi access was good, and we did not watch TV. The staff was very friendly. The restaurant was lovely, but somewhat expensive. We only ate there once. I am recommending this hotel to others, and will stay at the Solaria on my return trips to Tokyo.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: You could give this place 5 stars for the location alone. Just a block away from the Mitsuoka Department store and minutes walk from Ginza station and all the brand stores, you’ll find yourself in the thick of the action at the Solaria.But once you add in the fact the combination of the affordability and quality of the rooms, I think you’ll find yourself hard pressed to find another choice in Ginza or any other neighbourhood with such great value.If you’re looking to be in Ginza and want something reliable that doesn’t break the bank, you can’t do much better than the Solaria.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I stayed in the Solaria 2 times. 1 in 2013 and one in 2017 during the summer. I forgot I stayed here before so I was a bit bummed when i walked over ( 20 min walk from Tokyo station) and entered cause I remembered it as a decent place but for some reason not my favorite. They must have renovated or I chose a better room because it was great. just great! The room had a double bed and while the view was in the back and windows were tinted the bathroom was huge with full tub and window to room. Great internet and clean and really A good place if you get the larger rooms. I'm not sure if I stayed in a different size room ( I don't think so ) Or if the room is larger cause it is in the back with no real view ( unless you crack the window) but it was great. The location is great. An easy walk to Tsukiji , Ginza, Shimbashi, Closed Ginza street on weekends. Just great. I do wish the window was not blurred out and that is my only complaint, but i was near the fire escape so there was a reason etc. You can't go wrong with 1 person or a couple here. It would have been just ok for our son for 1-2 nights at most in the double room..as well, but not sure if they have cribs. GO FOR IT!
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Boutique hotel positioned conveniently in a lovely neighbourhood of Tokyo which does all of the basics very well. We paid around AUD$230/night for a Twin Room and for this price this hotel was excellent value. Room size was larger than other hotels and staff were friendly and helpful. Close to the fish market which is great if you're thinking about doing the early morning Tuna auction. Great area to stay as a couple or family with plenty of food and bar options close by without being directly in the madness of Shinjuku or Shibuya. No bells and whistles of a 5 star hotel like gyms and spa facilities but what they do, they do very well. Stay here!
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Stayed at Solaria for a total of 5 nights with my family. Staff was helpful in making reservations and brief recommendation on dining places around Ginza. Perfectly convenient location for anyone with kids or on a shopping trip. However, A male staff was especially impolite upon our departure to the airport this morning. After checking out, we booked a vehicle and were waiting at the hotel's entrance. He came out to ask for a room key card and demanded for us to pay for breakfast. Breakfast has been paid for, and his colleague has acknowledged that. We would have expected a "Thank You, see u again." , rather than such a demanding attitude. Without even checking, he was so confident in his demands. This was perhaps the most disappointing part of our experience with Solaria.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: You get what you pay for. The hotel is a no fuss hotel from check-in to check out.Friendly staffs and clean rooms. Probably my only concern is the small toilet space. However this is only a minor stay. Slept good (due to early flight to Tokyo?)The buffet breakfast is just okay with some unique dishes offered.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Great location, only 2 blocks of the main street in Ginza corner with the apple store. The staff was very helpful and the hotel very clean. Very well communicated, close to Ginza station and the Oi Oi Moll.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: This hotel is in an excellent location, and close to the subway, shops, fish market, restaurants, etc.As with the other hotels on our trip, my husband and I stayed in a twin room as they were larger than the double rooms. Our room in this hotel was probably the smallest room we stayed in, but that's to be expected given the location.As with our other hotels, our room was completely sound-proof and the air-conditioning was silent and effective (something that is sadly too rare, in our experience.) I loved the large walk-in shower and the bath products.I also enjoyed the breakfast area which was attractive and comfortable, and the breakfast buffet was the best we experienced on our trip.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: First time to Tokyo and this hotel did not disappoint. The rooms are tiny but super nice. You have everything you need in a teeny space - very comfy and clean. Loved the compact design and the energy efficiency. The skin products they placed in the room were lovely and the tub is way better than American designs. The lobby is nice and the staff was helpful. An AMAZING ramen restaurant right around the corner and lots of fun places to visit nearby. Close to the fish market, shopping, and dining. Priced right.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Very conveniently located in Ginza near the Ginza and Higashiginza subway stations, also 10 mins walking distance to Yurakucho JR Station. Very compact, very efficient in every way. Breakfast was fresh and just enough. The room, although small, had everything efficiently placed and was clean and thoughtful. Try the cream puff bakery right across the street, it was delicious!
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: We stayed at this hotel the last few days of our trip and it was nice to stay in a different area of Tokyo from the start of our trip. Though not very convenient to the city loop trains (Yamanote Line - free for JR Pass holders), there was a metro station just down the block. The hotel was stylish and comfortable and the staff helpful. We had a corner room which gave the impression that there was lots of room. By this point we were addicted to the Japanese baths and used the deep tub alcove and bath salts to the fullest extent!
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: A small boutique hotel with small rooms especially for 2 people with luggage. We always stay here before going on a cruise for Tokyo harbor. Although the front desk people spoke little English, I found it easy to communicate with them. The hotel is in the heart of Ginza, the major shopping area in Japan. It's centrally located to almost everything including train station and cruise ship terminal. Although you can get meals at the hotel, I always eat out.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The blanket and pillows are made of real feathers. You can ask at the reception to provide a synthetic cover instead, but no synthetic pillow. Good location: within 15 mins walk from the Tokyo station, close to different underground lines, the Tsukiji market and the Kabuki theatre; lots of luxury shops around. The single rooms are not well designed - the toilet and bathroom are on the side of the windows which are obscured with white film; there are some curtains but they don´t fully block out light. Standard rooms are laid out normally and have ligh-blocking curtains.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Everything about the hotel is perfect for a single traveller (rooms are small, but not a problem for one person) and the location is superb! My only minor complaint is that the very polite, well-intentioned front desk staff was always a chore to deal with for two reasons: 1) their English skills were VERY limited, and I say this not as some "dumb American" expecting everyone else to speak English -- I have studied and speak three foreign languages fluently myself, but not Japanese -- but as someone expecting that any hotel in the cosmopolitan, business-central Ginza District would be aware that a vast majority of guests from around the world might ONLY have English as a common communication means between each other...and 2) they were unaware of and ill-equipped to answer what I saw as some of the most common, basic tourist questions (i.e. how subway fares are purchased, where to catch a hop-on-hop-off tour bus, where the closest conveyor belt sushi restaurant is, how to get to a major performing arts center, or how to buy tickets for the Tokyo Sky Tree attraction). Almost every question I posed was greeted first by a blank stare and then 10-15 minutes of 2-3 desk staff people scurrying around doing research on the Internet and printing out useless pages of information. At one point, they even suggested I ask my questions to the neighborhood 7-Eleven!? This, as I told the hotel manager, is unacceptable in a hotel at the center of a major business district.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: This new hotel in Ginza was recommended by my friend. It is very Clean. We had good breakfast every morning in the hotel. It is a short walking distance to train station where we can go to different places like shibuya, shinjuku, roponggi, harajuku, etc. The bus station to AMD from Narita airport is a few steps from this hotel which makes it convenient for us. Good restaurants like ippudo ramen and ikinari steak are just right across the hotel. Very convenient and central.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Stayed @ the Solaria a number of times over the years for 3 reasons - Location, price and quality. You can't beat that it is in the middle of Ginza (100m or so off the main drag). For price, again for the quality you get it's heads and shoulders above other hotels in the area and the quality - Still feels like a new hotel and the service is good/consistent. Highly recommended for those looking for a cheaper option in downtown Tokyo! Oh, and internet is free - Bonus!
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Among many mid range hotel in this area, this hotel is popular because of good value for money. Though it is located in the middle of Ginza, a popular shopping district, the room is relatively spacious and the price is reasonable. All facilities are modern and the service is ok. This is more for business or quick holiday hotel.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Superb location in Ginza,which just one block behind Matsuya. For stations, easily reached from Ginza and Higashi Ginza. Small building but once you entered, well designed lobby, two smoothly working elevators, and the rooms are spacious compared to the other same level hotels in Ginza, especially the bathroom! Breakfast also was good with choice of Japanese and western. However, for staying more than 3 days, maybe you will have the 4th breakfast outside the hotel. Overall great hotel and will stay again here for sure!
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Have stayed in Ginza three times and this is the best value budget/mid range (for Ginza!) hotel I have stayed in. Bigger than average rooms, fantastic location for Ginza station (exit A13) and Higashi Ginza Station (exit A2) and close to everything you need. Great restaurants a short walk away. and Tsukiji market just a 10 min walk down the road.Excellent reception staff.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: The room is spacious when you compare with other hotels in Japan. And, it's location is perfect as it's only few minutes to nearby metro stations. As this trip is mainly for shopping & eating, I have lots of choices at nearby department stores & restaurants.Moreover, it's only 10-15 minutes walking distance to Tsukiji Market. Staff at front desk can speak English well that communication is not a problem at all.I will definitely recommend this hotel to my friends & will stay again next time in Tokyo.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Quiet location within Ginza close to all the shopping and excellent restaurants. The room is comfortable and well appointed though typically small. Has free wifi TV and the usual mod cons. The hotel has excellent English speaking service. Checkout is 11 AM and when we arrived they allowed us to check in at 1PM though usually its 3 PM
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Hotel location is very convenient and located in the pricey side of the city. 3 mins walk to Mitsukoshi Nihonbashi department store where the food court down on level B1 was fantastic and not to be missed. The room is clean but small which I guess is very typical in Tokyo. One thing that bothered me a little is the toilet in the bathroom, the flush is not very powerful due to the effort of water conservation but it can cause problems because we ended up having to flush multiple times. The front desk staffs speak adequate English, we didn't have any issue with communicating.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I've been to Tokyo a couple of times now, and I've come to conclusion that my favorite place to stay is at Solaria Hotel Ginza. Not only is it in the middle of Ginza, but it is affordable, highly maintained, and also walking distance to the Tokyo Metro.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Stayed for three nights. Excellent comfortable beds and good pillows. Great bathtub that came with various bath salts and stuff. Clean and well maintained. Front staff with limited English but trying their best.Room Japanese size smallish but OK (if a bit tight) with two giant suitcases and two people in twin room. Silent hotel and silent ac/heating.So so breakfast with somewhat limited selection (eg one black tea and one green and 650 Yen for a cappuccino) However the croissants require special mentioning as they were really really good.Many free umbrellas for borrow in the reception. When travelling to the airport (both) the closest metro is only 30 m from the hotel entrance just outside the Family Mart which is extremely convenient.The ice cream/cake parlour "Celi" on the corner opposite is worth a visit.Would stay again.
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: I needed to stay in Ginza due to work but I also wanted to be on a budget and I found Solaria for about $150/night. In Japan, there is a particular "businessman's hotel" which is sort of standardized. I guess you can consider it sort of like a hilton type model, as many of them are chains, however, Japanese standards are not like other standards, and these hotels are quite amazing and good and many of them are very well designed. They feel more like boutique hotels rather than a chain, especially the lobby and lounge areas. The only issue to watch out for is size of the rooms, but fortunately, Solaria was a totally normal sized room with a little sofa and desk area. Since I am only 5 feet tall, proportions don't matter as much to me, but I found this hotel quite adequate. both nights I had a bath in the very deep tubs and I found the hotel room bright and quiet. This hotel comes with the standard amenities of a business hotel (meaning, everything!!!) bath salts, toothbrushes, shampoos, and a million other amenities you probably didn't realize you needed in the bathroom. I did not eat the breakfast, but instead walked straight to tsujiki which is only about 10 minutes away for 830 am sushi and walked the markets. The hotel location is actually quite quite fabulous. very close to ginza train stations which there are several options, and about 900 yen taxi ride to Tokyo station. It's just removed from all the hustle and bustle of ginza, yet still extremely convenient. Mitsukoshi department store is right next door where you can go to the food halls in the basement(everyone needs to experience a department store food hall once in japan) and have some amazing local snacks and my fave stationary store K.itoya is close. There is a starbucks on every corner but there are also many better cafe's open (just not all of them open at 7 which is what I needed).
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: This hotel is well located and easy to access from most areas. Only one restrarunt but plenty around. Room clean and service staff great and helpful. There were a little thrown when two women wanted to sleep in a double bed. It is also disappointing that if you arrive before 3 and your room is ready they expect a fee.Otherwise I would recommend it
hotelName:
31    Solaria nishitetsu hotel Ginza
Name: hotel_name, dtype: object

review_body: Visited Tokyo in June. Very near the train station but other reviewers are correct - if you have luggage, use the exit with the elevator which is across the street from the hotel. You will have to roll all your luggage to cross the street then walk a little to get to the street of the hotel; it was really manageable. And coming from Haneda, the train stops in Ginza, no transfers. The fare was ¥610.Reserved 3 rooms for our family w/ bfast for 2 per room. Upon check in, without any prodding, the staff offered that the 2 kids with us would get free bfast. At bfast the next day, they didn't honor that, as in they acted like we were lying so since we didn't want to argue anymore we just signed for the kids. It took the front desk a day to tell us that they couldn't do anything as the owner of the Cafe is different from the owner of the hotel and they have their own rules. Huh??? Different policy for the Hotel Cafe??? So go figure haha. Anyway, the simple bfast was okay and filling even if it was the same the whole 6 days we were there - the breads were really good specially the mini chocolate Danish. Apart from the breakfast "misunderstanding", our stay at the hotel was good. The rooms were clean and we really liked the bathroom - others reviewers were right, the bathroom took up maybe 1/3 of the room so it was really comfortable. Rooms and bathrooms were very clean. The washroom at the lobby was even nicer than the one in the room - it was fully automatic in the same way as toilets in Japan but as you open the door, the toilet seat goes up. In the guest area downstairs there are also 2 computers with printer for the guests, as well as brochures and other tour pamphlets in English. You can also borrow umbrellas from the front desk.Behind the hotel is a shop which sells Yoga gear (I can't remember the name) and their bags are really nice. There was a Family Mart around the corner and a big drugstore that closes late and some vendo machines scattered around the hotel. You won't get hungry in that area, there are so many restaurants surrounding the hotel, like at least 2 per street (there's Japanese, Italian, Ramen, steak etc). There's a McDonald's 2 blocks away below Mercure Hotel, a Starbucks a few minutes from Solaria, a Lawson plus the Ramen restaurant right in front of the hotel. There are also 3 department stores in Ginza, we ate twice at Mitsukoshi, both at Japanese restaurants and both were really good. You can walk to all the shops in Ginza, everything is there. Aside from all the luxury brands and chain brands, there's a big music store - Yamaha near Zara and H&M. I think it has 12 floors and it had everything, guitars, straps, all sizes of amplifiers, music books. We only reached until the 3rd floor and we were there for more than 2 hours already. There's a money changer in Ginza at a building called Ginza Core, I think it's World Currency on the 5th floor of that bldg. Also, in case you need extra luggage and don't want to spend on expensive ones, they sell hard case luggage on the ground floor for only ¥5400, 3 sizes and different colors for the same price. Still on the ground floor, there's a store - Zoff - that's sells eyeglasses and sunglasses without or with prescription which you can claim 30 minutes to an hour after they check your eyes. The cheapest pairs, if I remember right, are sold for ¥7000 which includes prescription. They also make those with progressive ones but it will take more than a day. Tsukiji Market is also near the hotel, some family members walked there to eat and it took them 10 minutes. It's also just 1 station away from Ginza. Kabukiza Theatre is also just a little further down the street, with coffee shops on the ground floor while waiting for the show to start.
